Even when these expensive computational resources are available, model training also incurs a substantial cost to the environment due to the energy required to power this hardware for weeks or months at a time. [1] Though some of this energy may come from renewable or carbon credit-offset resources, the high energy demands of these models are still a concern since (1) energy is not currently derived from carbon-neural sources in many locations, and (2) when renewable energy is available, it is still limited to the equipment we have to produce and store it, and energy spent training a neural network might better be allocated to heating a family’s home. It is estimated that we must cut carbon emissions by half over the next decade to deter escalating rates of natural disaster, and based on the estimated CO2 emissions listed in Table 1, model training and development likely make up a substantial portion of the greenhouse gas emissions attributed to many NLP researchers. [2] 

To illustrate this point, let's consider a comparison of CO2 emissions from training NLP models versus everyday activities. As shown in Table 1, the estimated CO2 emissions from training common NLP models can be substantial, with some models emitting equivalent to a trans-American flight. For example, training BERT on a GPU is roughly equivalent to a trans-American flight. [10] In contrast, everyday activities have different CO2 emission profiles. For instance, an average American life over one year produces 36,156 lbs of CO2e emissions, which is significantly higher than the estimated CO2 emissions from training some NLP models. However, it's essential to note that these comparisons are rough estimates and depend on various factors, such as the specific model, hardware, and energy sources used.

The performance of BiDAF and FastQA models on the WikiHop and MedHop datasets is examined in this study. The results show that the performance of the BiDAF model outperforms the FastQA model across both datasets. In particular, under the standard conditions, BiDAF achieves accuracy rates of 42.9% on WikiHop and 47.8% on MedHop, while FastQA achieves accuracy rates of 25.7% on WikiHop and 23.1% on MedHop. However, when using the gold chain condition, BiDAF achieves accuracy rates of 57.9% on WikiHop and 86.4% on MedHop, significantly outperforming FastQA. 

![BiDAF vs FastQA on WikiHop under gold chain condition](image2)

![BiDAF vs FastQA on MedHop under gold chain condition](image9)

These findings suggest that the BiDAF model is better suited for capturing cross-document information and leveraging multiple steps of inference. The performance of the FastQA model is still respectable, especially under the standard conditions, but falls short of BiDAF's performance under the gold chain condition.

**Understanding the Impact of Positional Encodings and Loss Components on DETR-DC5's Performance**
===============================================================================

### Table 3: Results for different positional encodings compared to the baseline (last row)

|   | encoder  | decoder  | output pos. enc. | AP | Δ (Delta) AP |
| --- | ---------- | --- | --------------- | --- | -------------- |
| 1   | none       | sine at input | learned at attention | 35.8 | -4.8          |
| 2   | sine at input | sine at input | learned at attention | 39.9 | -0.7          |
| 3   | learned at attention | learned at attention | learned at input | 40.6 | -               |

The first row of table 3 shows that not using spatial positional encodings and passing output positional encodings at input leads to a significant drop in AP. The second row shows that passing fixed sine spatial positional encodings and output encodings at input leads to a minor AP drop compared to passing the positional encodings directly in attention. Learned spatial encodings passed to the attentions give similar results.

The last row of table 3 shows that passing learned spatial encodings to the attentions (which are shared across all layers) and learned output encodings (object queries) yields the best results in terms of AP.

### Decoder output slot analysis

Fig. 7 visualizes the boxes predicted by different slots for all images in COCO 2017 val set. DETR learns different specialization for each query slot. Each slot has several modes of operation focusing on different areas and box sizes. In particular, all slots have the mode for predicting image-wide boxes (visible as the red dots aligned in the middle of the plot). This is likely related to the distribution of objects in COCO.

### Generalization to unseen numbers of instances

Experiments were conducted to verify the generalization ability of DETR to unseen numbers of instances. A synthetic image with 24 giraffes was created to test the model's ability to find all giraffes on the image, which is clearly out of distribution. The model was able to find all giraffes on the synthetic image, confirming that there is no strong class-specialization in each object query.

### Extension to panoptic segmentation

Panoptic segmentation has recently attracted a lot of attention from the computer vision community. DETR can be naturally extended by adding a mask head on top of the decoder outputs to produce panoptic segmentation. This approach treats both stuffed and thing classes as object queries.

### Effect of NMS on performance

The importance of each decoder layer was analyzed by evaluating the objects that would be predicted at each stage of the decoding. Both AP and AP<sub>50</sub> improve after every layer, totaling into a significant +8.2/9.5 AP improvement between the first and the last layer. However, NMS improves performance for the predictions from the first decoder, but the improvement diminishes as depth increases.

### Comparison with other methods

Qualitative results are shown in Figure 9. In table 5, we compare our unified panoptic segmentation approach with several established methods that treat things and stuff classes separately. We report the Panoptic Quality (PQ) and the breakdown on things (PQ<sub>th</sub>) and stuff (PQ<sub>st</sub>). We also report the mask AP (computed on the things classes), before any panoptic post-treatment. We show that DETR outperforms published results on COCO-val 2017, as well as our strong Panoptic FPN baseline (trained with the same data-augmentation as DETR, for fair comparison). The result breakdown shows that DETR is especially dominant on stuff classes, and we hypothesize that the global reasoning allowed by the encoder attention is the key element to this result. For things class, despite a severe deficit of up to 8 mAP compared to the baselines on the mask AP computation, DETR obtains competitive PQ<sub>th</sub>. We also evaluated our method on the test set of the COCO dataset, and obtained 46 PQ.

These results indicate that ProgramFC facilitates more accurate fact-checking, particularly in complex claim scenarios.

To address the performance of ProgramFC, let's break down the details step-by-step.

ProgramFC combines symbolic programs with the flexibility of end-to-end neural models to aid fact-checking by generating reasoning plans. By assessing how well ProgramFC compares to other models in the realm of fact-checking, we can better understand its strengths and weaknesses.


**Comparison with Other Models:** ProgramFC, powered by Codex as the program generator, exhibits promising results, demonstrating efficiency and explainability when compared to models like InstructGPT and FLAN-T5. Specifically, ProgramFC improves upon InstructGPT and outperforms FLAN-T5 in terms of **retrieval recall** across various fact-checking tasks. Its performance indicates that ProgramFC effectively navigates complex claims through iterative retrieval and reasoning strategies, especially in scenarios that require multiple hops to verify claims.

**Error Trends:** Through the evaluation of its generated reasoning programs, ProgramFC displays an appreciable **reduction in syntax errors** compared to its predecessors, indicating its capacity to generate well-formed reasoning plans. However, **semantic errors** manifest in an increasing proportion with the complexity of the claims, underscoring the need for more sophisticated programs that account for intricate reasoning processes.

Considering the described performance and error trends, ProgramFC emerges as a highly effective tool for fact-checking, providing balanced capabilities in model capability, learning efficiency, and interpretability. This framework could be further refined by enhancing the efficiency of program generation and execution, facilitating real-world applications in more complex scenarios such as fake news detection and multi-modal fact-checking.

1.  **Pretraining**: Llama 2 undergoes pretraining on a large corpus of text to develop its language understanding.
2.  **Supervised Fine-Tuning**: The pre-trained model is then fine-tuned with supervised data to create an initial version of Llama 2-Chat.
3.  **Human Feedback**: The model utilizes human preference data to develop Safety Reward Models and Helpful Reward Models.
4.  **Fine-Tuning with RLHF**: The model undergoes Reinforcement Learning with Human Feedback (RLHF) using techniques such as Rejection Sampling and Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO).
5.  **Iterative Process**: The RLHF stage involves iterative refinement with accumulated reward modeling data to ensure that the reward models remain well-distributed.

Image1 depicts the flowchart of the training process, illustrating the iterative refinement of Llama 2-Chat models through human feedback and reinforcement learning.

### Conclusion

In conclusion, the safety performance of Llama 2-Chat models is comparable or lower than other AI models, as indicated by the benchmarks and human evaluations. The training processes that contribute to the safety features of Llama 2-Chat models include pretraining, supervised fine-tuning, human feedback, fine-tuning with RLHF, and an iterative process. These processes, combined with the openness and transparency of the Llama 2-Chat model, pave the way for more responsible development of LLMs and their deployment in various applications.

**Incorporating Logical Constraints and Demonstration Samples for Enhanced Model Performance**
====================================================================================

The use of logical constraints and demonstration samples significantly impacts the performance of different models on the MAVEN-ERE and Causal-TimeBank datasets. Our experiments demonstrate that incorporating logical constraints leads to substantial improvements in model performance, particularly in terms of Micro-F1 scores. Moreover, the introduction of demonstration samples as an additional factor enhances the performance of models, with the optimal balance between demonstration samples and logical constraints leading to the best results.

**Effect of Logical Constraints on Model Performance**
-------------------------------------------------

*   Our findings indicate that directly adding logical constraints to the model's input results in significant improvements in Micro-F1 scores, with some models achieving Micro-F1 scores of up to 26.4% on the MAVEN-ERE dataset.
*   Additionally, we observe that incorporating logical constraints with retrieval-based approaches further enhances model performance, with some models achieving Micro-F1 scores of up to 18.0% on the MAVEN-ERE dataset.
*   However, adding irrelevant logical constraints can lead to fluctuations in model performance, highlighting the need for careful selection of logical constraints.

**Impact of Demonstration Samples on Model Performance**
---------------------------------------------------

*   Our experiments show that the introduction of demonstration samples as an additional factor significantly enhances model performance, with some models achieving Micro-F1 scores of up to 26.4% on the MAVEN-ERE dataset.
*   Moreover, we observe that the optimal balance between demonstration samples and logical constraints leads to the best results, with some models achieving Micro-F1 scores of up to 18.0% on the MAVEN-ERE dataset.
*   Notably, the use of demonstration samples with logical constraints leads to a significant reduction in logical inconsistency, indicating improved model performance.

**Comparison of Model Performance**
----------------------------------

*   A comparison of the performance of different models on the MAVEN-ERE and Causal-TimeBank datasets reveals that models with logical constraints and demonstration samples perform significantly better than those without.
*   The results indicate that the optimal configuration of logical constraints and demonstration samples leads to the best performance, with some models achieving Micro-F1 scores of up to 26.4% on the MAVEN-ERE dataset.

**Conclusion**
----------

In conclusion, the use of logical constraints and demonstration samples has a significant impact on the performance of different models on the MAVEN-ERE and Causal-TimeBank datasets. Our findings highlight the importance of careful selection of logical constraints and the optimal balance between demonstration samples and logical constraints in achieving improved model performance.

![Micro-F1 Scores on MAVEN-ERE Dataset](image3)
![Logical Inconsistency on MAVEN-ERE Dataset](image3)

These results demonstrate the effectiveness of incorporating logical constraints and demonstration samples in enhancing model performance, and provide valuable insights for future research and applications.

Logical constraints and post-processing have been shown to significantly reduce logical inconsistency in LLMs. Studies have demonstrated that incorporating logical constraints can improve performance, especially when compared to models without such constraints. For instance, in the comparison of model performance on the MAVEN-ERE and Causal-TimeBank datasets, the results show that models with logical constraints outperform those without, as evidenced by lower logical inconsistency (LI) percentages. 

Moreover, the results indicate that post-processing can further reduce logical inconsistency, with the lowest LI percentages observed in models that have undergone post-processing. The effectiveness of post-processing, however, may come at the cost of potentially affecting the quality of the generated answers due to the random selection of candidate sets. As a result, the optimal approach may involve combining logical constraints and post-processing to achieve the best balance between performance and consistency.

Our aim with  MMMU  is to push the boundaries of what LMMs can achieve. We believe it will prove instrumental in developing next-generation multimodal foundation models and monitoring the progress towards Expert AGI. We shall caution that  MMMU  is not a  sufficient  test for Expert AGI, as per the definition [ 44 ], because there lacks a direct map- ping between performance on  MMMU  and “90th percentile of skilled adults,” nor are college exams the only tasks an AGI shall tackle. However, we believe it should be  necessary  for an Expert AGI to achieve strong performance on  MMMU  to demonstrate their broad and deep subject knowledge as well as expert-level understanding and reasoning capabilities. [4] to holistic ally evaluate LMMs’ general multimodal percep- tion and reasoning abilities. Therefore, numerous all-round benchmarks have been established to assess different facets of LMMs. These benchmarks cover a wide spectrum of specific skills of LMMs, from Optical Character Recogni- tion (OCR) as seen in the study by [ 37 ], to adversarial ro- bustness [ 68 ] and hallucination [ 13,  32 ], e.g., POPE [ 30 ] and HaELM [ 54 ]. More holistic evaluations have been con- ducted as well, such as LAMM [ 61 ], LVLM-eHub [ 57 ], SEED [ 25 ], MMBench [ 36 ], and MM-Vet [ 63 ]. These benchmarks still largely focus on relatively basic percep- tion abilities without requiring expert-level domain knowl- edge and deliberate reasoning. More recently, MathVista [ 40 ] presents a collection of visually challenging questions; however, its scope is limited exclusively to the mathemat- ical domain.  MMMU  is highly different from these bench- marks by collecting more difficult expert-level problems that cover 30 different subjects and require nuanced percep- tion, recalling domain-specific knowledge to perform step- by-step reasoning to derive the solution. In line with the mo- tivation of our study, concurrently, GAIA [ 42 ] introduces 466 questions that test fundamental abilities of models such as reasoning, multi modality handling, or tool use. [4]

Our  MMMU  benchmark introduces four key challenges to multimodal foundation models, as detailed in  Figure 1. Among these, we particularly highlight the challenge stem- ming from the requirement for both expert-level visual perceptual abilities and deliberate reasoning with subject- specific knowledge. This challenge is vividly illustrated through our tasks, which not only demand the processing of various heterogeneous image types but also necessitate a model’s adeptness in using domain-specific knowledge to deeply understand both the text and images and to reason. This goes significantly beyond basic visual perception, call- ing for an advanced approach that integrates advanced mul- timodal analysis with domain-specific knowledge. [2]

According to the detailed statistics in **Figure 3**, our benchmark collection takes three stages. Firstly, we go through the common university majors to decide what subjects should be included in our benchmark. The selection is based on the principle that vi- sual inputs should be commonly adopted in the subjects to provide valuable information. Through this principle, we rule out a few subjects like law and linguistics because it is difficult to find enough relevant multimodal problems in these subjects. Consequently, we select 30 subjects from six different disciplines. In the second stage, we recruit over 50 university students, including co-authors, specializing in these majors as annotators to assist in question collection. They collect multimodal questions from major textbooks and online resources, creating new questions based on their expertise where necessary. The annotators are instructed to adhere to copyright and license regulations, avoiding data from sites prohibiting copy and redistribution. The MMMU benchmark is designed to measure three essential skills in LMMs: perception, knowledge, and reasoning. Our aim is to evaluate how well these models can not only perceive and understand information across different modalities but also apply reasoning with subject- specific knowledge to derive the solution. [7]

We introduce the Massive Multi-discipline Multimodal Un- der standing and Reasoning ( MMMU ) benchmark, a novel benchmark meticulously curated to assess the expert-level multimodal understanding capability of foundation models across a broad scope of tasks. Covering 30 subjects across 6 disciplines, including Art, Business, Health & Medicine, Science, Humanities & Social Science, and Tech & Engi- neering, and over 183 subfields. The detailed subject cover- age and statistics are detailed in  Figure 3. The questions in our benchmark were manually collected by a team of 50 college students (including coauthors) from various dis- ciplines and subjects, drawing from online sources, text- books, and lecture materials. [4]

**MMMU Benchmark: A Comprehensive Multi-Disciplinary and Multi-Modal Assessment of Reasoning and Knowledge**

To answer your question, the MMMU benchmark stands out for its **breadth** and **depth** in assessing reasoning and knowledge capabilities of LMMs. Unlike other benchmarks that focus on specific skills or domains, MMMU covers a wide range of **30 subjects** across six disciplines, including Art, Business, Health & Medicine, Science, Humanities & Social Sciences, and Tech & Engineering. This provides a comprehensive evaluation of LMMs' ability to reason and understand complex information across various domains.

[Figure 1] illustrates the four key challenges of MMMU, which are:

1.  **Comprehensive Disciplines**: The dataset includes 11.5K college-level problems across six broad disciplines.
2.  **Heterogeneous Image Types**: The dataset features a wide variety of image types, such as diagrams, tables, plots, photographs, chemical structures, paintings, medical images, and more.
3.  **Interleaved Text and Images**: The problems in the dataset involve both text and images interleaved together, requiring the model to jointly understand the images and text.
4.  **Expert-level Skills Test**: The dataset tests expert-level visual perception and reasoning, requiring the model to apply logical, spatial, and commonsense reasoning.

These features distinguish MMMU from other benchmarks, which often focus on specific skills or domains. For instance, while VQA and GQA are excellent benchmarks for visual question answering, they lack the breadth and depth of MMMU.

**Image Usage and Question Formats**

MMMU features a wide range of image types, including:

*   Diagrams
*   Tables
*   Plots
*   Photographs
*   Chemical structures
*   Paintings
*   Medical images
*   Sheet music
*   Geometric shapes
*   Pathology images
*   Microscopic images
*   Comics

These images are used in various formats, including:

*   Images at the beginning
*   Images in the middle
*   Images at the end
*   Images in options
*   Examples with multiple images

The question formats in MMMU include:

*   Multiple-choice questions
*   Open questions
*   Questions with explanations

These features make MMMU an excellent benchmark for evaluating LMMs' ability to reason and understand complex information across various domains.

In conclusion, the MMMU benchmark is a comprehensive multi-disciplinary and multi-modal assessment of reasoning and knowledge capabilities of LMMs. Its breadth and depth, heterogeneous image types, interleaved text and images, and expert-level skills test make it an excellent benchmark for evaluating LMMs' abilities.

Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) systems have emerged as a promising solution for enhancing the accuracy and credibility of generation, particularly for knowledge-intensive tasks. Here's how RAG synergistically merges Large Language Models (LLMs) intrinsic knowledge with the vast, dynamic repositories of external databases.

Two prominent evaluation frameworks for RAG systems focus on both retrieval and generation quality, including RGB, RECALL, and CRUD. These frameworks assess various aspects, such as:

*   **Context Relevance:** Accuracy, EM, Recall, Precision, Cosine Similarity, Hit Rate, MRR, and ROUGE/ROUGE-L.
*   **Faithfulness:** Accuracy, EM, BLEU, and ROUGE/ROUGE-L.
*   **Answer Relevance:** Accuracy, EM, and R-Rate.
*   **Noise Robustness:** Accuracy, Recall, and Precision.
*   **Negative Rejection:** Accuracy and EM.
*   **Information Integration:** Accuracy, MRR, and ROUGE/ROUGE-L.
*   **Counterfactual Robustness:** Accuracy and ROUGE/ROUGE-L.

Using these frameworks, RAG systems can effectively evaluate their performance on various tasks, including dialogue, question answering, summarization, and fact verification. For instance, the RGB framework assesses retrieval quality and generation quality, while the RECALL framework focuses on generation quality and counterfactual robustness.

The use of metrics such as Accuracy, EM, and ROUGE/ROUGE-L helps evaluate the faithfulness and answer relevance of generated answers, while metrics like MRR and Hit Rate assess the context relevance and information integration. The evaluation of noise robustness and negative rejection ensures that the system can handle noisy or irrelevant input.

Overall, the evaluation frameworks for RAG systems provide a comprehensive assessment of their performance and help identify areas for improvement.

Here is the interleaved text and image response to the question:
### Evaluation Frameworks for RAG Systems
Two prominent evaluation frameworks for RAG systems focus on both retrieval and generation quality, including RGB, RECALL, and CRUD. These frameworks assess various aspects, such as:

#### RGB Framework
The RGB framework assesses retrieval quality and generation quality. It uses the following metrics to evaluate the performance of RAG systems:
*   **Accuracy:** Measures the proportion of correct answers.
*   **EM (Exact Match):** Measures the exact match between generated and expected answers.
*   **Accuracy:** Measures the proportion of correct answers.

#### RECALL Framework
The RECALL framework focuses on generation quality and counterfactual robustness. It uses the following metrics to evaluate the performance of RAG systems:
*   **R-Rate (Reappearance Rate):** Measures the proportion of correct answers that reappear in the test set.

#### CRUD Framework
The CRUD framework assesses retrieval quality, generation quality, creative generation, knowledge-intensive QA, error correction, and summarization. It uses the following metrics to evaluate the performance of RAG systems:
*   **BLEU:** Measures the similarity between generated and expected answers.
*   **ROUGE-L:** Measures the similarity between generated and expected answers.
*   **BertScore:** Measures the similarity between generated and expected answers.

### Evaluation Metrics
Using these frameworks, RAG systems can effectively evaluate their performance on various tasks, including dialogue, question answering, summarization, and fact verification. The use of metrics such as Accuracy, EM, and ROUGE/ROUGE-L helps evaluate the faithfulness and answer relevance of generated answers, while metrics like MRR and Hit Rate assess the context relevance and information integration.

The evaluation of noise robustness and negative rejection ensures that the system can handle noisy or irrelevant input.

### Advantages of RAG Systems
RAG systems have several advantages over traditional language generation models, including:

*   **Improved accuracy and credibility:** RAG systems can generate more accurate and credible answers by leveraging external knowledge sources.
*   **Flexibility and scalability:** RAG systems can be easily integrated with other applications and can handle a wide range of tasks and domains.
*   **Robustness to noise and irrelevant input:** RAG systems can handle noisy or irrelevant input and can generate accurate answers even in the presence of errors or ambiguities.

Overall, RAG systems offer a promising solution for various NLP tasks, including dialogue, question answering, summarization, and fact verification.

### Evaluation Frameworks and Metrics
Several evaluation frameworks have been proposed to assess RAG's retrieval and generation quality. The metrics used in these frameworks include:

#### Benchmark Frameworks
- **RGB†**: Assessments include accuracy, EM (Exact Match), Accuracy, and Cosine Similarity.
- **RECALL†**: Focuses on generation quality and counterfactual robustness, using R-Rate (Reappearance Rate) as a metric.
- **CRUD†**: Evaluates creative generation, knowledge-intensive QA, error correction, and summarization using BLEU, ROUGE-L, BertScore, and RAGQuestEval.

#### Automated Tools
- **RAGAS‡**: Assesses context relevance, faithfulness, and answer relevance, using * as unspecified metrics.
- **ARES‡**: Evaluates context relevance, faithfulness, and answer relevance, using accuracy, accuracy, and accuracy as metrics.
- **TruLens‡**: Also assesses context relevance, faithfulness, and answer relevance, but uses * as unspecified metrics.

### Key Differences Across Frameworks
The choice of evaluation aspects and metrics varies significantly across different frameworks. While some frameworks focus on a broad range of aspects, others concentrate on specific criteria that might be relevant to particular tasks or use cases. Understanding these differences is crucial for developing effective evaluation strategies that can accurately capture the strengths and weaknesses of RAG models.

As noted in [4], traditional measures do not yet represent a mature or standardized approach for quantifying RAG evaluation aspects. Developing custom metrics tailored to the nuances of RAG models is essential to address these limitations and provide a more comprehensive understanding of RAG's capabilities.

The ongoing efforts to improve RAG's robustness, handle extended contexts, and expand its application scope into multimodal domains underscore the importance of rigorous evaluation and the need for innovative evaluation frameworks and metrics.

**[1] Advanced RAG introduces specific improvements to overcome the limitations of Naive RAG.** The key enhancements include pre-retrieval and post-retrieval strategies to boost retriaval quality, as well as refined indexing techniques such as a sliding window approach, fine-grained segmentation, and metadata incorporation. These advancements further improve the overall retrieval process. **![Advanced RAG enhances retriaval quality](image1)**
 
 **Advanced RAG** is built upon **Naive RAG**, addressing its limitations through a series of optimizations. Specifically, it **incorporates pre-retrieval and post-retrieval strategies**, which significantly enhance the quality of retrieval, making it a crucial step towards effective RAG. Additionally, it **refines indexing techniques**, ensuring a more efficient retrieval process.

 
 **Modular RAG** takes the RAG paradigm to the next level by introducing various specialized components, including the search module, RAG-Fusion, memory module, routing module, and task adapter module. These components work together to streamline the retrieval process and improve the quality and relevance of the information retrieved. **![Modular RAG components](image3)**
 
 The introduction of **Modular RAG** offers enhanced adaptability and versatility. It includes strategies for improving components such as indexing, query, and embedding optimization. Furthermore, innovations like restructured RAG modules and rearranged RAG pipelines have been introduced to tackle specific challenges. Despite its distinctiveness, Modular RAG builds upon the foundational principles of Advanced and Naive RAG, illustrating a progression and refinement within the RAG family.

The Naive RAG follows a traditional process that includes indexing, retrieval, and generation, which is also characterized as a “Retrieve-Read” framework [7]. 
![Naive RAG process](image1_left)
In contrast, Advanced RAG builds on naive RAG, adding optimization strategies in pre-retrieval (e.g., query routing, rewriting, expansion) and post-retrieval stages (e.g., reranking, summarization, fusion). 
![Advanced RAG process](image1_middle)
On the other hand, Modular RAG enhances flexibility by introducing various specific functional modules. It includes iterative and adaptive processes like routing, searching, retrieving, reading, predicting, rewriting, reranking, demonstrating, and fusion. 
![Modular RAG process](image1_right)
These differences enable Modular RAG to tackle complex tasks more effectively, such as handling extended contexts, adapting to diverse data forms, and integrating with other AI methodologies.

RAPTOR, a novel tree-based retrieval system, presents a novel approach to augmenting parametric knowledge of large language models with contextual information at various levels of abstraction. The system leverages recursive clustering and summarization techniques to create a hierarchical tree structure that synthesizes information across various sections of the retrieval corpora. 

[1] In this paper, we have presented RAPTOR, a novel tree-based retrieval system that augments the parametric knowledge of large language models with contextual information at various levels of abstraction. By employing recursive clustering and summarization techniques, RAPTOR creates a hierarchical tree structure that is capable of synthesizing information across various sections of the retrieval corpora. During the query phase, RAPTOR leverages this tree structure for more effective retrieval. Our controlled experiments demonstrated that RAPTOR not only outperforms traditional retrieval methods but also sets new performance benchmarks on several question-answering tasks.

The multimodal retriever system is designed to efficiently encode and store a large volume of images/text embeddings for quick, accurate retrieval. In the process of multimodal retriever, the main challenge lies in creating and storing multimodal embeddings, with a focus on optimizing retrieval speed through index construction techniques. As shown in Fig.  2, the retriever creates and stores multimodal embeddings, which is then used for ranking and classification tasks. 
![Multimodal retriever and storage of embeddings](image4)

In the context of object recognition on detection datasets, the multimodal retriever system processes and ranks objects as follows:
 
1.  Pre-processing: 
    *   An image with multiple bounding boxes is shown, each highlighting different objects (e.g., flowers and a vase).
    *   These objects are cropped and resized to create individual embeddings using an Image Encoder.
2.  Embedding & Retrieve: 
    *   The image embeddings are used in a k-nearest neighbors (k-NN) search.
    *   An index is created for these embeddings, linked to a memory storage (Memory M).
    *   The retrieval process associates each bounding box with possible labels.
3.  Ranking and Classification: 
    *   The top-k retrieved results are sent to the Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs) for further ranking and classification.
    *   The MLLMs combine the internal knowledge and the retrieved information to make the final prediction of the image category.

The process of using the multimodal retriever system for object recognition in detection datasets involves the following steps:

1.  Image Encoding: The image is encoded into feature embeddings using an Image Encoder.
2.  Index Construction: The embeddings are stored in a memory index for efficient retrieval.
3.  Retrieval: The top-k similar results are retrieved from the memory index based on similarity.
4.  Ranking: The retrieved results are ranked using Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs).
5.  Classification: The final prediction is made based on the ranked results.

The multimodal retriever system enhances recognition tasks by combining multi-modal data retrieval and ranking processes, addressing the limitations of fine-grained recognition and preserving the model's comprehensive knowledge base.

Step-Back + RAG's error analysis results differ between TimeQA and StrategyQA in terms of dataset examples and task type. In TimeQA, Step-Back + RAG fixes 21.6% of errors coming from RAG, and introduces 6.3% of errors to RAG, as illustrated in Figure 6. According to Table 3, various baselines have been tested on the MuSiQue and StrategyQA datasets. Baseline performance of PaLM-2L and GPT-4 is low $(35.5\%$ and  $38.5\%$ for PaLM-2L and GPT-4 respectively) in MuSiQue since it is a hard multihop reasoning behchmark. 

In contrast, StrategyQA has stronger baselines $(82.8\%$ and  $78.3\%$ for PaLM-2L and GPT4 respectively) probably because of the binary fication task. CoT and TDB improve model performance a bit in case of MuSiQue (  $\sim3\%$   and 3.5% respectively) which can be attributed to the inherent reasoning nature of this task where these methods are shown to be helpful. In case of StrategyQA, there is no signficant performance gain with COT and TDB which could be due to the high baseline performance in this task, with limited scope for these prompting methods to improve performance.

### Comparison to GPT-4 and Baseline Models

PaLM-2L + Step-Back + RAG (ours) achieves the highest performance in both MuSiQue and StrategyQA: $42.8\%$ and $86.4\%$, respectively, outperforming GPT-4 on both tasks.

### Common Error Types Associated with Step-Back Prompting

Despite its strong performance, Step-Back Prompting is associated with several errors, mainly falling into the Reasoning Error (55%) and Math Error (25%) categories. It's worth noting that a very small fraction of errors occur due to Principle Error, which refers to the failure of the Abstraction step. The failure rate of Step-Back Prompting can be attributed to the complexity of tasks such as MMLU Physics, which demands deep reasoning and math skills.

In comparing PaLM-2L with Step-Back and RAG, we can observe that this method produces outstanding performance across multiple QA tasks, including TimeQA, MuSiQue, and StrategyQA. PaLM-2L with Step-Back and RAG consistently outperforms other methods in achieving high accuracy on these benchmarks.

**SnapNTell Model Performance and Key Components**
====================================================================

### **Evaluation Metrics**

The SnapNTell model is evaluated using three key metrics: Recognition Accuracy, Response Accuracy, and Pairwise Comparison.

[1] (1) The model achieves high Recognition Accuracy, correctly identifying entities in the image relevant to the question.

[2] (2) Response Accuracy is also high, indicating factual correctness and minimal signs of hallucination. This suggests that the model provides accurate and reliable responses.

[3] (3) Pairwise Comparison reveals that the SnapNTell model outperforms other baseline models in terms of contextual appropriateness and accuracy, with the highest win percentage among all models.

### **Retrieval Augmentation**

Retrieval augmentation is a crucial component of the SnapNTell model, which involves using recognized entities to retrieve additional information from a database. This step significantly enhances performance across various entity types, particularly long-tailed entities.

[4] (4) The introduction of retrieval augmentation leads to improved performance, as evident from the table showing comparative results between baseline models and the SnapNTell model.

[6] (6) The results demonstrate that retrieval augmentation can significantly enhance performance across various entity types, particularly long-tailed entities, effectively addressing the challenge of hallucinations in these entities.

### **Key Components**

The SnapNTell model's success can be attributed to the following key components:

*   **Retrieval Augmentation**: This step enables the model to retrieve additional information from a database, enhancing performance across various entity types.
*   **Entity Detection & Recognition Models**: Accurate entity detection and recognition are critical for the model's performance, allowing it to identify relevant entities in the image.
*   **Large Language Model (LLM)**: The LLM is used to combine image and textual data, producing accurate and coherent answers.

These components work together to enable the SnapNTell model to achieve high performance, outperforming other baseline models in terms of accuracy and pairwise comparison.

### **Comparison with Other Models**

The SnapNTell model is compared with other baseline models, including Mini-GPT4, Open-Flamingo, COGVLM, mPLUG-Owl2, LLaVA 1.5, and a human-annotated ground truth. The results show that the SnapNTell model has the highest win percentage, indicating its superior performance.

[8] (8) The table comparing various methods using four evaluation metrics reveals that the SnapNTell model outperforms other baseline models, with the highest scores across all four metrics.

[9] (9) The proposed method, SnapNTell, is specifically designed to tackle the challenge of long-tail entity queries, which often lead to inaccurate or hallucinated responses.

### **Impact of Entity Detection**

Entity detection is a critical component of the SnapNTell model, and its impact is assessed through an ablation study. The results show that the approach incorporating entity detection markedly surpasses the variant lacking this feature.

[10] (10) The ablation study highlights the significant contribution and necessity of entity detection in the model's overall effectiveness.

```markdown
### **Summary**

The SnapNTell model achieves high performance in terms of accuracy and pairwise comparison, outperforming other baseline models. The key components contributing to its success include retrieval augmentation, entity detection & recognition models, and a large language model (LLM). The model's performance is also enhanced by the incorporation of entity detection, which significantly improves its effectiveness.
```

The inclusion of entity detection (ED) in the SnapNTell approach has a profoundly positive impact on its performance across various evaluation metrics. 
[4] The ablation study presented in the paper, comparing the performance of the SnapNTell model with and without the ED component, reveals that the model without ED fared significantly worse than the variant incorporating ED, with notable declines in metrics such as ROUGE (from 35.28 to 28.02), BLEU (from 7.81 to 3.73), METEOR (from 29.27 to 26.26), and BELURT (from 0.55 to 0.45).

# Comparison of BERT-MRC Model Enhancements Across Datasets

According to the experiments, the enhancements to the BERT-MRC model show significant improvements across various datasets.

## Models and Baseline Performance

The BERT-MRC baseline model achieves the following F1 scores on the MRPC and QQP datasets:

- **BERT-MRC**: MRPC F1 = 91.11, QQP F1 = 93.04

## Enhancements and Performance

The enhancements to the BERT-MRC model, specifically FL, DL, and DSC, result in the following F1 score improvements:

- **BERT-MRC+FL**: MRPC F1 = 91.22 (+0.11 improvement over baseline), QQP F1 = 93.11 (+0.07 improvement)
- **BERT-MRC+DL**: MRPC F1 = 91.88 (+0.77 improvement), QQP F1 = 93.17 (+0.13 improvement)
- **BERT-MRC+DSC**: MRPC F1 = 92.07 (+0.96 improvement), QQP F1 = 93.33 (+0.29 improvement)

These enhancements demonstrate significant improvements in F1 score for the BERT-MRC model across various datasets.

[1] Notably, the proposed DSC loss achieves the highest F1 score across all datasets. Specifically, for positive datasets, DSC achieves minor improvements $(+0.05\,\mathrm{F}1)$ over DL. In contrast, it significantly outperforms DL for negative datasets. This is in line with our expectation since DSC helps more on more imbalanced datasets. The performance of FL and DL are not consistent across different datasets, while DSC consistently performs the best on all datasets.

![The table comparing the performance of different models on various datasets for question answering tasks. The key metrics reported are Exact Match (EM) and F1 scores across SQuAD v1.1, SQuAD v2.0, and QuoRef datasets. Each model is evaluated alone and with enhancements (FL, DL, DSC).](image1)

In this study, the performance of BERT and XLNet models was compared across different datasets, including MRPC, QQP, SQuAD v1.1, SQuAD v2.0, and QuoRef, in terms of F1 scores. The results show that while baseline BERT and XLNet models are strong performers, applying additional techniques such as feature labeling (FL), loss modification (DL), and dice-based loss (DSC) can bring about further improvements.

![The table presents F1 scores for different models on the MRPC and QQP datasets.](image5)

For instance, on the MRPC dataset, BERT+FL achieved a slight improvement, while BERT+DL provided a moderate boost. In contrast, BERT+DSC demonstrated the most significant improvements, outperforming the baseline model by a substantial margin.

Similarly, on the QQP dataset, XLNet+FL also showed a minor improvement, while XLNet+DL provided a more substantial gain. Again, XLNet+DSC achieved the highest scores, surpassing the baseline model by a significant margin.

These findings suggest that the proposed dice-based loss (DSC) can be a valuable addition to BERT and XLNet models, leading to improved performance on various datasets. The variation in performance across different datasets highlights the importance of dataset-specific adaptations and the need for more nuanced evaluation methods.

A key takeaway from this study is that the choice of loss function can have a substantial impact on model performance, particularly for tasks that involve imbalanced datasets. The proposed DSC loss, which incorporates a soft version of the F1 score, appears to be particularly effective in addressing this challenge.

In terms of limitations, it is worth noting that this study primarily focused on BERT and XLNet models, with fewer experiments conducted on other architectures. Future studies could benefit from exploring the performance of these models on additional architectures and datasets.

**Overview of Translation Quality Evaluation**
 COMET-RANK and BLEU are two prominent metrics used to evaluate machine translation quality. 

[1] Classic MT evaluation metrics are commonly characterized as $n$-gram matching metrics, which estimate MT quality by counting the number and fraction of $n$-grams that appear simultaneously in a candidate translation hypothesis and one or more human-references.

[2] For analysis, we use the DA RR corpus from the 2019 Shared Task and evaluate on the subset of the data from the top performing MT systems for each language pair. We included language pairs for which we could retrieve data for at least ten different MT systems (i.e., all but kk-en and gu-en).

[3] In this paper, we present COMET, a novel neural framework for training MT evaluation models that can serve as automatic metrics and easily be adapted and optimized to different types of human judgements of MT quality.

[4] All three of our COMET models were trained on data involving English (either as a source or as a target). Nevertheless, to demonstrate that our metrics generalize well, we test them on the three WMT 2019 language pairs that do not include English in either source or target.

[5] To shed some light on the actual value and contribution of the source language input in our models' ability to learn accurate predictions, we trained two versions of our DA RR Ranker model: one that uses only the reference, and another that uses both reference and source.

[6] Learnable metrics (Shimanaka et al., 2018; Mathur et al., 2019; Shimanaka et al., 2019) attempt to directly optimize the correlation with human judgments, and have recently shown promising results. B LEURT (Sellam et al., 2020), a learnable metric based on BERT (Devlin et al., 2019), claims state-of-the-art performance for the last 3 years of the WMT Metrics Shared task.

[7] Clearly, the inclusion of the source language in our models has a positive impact on the correlation with human judgments. Furthermore, the second variant of the model was exposed to English embeddings, which is not present in the training data.

[8] In recent years, word embeddings (Mikolov et al., 2013; Pennington et al., 2014; Peters et al., 2018; Devlin et al., 2019) have emerged as a commonly used alternative to $n$-gram matching for capturing word semantics similarity. Embedding-based metrics like M ETEOR-Vectorizer (Servan et al., 2016), B LEU 2 VEC (Tattar and Fishel, 2017), Y I S I-1 (Lo, 2019), M OVERSCORE (Zhao et al., 2019), and B ERTSCORE (Zhang et al., 2020) create soft-alignments between reference and hypothesis in an embedding space and then compute a score that reflects the semantic similarity between those segments.

[9] Table 2 shows results for the seven to-English language pairs. Again, we contrast our three COMET models against baseline metrics such as B LEU and CHR F, the 2019 task-winning metric Y I S I-1, as well as the recently published metrics B ERTSCORE and B LEURT.

[10] Table 1 shows results for all eight language pairs with English as source. We contrast our three COMET models against baseline metrics such as B LEU and CHR F, the 2019 task-winning metric Y I S I-1, as well as the more recent B ERTSCORE.

CodeBERT, a bimodal pre-trained model, has been shown to excel in various probing tasks related to programming languages (PL) and natural languages (NL) across different programming languages. **Probing Tasks Performance**

**CodeBERT's Strengths**
-----------------------

CodeBERT's success can be attributed to its ability to learn general-purpose representations that support downstream NL-PL applications. The use of a hybrid objective function that incorporates replaced token detection enables the model to utilize both "bimodal" data of NL-PL pairs and "unimodal" data, leading to better performance.

Furthermore, CodeBERT's ability to fine-tune model parameters for specific downstream tasks enhances its adaptability and ability to generalize across different programming languages.

**Future Research Directions**
-----------------------------

While CodeBERT has demonstrated impressive performance in probing tasks, there is room for improvement. Future research directions could focus on learning better generators with bimodal evidence, incorporating more complex neural architectures, and exploring generation-related learning objectives.

By addressing these areas, researchers can further enhance CodeBERT's capabilities and push the boundaries of what is possible in NL-PL applications.

**Conclusion**
--------------

In conclusion, CodeBERT's performance in probing tasks based on programming and natural languages across different programming languages is exceptional. Its ability to learn general-purpose representations, fine-tune model parameters, and utilize bimodal and unimodal data makes it a strong contender in the field of NL-PL applications.

**Overview of DeClarE Model Configurations**
-----------------------------------------

The DeClarE model is evaluated on four main configurations:

*   **DeClarE (Plain)**: This configuration includes a biLSTM layer without attention and source embeddings.
*   **DeClarE (Plain+Attn)**: This configuration adds an attention mechanism to the previous configuration.
*   **DeClarE (Plain+SrEmb)**: This configuration includes source embeddings in addition to the attention mechanism.
*   **DeClarE (Full)**: This configuration includes all the components mentioned in the previous configurations.

**Comparison of DeClarE Model Performance Across Datasets**
---------------------------------------------------------

The performance of the DeClarE model is compared across different datasets and configurations:

*   **Snopes and PolitiFact Datasets**: The model is compared to other approaches like LSTM-text and CNN-text models.
*   **NewsTrust Dataset**: The model is evaluated in terms of mean squared error (MSE) for credibility rating prediction.
*   **SemEval Dataset**: The model is compared to other approaches like NileTMRG and IITP on the close and open variants of the task.

**Comparative Analysis of LANI and CHAI Datasets**
The comparative analysis of the LANI and CHAI datasets reveals key differences in task completion and performance metrics between the two datasets.

**Key Differences in Task Completion and Performance Metrics:**
1.  **Metrics Used:** The metrics used for evaluation differ between the two datasets. For LANI, the metrics include stop distance (SD) and task completion (TC), while for CHAI, the metrics are stop distance (SD) and manipulation accuracy (MA).
2.  **Error Rates:** The error rates for both datasets are relatively high, indicating the complexity of the tasks. The SD for LANI is 5.2, with successful task completion (TC) at 63%, while the SD for CHAI is 1.34, with manipulation accuracy at 100%.
3.  **Human Performance:** Human performance on the tasks is imperfect, with a stop distance error (SD) of 5.2 on LANI and 1.34 on CHAI. The human manipulation accuracy is 100% on CHAI, while the human distance error (SD) on LANI is 5.2.
4.  **Method Performance:** The comparative analysis of methods on both datasets reveals that the proposed approach outperforms previous methods, such as MISRA17 and CHAPLOT18. The proposed approach achieves a lower SD and higher TC on LANI and a lower SD and higher MA on CHAI.
5.  **Linguistic Complexity:** The linguistic complexity of the instructions differs between the two datasets. LANI instructions are more likely to include spatial relations, conjunctions, temporal coordination, trajectory constraints, co-reference, and comparatives, while CHAI instructions are more likely to include manipulations and object interactions.
6.  **State Space:** The state space of the two environments differs significantly. LANI has a larger state space than existing navigation environments, while CHAI has a larger and more complex state space than similar environments.

**Performance Comparison:**
The proposed approach outperforms previous methods on both datasets, achieving a lower SD and higher TC on LANI and a lower SD and higher MA on CHAI. The approach demonstrates improved performance compared to other methods, indicating its potential for effective navigation instruction execution.

**Human Evaluation:**
Human evaluation of the approach on the LANI dataset reveals a mean rating of 4.38, while the approach's rating is 3.78. The approach also outperforms CHAPLOT18 on LANI, achieving a 5% improvement in task completion accuracy.

**Improvements and Future Work:**
The comparative analysis highlights the complexity of the tasks and the need for further improvements. Future work should focus on developing more accurate and robust methods for navigation instruction execution, particularly for the CHAI dataset. Additionally, exploring alternative evaluation metrics and incorporating human feedback into the evaluation process can help improve the approach's performance.

The proposed approach outperforms previous methods, achieving improved performance on both datasets. The multitask approach used by SciIE, which shares span representations and leverages cross-sentence information, effectively improves performance across all tasks. This approach outperforms previous state-of-the-art systems that relied on hand-engineered features or pipeline processing.

The inclusion of coreference links significantly enhances the performance of SciIE. A comparison of the precision versus pseudo-recall curves shows that the model with coreference links achieves a better AUC of 0.751 compared to the one without coreference links, which has an AUC of 0.695.

Training data significantly impacts performance across different datasets. A larger training corpus improves performance on most GLUE tasks, with gains observed across various tasks such as CoLA, SST-2, MRPC, STS-B, QQP, MNLI-matched, QNLI, and RTE. However, the impact of training data varies across datasets. For instance, Common Crawl and English Wikipedia perform exceptionally well, while News Crawl, which primarily consists of individual sentences, shows less improvement. Notably, tasks that involve multi-sentence examples, such as sentence pairs, benefit more from increased training data. This is highlighted by the 14-point accuracy gap between News Crawl and Common Crawl for the RTE task with 4.5B tokens. As seen in Figure 3, extensive training data can lead to substantial improvements in accuracy, with gains being observed up to 18B tokens. This suggests that additional data will likely continue to enhance performance.

Q4: Effect of Word Embedding Alignment
The alignment of word embeddings has a nuanced impact on BLEU scores in different language translation tasks. While it can lead to improved performance, especially in cases where the source and target languages are more linguistically similar, the effect may be limited or even negative in other cases. A more detailed analysis of the specific language pairs and training data sizes is necessary to fully understand the relationship between word embeddings alignment and BLEU scores.

Pre-training can significantly improve translation accuracy, especially for low-resource languages, by aligning the word embeddings of the source languages in a similar vector space. This is demonstrated by the results shown in Figure 2, which displays the f-measure of target words bucketed by frequency in the training corpus. As displayed in Figure 2, pre-training improves the accuracy of translation for the entire vocabulary, but particularly for words that are of low frequency in the training corpus. 
![Table presents data related to translation datasets from various source languages to Portuguese (PT), categorized by language family. It contains the following columns: Dataset, Lang. Family, std, and pre. For example, ES → PT shows an improvement of +7.0](image1)
According to Table 5, when applying pre-trained embeddings, the gains in each translation pair are roughly in order of their similarity, with GL/Pt showing the largest gains, and BE/RU showing a small decrease. In addition, it is interesting to note that aligning the word embeddings helps to increase the BLEU scores for all three tasks. These increases are intuitive, as a single encoder is used for both of the source languages, and the encoder would have to learn a significantly more complex transform of the input if the word embeddings for the languages were in a semantically separate space. 
![Table shows four rows with text related to a translation or transcription task, including the source, reference, bi:std, and multi:pre-align segments](image2)
The main intuitive hypothesis as to why pre-training works is that the embedding space becomes more consistent, with semantically similar words closer together. We can also make an additional hypothesis: if the two languages in the translation pair are more linguistically similar, the semantic neighborhoods will be more similar between the two languages. 
![The table presents evaluation metrics for different training and evaluation setups involving language pairs, including columns for Train, Eval, bi, std, pre, and align](image3)
According to the results, pre-training is most effective when the training set size is not too small but not too large, usually with a baseline BLEU score in the range of 3-4. This suggests that at least a moderately effective system is necessary before pre-training takes effect, but once there is enough data to capture the basic characteristics of the language, pre-training can be highly effective. 
![The image consists of two line graphs illustrating the relationship between training set size and BLEU scores for translation tasks from Portuguese (Pt), Turkish (Tr), and Russian (Ru) to English (En)](image5)

In conclusion, pre-training can improve translation accuracy by aligning the word embeddings of the source languages and increasing the BLEU scores for all three tasks. The effectiveness of pre-training depends on the training set size and language similarity, with the largest gains achieved when the training set size is not too small but not too large, and the language similarity is high.

In the context of NMT, pre-trained embeddings are useful since the NMT system can already learn a reasonable projection of word embeddings during its normal training process [1]. However, using independent word embeddings for source and target languages may not lead to direct correspondences between the embedding spaces in both languages. To test this hypothesis, we used the approach proposed by Smith et al. (2017) to learn orthogonal transformations that convert word embeddings of multiple languages to a single space and used these aligned embeddings instead of independent ones [3]. Our results show that pre-training and alignment significantly improve the translation performance, particularly for low-resource languages [4]. This improvement is observed across different language pairs, with the most significant gains seen for languages with similar translation pairs [5]. For example, in the GL → EN pair, pre-trained source language embeddings resulted in a significant increase in F-measure scores, with the aligned embeddings outperforming the unaligned ones [6]. We also observed that the effectiveness of pre-trained embeddings increases with the similarity of the source and target languages [7]. Furthermore, the use of aligned word embeddings is beneficial even in bilingual systems, where the goal is to improve translation performance for low-resource languages [8]. Overall, our findings suggest that aligning word embeddings across languages can significantly improve translation performance, particularly in low-resource scenarios, and that pre-trained embeddings can be a valuable tool in this process.

Our contributions can be summarized as follows:**

### DyGIE's Performance on Entity and Relation Extraction Tasks Across Different Datasets

The DyGIE system is presented in various datasets, showcasing its effectiveness in both entity and relation extraction tasks. The system outperforms existing state-of-the-art methods in many cases, indicating its potential for real-world applications.

#### Entity Extraction Performance

- **ACE04 Dataset**: DyGIE achieves an entity score of 87.4, surpassing Miwa and Bansal (2016) and Bekoulis et al. (2018).
- **ACE05 Dataset**: DyGIE outperforms Zhang et al. (2017) and Sanh et al. (2019) in entity extraction, with an entity score of 88.4.
- **SciERC Dataset**: DyGIE yields the best entity score of 65.2, besting Luan et al. (2018a).
- **WLPC Dataset**: DyGIE shows the highest entity score of 79.5, surpassing Kulkarni et al. (2018).

#### Relation Extraction Performance

- **ACE04 Dataset**: DyGIE edges out Bekoulis et al. (2018) with a relation score of 59.7.
- **ACE05 Dataset**: DyGIE outperforms Zhang et al. (2017) and Sanh et al. (2019) in relation extraction, achieving a relation score of 63.2.
- **SciERC Dataset**: DyGIE yields the best relation score of 41.6, surpassing Luan et al. (2018a).
- **WLPC Dataset**: DyGIE shows the highest relation score of 64.1, outperforming Kulkarni et al. (2018).

### Effects of Coreference and Relation Propagation Layers

The DyGIE system demonstrates significant improvements in both entity and relation extraction tasks across the datasets when utilizing coreference and relation propagation layers. These layers allow the model to better understand the relationships between entities and their corresponding relations, leading to improved performance.

#### Coreference Propagation

- The DyGIE system achieves its best entity extraction scores when utilizing coreference propagation.
- The impact of coreference propagation on entity extraction is notable, particularly in the ACE05 dataset.

#### Relation Propagation

- The DyGIE system outperforms existing methods in relation extraction tasks when utilizing relation propagation.
- Relation propagation significantly improves the model's ability to identify relations between entities.

### Conclusion

The DyGIE system showcases its effectiveness in entity and relation extraction tasks across various datasets. The incorporation of coreference and relation propagation layers further enhances the model's performance, indicating the potential for real-world applications in information extraction.

**D Y GIE Framework Outperforms State-of-the-Art Methods Across Diverse Domains**
D Y GIE uses multi-task learning to identify entities, relations, and coreferences through shared span representations using dynamically constructed span graphs. The nodes in the graph are dynamically selected from a beam of highly-conﬁdent mentions, and the edges are weighted according to the conﬁdence scores of relation types or coref- erences. Unlike the multi-task method that only shares span representations from the local context (Luan et al.,  2018a), our framework leverages rich contextual span representations by propagat- ing information through coreference and relation links. Unlike previous BIO-based entity recogni- tion systems (Collobert and Weston,  2008; Lample et al.,  2016; Ma and Hovy,  2016) that assign a text span to at most one entity, our framework enumer- ates and represents all possible spans to recognize arbitrarily overlapping entities.![D Y GIE Framework Architecture](image1)

**Comparative Analysis Across Datasets**
We evaluate the performance of D Y GIE on overlapping entity extraction in three datasets: ACE2004, ACE2005 and GENIA. Since relation annotations are not available for these datasets, we include the coreference propagation layer in our models but not the relation layer. On SciERC, D Y GIE advances the state of the art by $5.9\%$ and $1.9\%$ for relation extraction and NER, respectively. The improvement of D Y GIE over the previous SciERC model underscores the ability of coreference and relation propagation to construct rich contextualized representations.![D Y GIE Outperforms Previous Models on SciERC](image2)

**Impact of Coreference and Relation Propagation**
For the ACE04-O dataset, we observe that coreference propagation is mainly helpful for entities; it appears to hurt relation extraction. On SciIE, coreference propagation gives a small ben- eﬁt on both tasks. Relation propagation signiﬁ- cantly beneﬁts both entity and relation extraction in both domains. In particular, there are a large por- tion of sentences with multiple relation instances across different entities in both ACE05 and Sci- ERC, which is the scenario in which we expect relation propagation to help.![Coreference and Relation Propagation Impact](image3)

**Entity and Relation Extraction Performance**
On SciERC, D Y GIE achieves the highest Entity F1 score across all datasets. The DyGIE system achieves the highest Entity F1 score across all datasets, while the DyGIE system achieves the highest Relation F1 score across all datasets.![Entity and Relation Extraction Performance](image4)

**Conclusion**
In conclusion, the DyGIE system achieves state-of-the-art results on entity recognition and relation extraction tasks across a diverse range of domains. The key contribution of our model is the dynamic span graph approach, which enables the model to learn useful information from broader context. We welcome the community to test our model on different information extraction tasks. Future directions include extending the framework to encompass more structural IE tasks such as event extraction.![D Y GIE System Performance](image5)

Entity Extraction with DyGIE: A Comparative Analysis
======================================================

DyGIE, a dynamic span graph approach, has been shown to achieve state-of-the-art results on entity recognition and relation extraction tasks across diverse domains. To understand the variations in performance and the roles of CorefProp and RelProp, we analyze the results on three datasets: ACE04-O, ACE05-O, and GENIA.

### Performance on ACE04-O, ACE05-O, and GENIA

Fine-tuning strategies like GEM and EWC play a crucial role in adapting the model to new domain data. To better understand their comparison and the impact of slot similarities, let's delve into the quotes and image descriptions.

GEM, which stands for Gradient Episodic Memory, utilizes a small number of samples from the source domains to keep track of learned parameters while fine-tuning on the new target domain. This method prevents the loss on stored samples from increasing by applying a constraint on the gradient, thereby minimizing catastrophic forgetting (cite [8]). In the context of fine-tuning on a new domain, GEM outperforms naive and EWC fine-tuning in terms of overcoming catastrophic forgetting (cite [6]).

On the other hand, EWC (Elastic Weight Consolidation) uses the diagonal of the Fisher information matrix $F$ as a regularizer for adapting to the target domain data. This matrix is approximated using samples from the source domain. EWC helps in forgetting the old knowledge in favor of the new one, which is beneficial when adapting to new data but can lead to catastrophic forgetting if not handled properly (cite [3]).

While fine-tuning from the base model often achieves better results on the new domain compared to training from scratch (cite [9]), the performance difference between GEM and EWC can vary depending on the specific scenario and data availability.

The effectiveness of fine-tuning strategies can also be influenced by the similarity between slots in the new domain and those seen during training. A heatmap visualizing the cosine similarity between embeddings for different slots in the MultiWOZ dataset (cite [5]) reveals that slots with similar embeddings have higher similarities, suggesting that these pairs typically have related or shared attributes. This observation highlights the importance of considering slot similarities when adapting the model to new domain data.

In the context of domain expansion, pre-training followed by fine-tuning on the new domain often outperforms training from scratch on the single domain (cite [6]). This is particularly evident in the zero-shot analysis of two selected domains, hotel and restaurant, which contain more slots to be tracked (cite [7]).

To summarize, GEM and EWC fine-tuning strategies differ in their approach to adapting the model to new domain data. While GEM focuses on minimizing catastrophic forgetting by keeping track of learned parameters, EWC regularizes the model's parameters using the Fisher information matrix. The effectiveness of these strategies depends on various factors, including the availability of data and the similarity between slots in the new domain and those seen during training.

Here is an image that represents how GEM and EWC can be interleaved with the description: 
![Heatmap Visualizing Slot Similarities](image5) 

The heatmap shows the cosine similarity between embeddings for different slots in the MultiWOZ dataset, highlighting the similarities between slots like "destination" and "departure" or "price range" and "stars." This visual representation can help in understanding the importance of considering slot similarities when adapting the model to new domain data.

**Answer:** Fine-tuning strategies like GEM and EWC compare in adapting the model to new domain data by using different approaches to handle catastrophic forgetting. GEM keeps track of learned parameters to prevent forgetting, while EWC regularizes the model's parameters using the Fisher information matrix. The effectiveness of these strategies depends on factors like data availability and slot similarities.

**The Impact of Machine Translation Systems on Gender Bias Across Languages**
====================================================================

### Introduction

Research has shown that machine translation systems often exhibit biases towards stereotypical gender roles, which can be detrimental in various contexts, such as gender equality and social justice.

### The Problem

As demonstrated by [1], the discrepancy in performance between stereotypical and non-stereotypical gender role assignments is a significant concern. For instance, Google Translate's performance on stereotypical translations is consistently higher across all tested languages compared to non-stereotypical translations, as shown in Figure 2 of [1].

### The Solution

Our approach uses a concatenation of Winogender and WinoBias to evaluate gender bias in machine translation. We devise an automatic translation evaluation method for eight diverse target languages, without requiring additional gold translations, relying instead on automatic measures for alignment and morphological analysis (Section 2). Our analyses show that four widely used commercial MT systems and two recent state-of-the-art academic models are significantly gender-biased on all tested languages (Section 3).

![The chart comparing stereotypical and non-stereotypical translations for Google Translate](image3)

### Results

The results of our study highlight the importance of addressing gender bias in machine translation systems. As shown in Figure 2 of [1], the accuracy for stereotypical translations is consistently higher across all tested languages compared to non-stereotypical translations.

### Conclusion

Our study demonstrates the need for more accurate and inclusive machine translation systems that can handle diverse languages and contexts. We hope that our approach and findings will inspire further research and development in this area.

![Table 2: Performance of commercial MT systems on the WinoMT corpus](image4)

### Future Work

Our method and benchmarks are publicly available, and are easily extensible with more languages and MT models. We encourage researchers and developers to contribute to this effort and improve the accuracy and inclusivity of machine translation systems.

In machine translation, gender bias can lead to inaccurate gender assignments, as demonstrated by the bar chart in image1, showing higher accuracy for stereotypical gender translations across all tested languages. However, adding stereotypically female adjectives, such as "pretty" in image8, can reduce bias in some languages, with significant improvements observed in Spanish, Russian, and Ukrainian.

To address this issue, researchers employed a gender bias evaluation method that assesses the accuracy of machine translation systems in preserving the gender of entities from the original sentence. As stated in [quote 1], most systems perform poorly on this metric, with the exception of German, where three out of four systems achieve their best performance. This suggests that language similarity to English may contribute to better performance in this regard.

Moreover, an analysis of Figure 2 in [quote 2] shows that systems exhibit significantly better performance when presented with pro-stereotypical assignments, such as female nurses, whereas their performance deteriorates when translating anti-stereotypical roles, like male receptionists.

A more nuanced approach to mitigating gender bias involves understanding the relationship between coreference resolution and machine translation. By using pre-modified sentences with stereotypical gender adjectives, as shown in [quote 8], researchers found that this can improve performance in some languages, reducing bias.

The findings of this study are illustrated in Table 4, which compares the performance of Google Translate on Spanish, Russian, and Ukrainian gender prediction accuracy. The results indicate that adding stereotypical gender adjectives can significantly reduce bias in some languages.

In conclusion, stereotype-based adjustments in machine translation can mitigate gender bias accuracy across different languages, as demonstrated by the effectiveness of adding stereotypically female adjectives in some languages. This approach highlights the importance of considering the nuances of language and context in machine translation systems to reduce gender bias and promote more accurate gender assignments.

For example, **the model achieves near-chance accuracy on comparison questions** ([8]) highlights that comparison questions may not be solvable by single-hop models. This suggests that more complex models or approaches may be needed to handle these types of questions effectively.

Overall, the results suggest that different training and evaluation strategies can have a significant impact on F1 scores in multi-hop and single-hop question answering tasks. Future work can focus on developing more effective training and evaluation methods to improve the performance of these models.
