**Table 4** shows the accuracy of BERT on $200\,\mathrm{ex}\cdot$ -amples from the dev set of the MRPC paraphrase detection task under various attack and defense settings. We re-trained the ScRNN model variants on the MRPC training set for these experiments. Again, we find that simple 1 - 2 character attacks can bring down the accuracy of BERT significantly $(89\%$ to $31\%$ ). Word recognition models can provide an effective defense, with both our pass-through and neutral variants recovering most of the accuracy. While the neutral backoff model is effective on 2-char attacks, it hurts performance in the no attack setting, since it incorrectly modifies certain correctly spelled entity names. Since the two variants are already effective, we did not train a background model for this task.

![A table showing the performance of different models under various attack and defense settings. The table has columns for the model variant, attack type, and accuracy. The rows show the performance of the models under different attack and defense settings.](image1)

**To combat adversarial spelling mistakes, we propose placing a word recognition model in front of the downstream classifier. Our word recognition models build upon the RNN semi-character architecture, introducing several new backoff strategies for handling rare and unseen words. Trained to recognize words corrupted by random adds, drops, swaps, and keyboard mistakes, our method achieves $32\%$ relative (and $3.3\%$ absolute) error reduction over the vanilla semi-character model. Noteably, our pipeline confers robustness on the downstream classifier, outperforming both adversarial training and off-the-shelf spell check-ers. Against a BERT model fine-tuned for sentiment analysis, a single adversarially-chosen character attack lowers accuracy from $90.3\%$ to $45.8\%$. Our defense restores accuracy to $75\%^{1}$. Surprisingly, better word recognition does not always entail greater robustness. Our analysis reveals that robustness also depends upon a quantity that we denote the sensitivity.**

![An image showing a pipeline with a word recognition model in front of the downstream classifier. The image also shows the improvement in accuracy after the defense is applied.](image2)

**Backoff Variations While Sakaguchi et al. (2017) demonstrate strong word recognition performance, a drawback of their evaluation setup is that they only attack and evaluate on the subset of words that are a part of their training vocabulary. In such a setting, the word recognition performance is unreasonably dependent on the chosen vocabulary size. For the adversarial setting, rare and unseen words in the wild are particularly critical, as they provide opportunities for the attackers. A reliable word-recognizer should handle these cases gracefully. Below, we explore different ways to back off when the ScRNN predicts UNK (a frequent outcome for rare and unseen words):**

**Results The neutral backoff variant has the lowest sensitivity (Table 5). This is expected, as it returns a fixed neutral word whenever the ScRNN predicts an UNK, therefore reducing the number of unique outputs it predicts. Open vocabulary (i.e. char-only, word+char, word-piece) downstream classifiers consider every unique combination of characters differently, whereas word-only classifiers internally treat all out of vocabulary (OOV) words alike. Hence, for char-only,**

![A table showing the performance of different backoff variants under various attack and defense settings. The table has columns for the attack type, sensitivity, and word error rate. The rows show the performance of the backoff variants under different attack and defense settings.](image3)

**Fourth, we offer a detailed qualitative analysis, demonstrating that a low word error rate alone is insufﬁcient for a word recognizer to confer robustness on the downstream task. Additionally, we ﬁnd that it is important that the recognition model supply few degrees of freedom to an attacker. We provide a metric to quantify this notion of sensitivity in word recognition models and study its relation to robustness empirically. Models with low sensitivity and word error rate are most robust.**

![A scatter plot showing the relationship between sensitivity and word error rate for different models. The plot has two sub-plots, one for closed vocabulary models and one for open vocabulary models.](image4)

**Ideally, a preferred defense is one with low sensitivity and word error rate. In practice, however, we see that a low error rate often comes at the cost of sensitivity. We visualize this trade-off in Figure 2, where we plot WER and sensitivity on the two axes, and depict the robustness when using different backoff variants. Generally, sensitivity is the more dominant factor out of the two, as the error rates of the considered variants are reasonably low.**

![A table showing the effectiveness of different spell-correction methods across various types of spelling errors. The table has columns for the spell-corrector and the type of spelling error. The rows show the performance of the spell-correctors under different types of spelling errors.](image5)

The "BERT + Pass-through" and "BERT + Neutral" models maintain relatively higher performance under the 1-char and 2-char attacks compared to standard BERT. "BERT + Neutral" has the highest performance under 2-char attack, indicated by the bold value of 82.5.**

**Comparing Evaluation Metrics for Machine Translation Across Language Pairs**
====================================================================

**Understanding the Importance of Asymmetry in Evaluation Metrics**
----------------------------------------------------------------

Note that the penalization of ties makes our evaluation asymmetric, dependent on whether the metric predicted the tie for a pair where humans predicted <$$>$\text{ or }\$. It is now important to interpret the meaning of the comparison identically for humans and metrics. For error metrics, we thus reverse the sign of the metric score prior to the comparison with human scores: higher scores have to indicate better translation quality. In WMT19, the original authors did this for CharacTER.

**System-Level Evaluation Metrics Achieve High Correlations**
---------------------------------------------------------

In system-level evaluation, the series of YiSi metrics achieve the highest correlations in several language pairs and is not significantly outperformed by any other metrics (denoted as a “win” in the following) for almost all language pairs.

**Metrics and QE Systems: A Focus on Semantic Features**
---------------------------------------------------------

Metrics and QE systems such as BERTr, ESIM, YiSi that perform well at judging our best systems often use more semantic features compared to our n-gram/char-gram based baselines. Future metrics may want to explore a) whether semantic features such as contextual word embeddings are achieving semantic understanding and b) whether semantic understanding is the true source of a metric’s performance gains.

Assumptions for the expected long-term rate of return on plan assets are based on future expectations for returns for each asset class and the effect of periodic target asset allocation rebalancing. According to \[5\], U.S. employees whose base salary and management responsibility exceed a certain level can defer receipt of a portion of their cash compensation, with payments made based on the participant's distribution election and plan balance. Participants can earn a return on their deferred compensation based on notional investments in the same investment funds that are offered in our defined contribution plans.

In 2020, U.S. Defined Benefit and Non-U.S. Defined Benefit plans had different allocation ranges for fixed income securities and equity securities, with the actual allocations differing from the target ranges. For U.S. Defined Benefit plans, the target allocation ranges were between 65% to 80% for fixed income securities and cash equivalents and 20% to 35% for equity securities, while actual allocations were 70% for fixed income securities and 30% for equity securities. 

On the other hand, for Non-U.S. Defined Benefit plans, the target allocation ranges were between 60% to 100% for fixed income securities and cash equivalents and 0% to 40% for equity securities, with actual allocations of 76% for fixed income securities and 24% for equity securities. These variations suggest that while both types of plans aim to balance risk and return, their specific allocation strategies differ based on their respective investment mixes and long-term objectives.

### Operating Lease Liabilities: A Comparison from 2019 to 2020

The table from image2 presents key information regarding the company's operating lease liabilities for the years 2019 and 2020. To analyze the changes in operating lease liabilities from 2019 to 2020, we need to consider the total operating lease liabilities, the composition of current and long-term liabilities, and the factors that might have influenced these changes.

#### Total Operating Lease Liabilities

- **2019:** $797 million
- **2020:** $974 million

### Increase in Total Operating Lease Liabilities

The total operating lease liabilities increased from $797 million in 2019 to $974 million in 2020, showing an increase of $177 million or 22.2%. This indicates a notable growth in the company's operating lease obligations during the period under review.

#### Current vs. Long-term Operating Lease Liabilities

- **Current:** $158 million in 2019, $189 million in 2020
- **Long-term:** $639 million in 2019, $785 million in 2020

### Composition of Operating Lease Liabilities

The composition of operating lease liabilities remained relatively stable, with slight increases in both current and long-term liabilities. The increase in long-term liabilities indicates that the company's operating lease obligations have matured or are nearing maturity, reflecting the natural progression of lease terms.

#### Factors Influencing the Changes

Several factors might have influenced the changes in the company's operating lease liabilities from 2019 to 2020:

1.  **Increased Usage or Operations**: An expansion of the company's operations or increased usage of leased assets could have led to an increase in operating lease liabilities.
2.  **Maturity of Lease Terms**: The company's lease terms may have matured or are nearing maturity, leading to an increase in long-term liabilities.
3.  **Inflation and Economic Conditions**: Changes in inflation rates or economic conditions could affect the company's cash flows and ability to service its operating lease liabilities, potentially leading to an increase in liabilities.
4.  **Industry and Market Conditions**: The company's industry or market may be experiencing significant changes, which could impact its ability to service operating lease liabilities, contributing to an increase in liabilities.

While the exact factors influencing the changes in operating lease liabilities from 2019 to 2020 are not specified, these possible factors highlight the complexities involved in managing operating lease obligations and the need for careful financial planning and analysis.

**ExxonMobil’s Capital Expenditures and Taxes Evolution and Implications**
====================================================================

According to the provided quotes, ExxonMobil's capital expenditures and taxes underwent significant changes between 2019 and 2020. Here are the key findings:

### Capital Expenditures

[3] indicates that ExxonMobil prioritized opportunities to hold 2021 capital spending in a range of $\S16$ billion to $\S19$ billion, with actual spending potentially varying depending on individual projects and property acquisitions. In contrast, Capex in 2020 was $\S21.4$ billion.

This decrease in capital expenditures can be attributed to the lower global project spending reflected in the Downstream sector, as mentioned in [6].

### Taxes

[9] and [10] provide financial data on ExxonMobil's income taxes for 2019 and 2020, respectively. Total taxes on the Corporation's income statement decreased from $\S38.5$ billion in 2019 to $\S22.8$ billion in 2020.

The effective tax rate decreased from 34% in 2019 to 17% in 2020, primarily due to a change in the mix of results in jurisdictions with varying tax rates. Notably, [10] mentions that the relative benefit is driven by asset impairments recorded in 2020.

### Financial Implications

The decrease in capital expenditures and taxes had significant financial implications for ExxonMobil. The reduced capital expenditures may lead to a decrease in the Corporation's ability to invest in new projects and expand its operations.

Conversely, the decrease in taxes can provide ExxonMobil with more liquidity, as the Corporation ended the year with $\S68$ billion in gross debt and intends to reduce debt over time. However, the reduced tax revenue may impact the Corporation's ability to invest in new projects and expand its operations.

```markdown
### Capital Expenditures and Taxes Evolution
```

**Berkshire Hathaway’s Stock Repurchase Program and Net Earnings Comparison**
====================================================================

According to the provided text quotes, the Berkshire Hathaway’s stock repurchase program and its net earnings across different segments have shown varying performance over the years 2019 to 2021.

### Stock Repurchase Program

The program, as outlined in [3] and [4], permits Berkshire to repurchase its Class A and Class B shares at prices below the intrinsic value, conservatively determined by Warren Buffett and Charlie Munger. The program does not specify a maximum number of shares to be repurchased or a specified repurchase amount, and it is expected to continue indefinitely.

In 2021, Berkshire paid $27.1 billion to repurchase shares of its Class A and B common stock, with the majority of the purchases made under a public program. The program is designed to return value to shareholders and maintain financial strength.

### Net Earnings by Segment

The table in [5] shows the net earnings attributable to Berkshire Hathaway shareholders from various segments over the years 2019, 2020, and 2021:

| Segment | 2019 | 2020 | 2021 |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |

| Insurance – Investment Income | $5,530M | $5,039M | $4,807M |

| Manufacturing, Service, and Retailing | $9,372M | $8,300M | $11,120M |
| Investment and Derivative Gains/Losses | $57,445M | $31,591M | $62,340M |
| Other | $424M | $(11,318)M | $1,315M |

### Comparison

The stock repurchase program and net earnings across different segments have shown varying performance over the years 2019 to 2021. The insurance underwriting segment has consistently shown strong earnings growth, with increases of 122% and 110% in 2021 and 2020, respectively. The manufacturing, service, and retailing segment has also shown significant growth, with increases of 119% and 15% in 2021 and 2020, respectively.

In contrast, the insurance investment income segment has shown a decline of 13% in 2021 compared to 2020, due to declines in interest rates on Berkshire's substantial holdings of cash and U.S. Treasury Bills.

The overall net earnings of Berkshire Hathaway have shown a mixed performance, with increases of 9% and 9% in 2021 and 2020, respectively. However, the company's financial strength and liquidity have remained strong, with cash, cash equivalents, and U.S. Treasury Bill holdings totaling $30 billion or more.

### Conclusion

The Berkshire Hathaway’s stock repurchase program and its net earnings across different segments have shown varying performance over the years 2019 to 2021. While the insurance underwriting and manufacturing, service, and retailing segments have shown strong earnings growth, the insurance investment income segment has declined due to interest rate declines. The company's overall financial strength and liquidity have remained strong, providing a solid foundation for future growth.

We can also calculate the increase in ROE using the [1] table to see how the equity changed, from $8.14 billion to $11.3 billion. We can calculate the return on stockholders' equity as follows:

$$\text{ROE} = \frac{\text{Net Income}}{\text{Stockholders' Equity}}$$

This results in ROE increasing from $1.00 in 2020 to $1.10 in 2021, as follows:
$$\text{ROE in 2020} = \frac{(-1.6\text{B})}{(8.14\text{B})} = 0.196$$
$$\text{ROE in 2021} = \frac{(7.3\text{B})}{(11.3\text{B})} = 0.643$$

The changes in ROE indicate a rise from $1.96% in 2020 to $6.43% in 2021, showing a significant improvement.

To determine the total long-term capital and finance lease obligations for December 31, 2017, let's break down the components and calculations as presented in the financial statements.

### Long-term Capital Lease Obligations
The table showing long-term capital lease obligations as of December 31, 2017, is provided in image3. The calculation directly from this table for the total long-term capital lease obligations is straightforward:

\[ \text{Total Long-term Capital Lease Obligations} = \text{Gross Capital Lease Obligations} - \text{Less Current Portion of Capital Lease Obligations} \]
\[ \text{Total Long-term Capital Lease Obligations} = \$14,811 - \$5,839 = \$8,438 \]

### Long-term Finance Lease Obligations
Similarly, from image4, we have the components to calculate the total long-term finance lease obligations:

\[ \text{Total Long-term Finance Lease Obligations} = \text{Gross Finance Lease Obligations} - \text{Less Current Portion of Finance Lease Obligations} \]
\[ \text{Total Long-term Finance Lease Obligations} = \$6,265 - \$282 = \$4,745 \]

### Interest and Present Value Considerations
The calculations also mention present value and imputed interest, which affect the total obligations but are already considered within the gross and current portion calculations. The subtraction of these values ensures the total obligation reflects the net minimum lease payments required over the lease term, not the present value of all future payments.

### Conclusion
The total long-term capital lease obligations for December 31, 2017, were $8,438 million, while the total long-term finance lease obligations were $4,745 million.

```markdown
### Long-term Lease Obligations as of December 31, 2017

- **Long-term Capital Lease Obligations:** $\$8,438$
- **Long-term Finance Lease Obligations:** $\$4,745$
```

There is usually a tax impact on other items, although this is not always the case for items arising from legal  settlements in certain jurisdictions. Adjustments related to income from associated companies are recorded net of any related tax effect. **Comparison of Changes in Total Liabilities and Shareholders' Equity**
====================================================================

The comparison of changes in total liabilities and shareholders' equity from 2020 to 2021 reveals a significant increase in total liabilities, while shareholders' equity also saw a notable increase. This analysis will discuss the implications of these changes on net earnings and comprehensive income.

### Total Liabilities
-------------------

A comparison of total liabilities in 2020 and 2021 shows an increase from $422,393 to $443,854, representing a rise of $21,461. The main contributors to this increase are:

*   Unpaid losses and loss adjustment expenses: from $79,854 to $86,664, an increase of $6,810
*   Notes payable and other borrowings: from $41,522 to $39,272 (decrease of $2,250), despite this being a decrease, its effect was insignificant when summed up with the total increase.
*   Unearned premiums: from $21,395 to $23,512, an increase of $2,117
*   Accounts payable, accruals, and other liabilities: from $30,344 to $30,376, an increase of $32
*   Aircraft repurchase liabilities and unearned lease revenues: from $5,856 to $5,849, a decrease of $7

### Shareholders' Equity
------------------------

Shareholders' equity increased from $506.2 billion in 2020 to $506.2 billion in 2021. The main contributor to this increase is the net earnings of $89.8 billion.

### Net Earnings and Comprehensive Income
-----------------------------------------

A comparison of net earnings and comprehensive income from 2020 to 2021 shows an increase in both. Net earnings rose from $43,253 to $90,807, representing a rise of $47,554. Comprehensive income increased from $44,272 to $91,041, representing a rise of $46,769.

### Relating Changes to Net Earnings and Comprehensive Income
---------------------------------------------------------

The increase in total liabilities is largely due to the rise in unpaid losses and loss adjustment expenses, notes payable, and unearned premiums. In contrast, the increase in shareholders' equity is primarily due to the net earnings.

The increase in comprehensive income can be attributed to the rise in net earnings, which resulted in a higher comprehensive income attributable to Berkshire Hathaway shareholders. The comprehensive income is the sum of net earnings and other comprehensive income.

**Toyota's Approach to Climate Scenarios and Shareholder Returns**
Toyota aims to maintain a robust financial foundation to support sustainable growth by maintaining stability while pursuing growth and efficiency over the medium and long terms.

Through its use of cost reduction and thorough application of the Toyota Production System (TPS), Toyota reinforces its profit structure and secures funds to invest in advanced and cutting-edge technologies, such as electrified vehicles.

![Toyota’s Financial Strategy is supported by maintaining stability while pursuing growth and efficiency over the medium and long terms](image7)

To achieve this, Toyota focuses on energy conservation and promoting efficient technology, aiming to reduce energy costs and increase the efficiency of its operations.

![Toyota’s focus on energy conservation and promoting efficient technology to reduce energy costs and increase efficiency](image8)

In terms of shareholder returns, Toyota has a payout ratio of around 30% and has maintained a stable dividend payment per share over the years, with a total return ratio of around 40%.

![Toyota’s dividend payment per share and total return ratio](image5)

Additionally, Toyota has invested in share repurchases, with a total spend of around $2.5 billion in 2021.

![Toyota’s share repurchases in 2021](image5)

In response to climate scenarios, Toyota has organized the risks relating to climate change and identified particularly significant risks in line with risk management processes based on the degree of impact and stakeholders' interest.

![Toyota’s approach to climate change risks and identification of significant risks](image9)

Toyota has also endorsed and signed on to the recommendations of the Financial Stability Board's Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures (TCFD) in April 2019 and appropriately discloses information concerning risks and opportunities related to climate change and their analyses.

![Toyota’s compliance with TCFD recommendations](image9)

Furthermore, Toyota has used scenarios such as those of the $|\mathsf{E}\mathsf{A}^{\star}$ to examine future images of society based on the current policy scenario, below $^{2^{\circ}\mathrm{C}}$ scenario, and $1.5^{\circ}\mathrm{C}$ scenario at around 2030 for Toyota’s external environment, in light of risk and opportunity analysis.

![Toyota’s use of scenarios to examine future images of society based on different climate scenarios](image5)

Overall, Toyota’s financial strategy is closely tied to its response to climate scenarios, with a focus on maintaining stability, pursuing growth and efficiency, and investing in advanced technologies such as electrification.

![Toyota’s overall approach to climate change and financial strategy](image4)

### Depreciation and Impairment Losses Evolution from 2019 to 2020

Depreciation and impairment losses have undergone significant changes across various asset categories from 2019 to 2020. Specifically:

-   **Intangible assets**: The carrying amount of intangible assets increased from DKK 9,607 million in 2019 to DKK 9,607 million in 2020, primarily due to the increase in costs for patents and licences. The impairment losses recognised on intangible assets not yet available for use were DKK 529 million in 2020, substantially all of which related to the Diabetes and Obesity care segment.

-   **Property, plant and equipment**: The depreciation for the year decreased from DKK 852 million in 2019 to DKK 964 million in 2020, primarily due to the increase in depreciation for the year for other equipment.

-   **Research and development costs**: The impairment losses related to software and property, plant and equipment used in the research and development activities were DKK 529 million in 2020, an increase from DKK 450 million in 2019. The depreciation costs also increased from DKK 852 million in 2019 to DKK 964 million in 2020.

These changes have had a significant impact on the net carrying amounts of intangible assets and property, plant, and equipment.

### Impact on Net Carrying Amounts

The increase in impairment losses on intangible assets not yet available for use, and the increase in depreciation costs for research and development activities, have resulted in a higher carrying amount for these asset categories.

Total revenues for McDonald's decreased by 10% from 2019 to 2020, primarily reflecting sales declines in the International Operated Markets segment as a result of COVID-19, partly offset by positive sales performance in the U.S., which was more than offset by support provided for marketing, through incentives to franchisees, to accelerate recovery and drive growth, including the free Thank You Meals served across the country to first responders and health care workers.![Change in Total Revenues 2019-2020](image5)
Total restaurant margins decreased 13% in 2020, which reflected sales declines in the International Operated Markets segment as a result of COVID-19, partly offset by positive sales performance in the U.S. The declines were driven by the International Operated Markets segment, where revenue declines were more significant due to temporary restaurant closures and limited operations, affecting the U.K., France, Germany, Italy, and Spain.![Restaurant Margins Decline 2020](image6)
The decline in total restaurant margins can be attributed to the significant decline in the International Operated Markets segment, as well as the increase in fixed expenses such as lease expense and depreciation expense, mainly in the franchised segment.![Franchised Margin Expenses](image7)

BHP's governance framework addresses climate change risks through a structured and rigorous approach to Board succession planning, ensuring a diverse pipeline, and an ongoing process of evaluating and training its directors to consider potential implications of climate change on the company's operational capacity.

### **Text Cited for Evidence:**

[3] Climate change is a material governance and strategic issue and is routinely on the Board agenda, including as part of strategy discussions, portfolio reviews and investment decisions, risk management oversight and monitoring, and performance against our commitments. The Sustainability Committee assists the Board in overseeing the Group’s climate change performance and governance responsibilities. The Risk and Audit Committee and Sustainability Committee assist the Board with the oversight of climate-related risk management, although the Board retains overall accountability for BHP’s risk profile. Below the level of the Board, key management decisions are made by the CEO and management, in accordance with their delegated authority.

[10] Board members bring experience from a range of sectors, including resources, energy, finance, technology and public policy. The Board also seeks the input of management and other independent advisers. This equips them to consider potential implications of climate change on BHP and its operational capacity, as well as understand the nature of the debate and the international policy response as it develops. In addition, there is a deep understanding of systemic risk and the potential impacts on our portfolio.

[7] The Committee considered financial statement disclosures and how the Group’s greenhouse gas emissions reduction commitments and climate change scenarios, including those aligned with the Paris Agreement goals, are reflected in the Group’s key judgements and estimates used in the preparation of the Group’s FY2021 finance statements. This included consideration of portfolio impacts, demand for the Group’s commodities and associated price outlooks, costs of decarbonisation and Scope 3 emissions considerations. Specific focus was also given to the potential impact on impairment assessments and the expected timing and cost of closure activities.

**[1]** Actuarial assumptions play a crucial role in determining the funded status of defined benefit plans. These assumptions include discount rates, expected compensation increases, and mortality rates. For instance, the discount rate is determined by reference to yields on high-quality corporate bonds of appropriate duration and currency at the end of the reporting period. 

**[2]** The **discount rate** varies across countries, with Germany using Siemens-specific tables, the United States relying on the Pri-2012 generational projection from the U.S. Social Security Administration, the United Kingdom using SAPS S2 Standard mortality tables, and Switzerland utilizing BVG 2020 G and BVG 2015 G.

**[3]** When it comes to **mortality rates**, the United States uses a different approach, whereas Germany and Switzerland use their respective mortality tables. The discount rate and mortality rates have a significant impact on the funded status of defined benefit plans.

**[4]** In terms of **Euro**, the dollar, British pound, and Swiss franc, the rates also differ, which can affect the funded status of defined benefit plans.

**[5]** In summary, the differences in actuarial assumptions and financial indicators between Germany and the United States lead to variations in the funded status of defined benefit plans.

**Impact of Adjusted Net Operating Income and Profit Before Tax Across Banking Segments in 2020**
=====================================================================================================

According to the financial results presented in the management view of adjusted revenue for the years 2020, 2019, and 2018, the banking segments experienced varying impacts on adjusted net operating income and profit before tax.

### Global Markets
----------------

The Global Markets segment showed a significant increase in total revenue, rising by $1,562 million (27%) from 2019. This growth was largely driven by an increase in foreign exchange revenue, rates revenue, and credit revenue. The segment's adjusted net operating income also saw a substantial increase, driven by the growth in revenue.

### FICC (Fixed Income, Currencies, and Commodities)
------------------------------------------------

The FICC segment reported a notable increase in revenue, rising by $1,541 million (33%) from 2019. Foreign exchange revenue increased by $702 million (26%), while rates revenue grew by $283 million (20%). The segment's adjusted net operating income also increased, driven by the growth in revenue.

### Equities
------------

The Equities segment reported a modest increase in revenue, rising by $21 million (2%) from 2019. This growth was largely driven by an increase in equities revenue.

### Securities Services
---------------------

The Securities Services segment reported a decline in revenue, decreasing by $234 million (12%) from 2019. This decline was largely driven by a decrease in securities services revenue.

### Global Banking
-----------------

The Global Banking segment reported a decrease in revenue, falling by $71 million (2%) from 2019. This decline was largely driven by a decrease in global banking revenue.

### Global Liquidity and Cash Management
---------------------------------------

The Global Liquidity and Cash Management segment reported a significant decline in revenue, falling by $701 million (26%) from 2019. This decline was largely driven by a decrease in global liquidity and cash management revenue.

### Global Trade and Receivables Finance
-----------------------------------------

The Global Trade and Receivables Finance segment reported a decline in revenue, decreasing by $33 million (4%) from 2019. This decline was largely driven by a decrease in global trade and receivables finance revenue.

### Principal Investments
------------------------

The Principal Investments segment reported a decline in revenue, falling by $147 million (56%) from 2019. This decline was largely driven by a decrease in principal investments revenue.

### Credit and Funding Valuation Adjustments
-------------------------------------------

The Credit and Funding Valuation Adjustments segment reported a significant increase in losses, decreasing by $293 million (over 200%) from 2019. This decline was largely driven by a decrease in credit and funding valuation adjustments revenue.

### Other
------------

The Other segment reported a decline in revenue, decreasing by $67 million (10%) from 2019. This decline was largely driven by a decrease in other revenue.

### Markets Treasury, HSBC Holdings Interest Expense and Argentina Hyperinflation
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The Markets Treasury, HSBC Holdings Interest Expense and Argentina Hyperinflation segment reported a significant increase in revenue, rising by $284 million (over 200%) from 2019. This growth was largely driven by an increase in markets treasury revenue.

Under the standardized and advanced approaches, the risk-weighted assets and TLAC ratios underwent significant changes from 2019 to 2020. For the standardized approach, the risk-weighted assets decreased from $1,493 billion to $1,480 billion, representing a reduction of $13 billion. Similarly, the TLAC ratio decreased from 24.6% to 27.4%, also a reduction of $3.2 percentage points.

For the advanced approach, the risk-weighted assets decreased from $1,447 billion to $1,371 billion, representing a reduction of $76 billion. The TLAC ratio also decreased from 22.0% to 27.4%, a reduction of $5.6 percentage points.

In comparison to the regulatory minimum requirements, the standardized approach's risk-weighted assets and TLAC ratios are within the acceptable limits, while the advanced approach's risk-weighted assets are slightly below the minimum requirements.

![Comparing risk-weighted assets and TLAC ratios from 2019 to 2020 under standardized and advanced approaches](image6)

However, it is worth noting that the risk-weighted assets and TLAC ratios are calculated differently under the standardized and advanced approaches, which can lead to differences in the calculated values. Therefore, it is essential to compare the calculated values with the regulatory minimum requirements and ensure that the correct approach is used.

![Understand that the values are from standardized and advanced approaches](image7)

### Conclusion
The risk-weighted assets and TLAC ratios decreased from 2019 to 2020 under both the standardized and advanced approaches. The standardized approach's risk-weighted assets and TLAC ratios are within the regulatory minimum requirements, while the advanced approach's risk-weighted assets are slightly below the minimum requirements.

Effective Board Succession Planning and Director Development
===========================================================

BHP's Nomination and Governance Committee plays a vital role in ensuring the effective succession planning and development of its Directors. The Committee's rigorous approach and ongoing process aim to maintain a diverse pipeline of talent, balancing experience and new perspectives. 

### A Structured Approach

BHP employs a structured method to manage Board succession planning, ensuring a diverse pipeline of talent. This includes considering unforeseen departures and replacing current Board members, focusing on diversity, size, tenure, skills, experience, and the attributes necessary for effective governance and risk management within BHP.

### Continuous Improvement

The succession planning process is ongoing, particularly for Non-executive Directors, with a nine-year tenure as a guide. The Board aims to maintain a balance between experience and new perspectives and ensure that the Board is equipped to adapt to changing external factors and BHP's specific circumstances.

### Role Description

For new appointments, the Nomination and Governance Committee outlines a role description, incorporating criteria and attributes specified in the Board Governance Document and section 2.1.7.

### Selection and Appointment of Search Firm

An external search firm, selected to carry out a global search, is provided with the role description to align with the Board's criteria.

### Board Interviews

Shortlisted candidates are initially considered by the Chair and the Nomination and Governance Committee. Candidates meet with each Board member before a decision is made about their appointment.

### Committee Recommendation

The Nomination and Governance Committee recommends the preferred candidate for Board appointment.

### Background Checks

The Board, supported by external consultants, performs background and reference checks on the candidate.

### Letter of Appointment

A letter of appointment is produced, detailing the terms for Non-executive Directors, indemnification by the Group, and definitions of their role, independence, participation, time commitment, and continuous improvement. Written agreements are established for all Non-executive Directors.

These steps demonstrate BHP's commitment to effective Board succession planning and director development, ensuring the Board remains equipped to address the challenges of the mining and resources sector.

The various exhibits listed in Accenture's exhibit index relate to different aspects of the company's operations, management, and governance. Here's a breakdown of the different types of exhibits and their relevance to the consolidated financial statements:

### Exhibits Related to Corporate Governance

- **3.1, 3.2, 4.1, 10.1:** These exhibits include Articles of Association for Accenture Canada Holdings Inc., Exchange Trust Agreements, Supplemental Agreements, and other corporate governance documents. These documents outline the company's organizational structure, management, and decision-making processes.
- **Accenture LLP Leadership Separation Benefits Plan:** This exhibit outlines the company's leadership separation benefits plan, which is a formal arrangement for separating the roles of CEO and Chairman of the Board.
- **Key Executive Performance-Based Awards and CEO Discretionary Grants:** Exhibits related to these awards provide details on the compensation packages for Accenture's executive officers.

### Exhibits Related to Legal Filings

- **Power of Attorney and Consents of KPMG LLP:** These exhibits detail the legal filings related to the company's independent audit committee and their engagement with KPMG LLP as the company's auditor.
- **Certifications of compliance with the Sarbanes-Oxley Act:** Exhibits related to these certifications confirm the company's compliance with the relevant provisions of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act.

### Exhibits Related to Share Incentive Plans

- **Share Incentive Plan Agreements:** Exhibits related to these agreements detail the terms and conditions of various share incentive plans, including those for key executives.
- **Employee Share Purchase Plans:** Exhibits outlining these plans describe how employees can purchase shares of the company.

### Exhibits Related to Financial Documents

- **Exhibit 101:** This exhibit contains references to various consolidated financial statements, including the company's balance sheets, income statements, statements of comprehensive income, shareholders' equity statements, and cash flows statements, all formatted in Inline XBRL.

### Exhibit Table and Entries

The table listing exhibits provides detailed information about each document, including:

- **Exhibit Number:** A unique identifier for the exhibit.
- **Description:** A brief summary of the exhibit's content.
- **Reference:** A link to where the document is incorporated, often referencing SEC filings or forms (e.g., 8-K, 10-K, 10-Q, S-1/A).
- **Date:** The date associated with the agreement or filing.
- **Asterisks:** Possibly indicating special notes or conditions.

By examining these exhibits, investors and analysts can gain a deeper understanding of Accenture's corporate governance, financial management, and share incentive plans, which are all critical components of the company's consolidated financial statements.

**Non-GAAP Financial Information:**

Accenture also provides non-GAAP financial information in the report, which management believes offers additional insights into the company's performance. This non-GAAP financial information includes measures such as key performance indicators (KPIs) and financial ratios, which are discussed in the report but are not part of the consolidated financial statements.

**Conclusion:**

The exhibits listed in Accenture's exhibit index provide a comprehensive overview of the company's operations, management, and governance. By analyzing these exhibits, investors can gain a more detailed understanding of Accenture's financial performance, corporate governance practices, and share incentive plans, all of which are integral to the company's consolidated financial statements.

**Upstream and Downstream Performance in 2021 vs 2020**
===========================================================

### Net Income

According to Chevron Corporation's financial statements, the Upstream segment reported a net income of $15,818 million in 2021, compared to a net loss of $(2,433) million in 2020. This represents a significant increase of $18,251 million, driven by higher realizations, absence of impairments, and write-offs, as well as higher sales volumes.

In contrast, the Downstream segment reported a net income of $2,914 million in 2021, compared to a net loss of $(571) million in 2020. This represents an increase of $2,485 million, mainly due to higher margins on refined product sales, earnings from 50%-owned CPChem, and higher sales volumes.

### Total Assets

In terms of total assets, the Upstream segment had assets of $184,412 million in 2021, compared to $191,309 million in 2020. This represents a decrease of $6,897 million.

The Downstream segment had assets of $45,224 million in 2021, compared to $39,586 million in 2020. This represents an increase of $5,638 million.

### Financial Institution Capital Structure and RWA Changes (2019-2020)

The table below outlines key changes in the financial institution's capital structure and Risk-Weighted Assets (RWA) from 2019 to 2020.

#### Credit Risk RWA

| Component | 2019 | 2020 | Change |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Initial Balance (Standardized) | $342,684 million | $387,066 million | $44,382 million |
| Initial Balance (Advanced) | $228,927 million | $284,930 million | $56,003 million |
| Total Change (Standardized) | $44,382 million |  |  |
| Total Change (Advanced) | $56,003 million |  |  |
| Final Balance (Standardized) | $387,066 million |  |  |
| Final Balance (Advanced) | $284,930 million |  |  |

The changes in credit risk RWA show a net increase under both the Standardized and Advanced Approaches. This increase can be attributed to various factors, including an increase in Derivatives exposures driven by market volatility, as well as an increase in Investment securities.

### External TLAC as a Percentage of Risk-Weighted Assets

| Year | External TLAC as a % of RWA (Regulatory) | External TLAC as a % of RWA (Required Ratio) | Actual TLAC as a % of RWA (2020) |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| 2019 | 18.0% | 21.5% | 49.9% |
| 2020 |  |  | 47.7% |

The actual TLAC as a percentage of Risk-Weighted Assets decreased from 49.9% in 2019 to 47.7% in 2020. This indicates a decrease in the External TLAC as a percentage of RWA compared to the regulatory requirement and the required ratio.

#### Capital Ratios

The table below provides a summary of the financial institution's capital ratios in 2019 and 2020.

| Component | 2019 | 2020 | Change |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Common Equity Tier 1 Capital Ratio | 16.4% | 16.4% |  |
| Tier 1 Capital Ratio | 18.6% | 18.6% |  |
| Total Capital Ratio | 21.0% | 21.0% |  |

These capital ratios remained consistent in 2020 compared to 2019, indicating that the financial institution's capital structure and regulatory compliance requirements were met.

### Effect on Capital Structure

The changes in credit risk RWA and External TLAC as a percentage of Risk-Weighted Assets had both positive and negative effects on the financial institution's capital structure.

The increase in credit risk RWA resulted in a higher Risk-Weighted Asset base, which could lead to a higher capital requirement under the Advanced Approach. However, the decrease in External TLAC as a percentage of Risk-Weighted Assets may have resulted in a lower capital requirement.

**[10]** The SCB replaces the existing Common Equity Tier 1 capital conservation buffer of $2.5\%$.

### Changes in Capital Conservation Buffer

The introduction of the Supervisory Capital Buffer (SCB) in 2020 replaced the existing capital conservation buffer of $2.5\%$. The SCB is calculated as the greater of two scenarios:

1.  The maximum decline in Common Equity Tier 1 capital ratio under the severely adverse scenario over the supervisory stress test measurement period plus the sum of the four quarters of planned common stock dividends divided by the projected RWAs from the quarter in which the Firm’s projected Common Equity Tier 1 capital ratio reaches its minimum in the supervisory stress test.
2.  $2.5\%$

This change aims to enhance the resilience of the financial institution's capital structure and reduce the risk of capital depletion in response to adverse economic conditions.

**Intangible Assets with Determinable Lives for Procter & Gamble: A Comparative Analysis**
=============================================================================

As evident from the provided data, Procter & Gamble's intangible assets with determinable lives experienced a noticeable increase in their gross carrying amount from 2021 to 2022. 

*   **Brands:** The gross carrying amount for brands rose from $3,908 in 2021 to $4,299 in 2022, an increase of $491.
*   **Patents and Technology:** The gross carrying amount for patents and technology also increased, rising from $2,781 in 2021 to $2,769 in 2022, a decrease of $12.
*   **Customer Relationships:** The gross carrying amount for customer relationships increased from $1,789 in 2021 to $1,797 in 2022, a rise of $8.
*   **Other:** The gross carrying amount for other intangible assets rose from $150 in 2021 to $147 in 2022, a decrease of $3.

These changes are primarily attributed to the acquisition of a minor brand in the Health Care reportable segment and currency translation effects across all reportable segments. The impact of these factors on the company's overall amortization expenses can be analyzed by examining the changes in the gross carrying amounts and accumulated amortization over the two years.

**Amortization Expenses:**
------------------------

The amortization expenses for intangible assets with determinable lives can be calculated by subtracting the accumulated amortization from the gross carrying amount. 

*   **2021:** 
    *   Brands: $(2,546) ÷ $3,908 = 65.1% of the gross carrying amount
    *   Patents and Technology: $(2,575) ÷ $2,781 = 92.3% of the gross carrying amount
    *   Customer Relationships: $(882) ÷ $1,789 = 49.1% of the gross carrying amount
    *   Other: $(97) ÷ $150 = 64.7% of the gross carrying amount
*   **2022:** 
    *   Brands: $(2,628) ÷ $4,299 = 61.3% of the gross carrying amount
    *   Patents and Technology: $(2,609) ÷ $2,769 = 93.6% of the gross carrying amount
    *   Customer Relationships: $(939) ÷ $1,797 = 51.8% of the gross carrying amount
    *   Other: $(97) ÷ $147 = 66.3% of the gross carrying amount

The amortization expenses for intangible assets with determinable lives decreased from 2021 to 2022, primarily due to the increase in gross carrying amounts. This suggests that the company's overall amortization expenses may be influenced by the growth of its intangible assets with determinable lives.

**Conclusion:**
----------

In conclusion, Procter & Gamble's intangible assets with determinable lives experienced a noticeable increase in their gross carrying amount from 2021 to 2022, primarily due to the acquisition of a minor brand in the Health Care reportable segment and currency translation effects. The company's overall amortization expenses decreased from 2021 to 2022, indicating that the growth of its intangible assets with determinable lives may have contributed to this decrease.

### Potential Impacts and Mitigations for Supply Chain Disruptions

According to [Image2], potential impacts of supply chain disruptions include supply issues and cost increases. Key mitigations for these risks include safety and security policies, business continuity plans, and prioritization based on long-term potential.

Nestlé's factory distribution across different regions is crucial in understanding the potential impacts of supply chain disruptions. The company's ability to maintain supply chains in various regions, as depicted in [Image3], can be critical in preventing supply issues and cost increases. For instance, having a diversified distribution network across the Americas can help mitigate the impact of regional disruptions.

Moreover, Nestlé's emphasis on business continuity planning and safety and security policies, as mentioned in [Image2], can help the company respond effectively to supply chain disruptions. By prioritizing regions with strong supply chains and investing in safety and security measures, Nestlé can minimize the impact of disruptions and ensure the continuity of its operations.

### Conclusion

The potential impacts of supply chain disruptions on Nestlé's operations are significant, and the company must implement effective mitigations to minimize these risks. By maintaining a diversified distribution network, prioritizing regions with strong supply chains, and investing in safety and security measures, Nestlé can ensure the continuity of its operations and minimize the impact of supply chain disruptions.

**Net Interest Income and Total Revenue Comparison for Consumer Banking and Wealth Management Sectors in 2020 vs. 2019**
### Statement on 2020 Performance

According to financial reports, the consumer banking sector experienced a decrease in net interest income of $\S5.5$ billion to $\S43.4$ billion in 2020 compared to 2019. Total revenue, net of interest expense, decreased by $\S1.9$ billion to $\S18.6$ billion. These changes were primarily driven by lower interest rates and increased provision for credit losses.

Wealth management sectors reported a decrease in net interest income, but the specific details regarding total revenue are not directly mentioned in the provided data.

### Key Financial Metrics Comparison

The table for the Consumer Banking sector provides the following key financial metrics:

- **Net interest income:** $5,468 (2020), $6,504 (2019), -16%
- **Noninterest income:** $13,116 (2020), $13,034 (2019), 1%
- **Total revenue, net of interest expense:** $18,584 (2020), $19,538 (2019), -5%
- **Provision for credit losses:** $357 (2020), $82 (2019), n/m (not meaningful)
- **Noninterest expense:** $14,154 (2020), $13,825 (2019), 2%
- **Income before income taxes:** $4,073 (2020), $5,631 (2019), -28%
- **Income tax expense:** $998 (2020), $1,380 (2019), -28%
- **Net income:** $3,075 (2020), $4,251 (2019), -28%

### Additional Metrics Comparison

The table also presents additional key metrics, including the effective tax rate (24.5% in both years), net interest yield (1.73% in 2020, 2.33% in 2019), return on average allocated capital (21 in 2020, 29 in 2019), and efficiency ratio (76.16 in 2020, 70.76 in 2019).

### Insights and Implications

The data suggests that the Consumer Banking sector faced challenges in 2020, primarily due to lower interest rates and increased provision for credit losses. This led to a decrease in net interest income and total revenue. The effective tax rate and efficiency ratio also decreased, indicating potential cost savings but also potential efficiencies.

The Wealth Management sector's performance is not directly comparable, but the decrease in net interest income suggests that the sector may have faced similar challenges.

### Conclusion

The provided data indicates that the Consumer Banking sector experienced a decline in net interest income and total revenue in 2020 compared to 2019. The Wealth Management sector's performance is not directly comparable, but the data suggests that both sectors faced challenges in 2020.

### Comparison of Net Income and Basic EPS under IFRS and Core Results

#### **Year 2020**

- **IFRS Net Income:** $8,071
- **Core Net Income:** $13,158
- **Basic EPS (USD):**
  - IFRS: $3.55
  - Core: $5.78

- **IFRS Net Income:** $14,094
- **Core Net Income:** $10,761
- **Basic EPS (USD):**
  - IFRS: $10.71
  - Core: $6.29

### Adjustments Most Significant in Affecting Net Income and Basic EPS

For **Year 2020**:
- The most significant adjustments in affecting **Net Income** were from **"Income from associated companies"** under **Core Income Before Taxes** and **Other financial income and expense** under **Core Income Before Taxes**. However, the most impactful figures are likely to be the increase in **Core Net Income** from $8,071 to $13,158 and the change in **Basic EPS** from $3.55 to $5.78.
- For **Basic EPS**, the adjustments in IFRS and core results are significantly impacted by the changes in net income, especially the growth from IFRS to Core results, with core EPS more than doubling from $3.55 to $5.78.

For **Year 2021**:
- The **net income** is decreased under **Core Results** from $14,094 to $10,761, indicating that the core results accounting for significant expenses or charges has reduced the net income. Conversely, the **Basic EPS** under IFRS increases to $10.71 compared to the core EPS of $6.29, showing a more substantial increase in earnings per share under IFRS.
- The adjustment most significant in affecting **Basic EPS** under IFRS was the increase from the core EPS of $6.29 to the IFRS EPS of $10.71, showing a substantial difference in the way earnings per share is calculated between IFRS and core results.

### Summary

- The most significant adjustments in affecting net income and basic EPS were the changes in "Income from associated companies" and other financial income and expenses as part of the core results.
- The contrast between IFRS and core results shows that certain accounting changes can have a significant impact on both net income and basic EPS, especially in terms of the classification and impact of various expenses and income items.
- The specific adjustments most impactful can vary significantly between the two years, depending on the nature of the items included in the adjustments and how they are treated under both IFRS and core results.

Lease and Employee Benefit Liabilities have experienced significant changes due to the transition to AASB 16. 

According to [4], site restoration is now capitalised as part of the lease right-of-use asset and depreciated over the life of the lease term. Previously, it was capitalized as part of leasehold improvements and depreciated over the estimated useful life of the leasehold improvements. This shift has resulted in an increase in lease liabilities.

The transition to AASB 16 has also led to changes in the accounting for employee benefits. Prior to the adoption, employee benefits such as annual leave were capitalized as a provision for future restoration costs and depreciated over the estimated useful life of the leasehold improvements. However, as of the transition to AASB 16, employee benefits are now expensed immediately. 

This change resulted in an increase in employee benefit liabilities, as the cost of restoring site was capitalized previously but is now expensed. Consequently, the financial impact of the transition to AASB 16 on lease and employee benefit liabilities in 2020 was a significant increase.

![The amounts of lease liabilities increased from $143,621 at 1 July 2019 to $167,154 at 28 June 2020.](image1)

The fair value allocation of net assets acquired differs between the ClickSoftware and Salesforce.org acquisitions. The main difference lies in the valuation of goodwill.

In the ClickSoftware acquisition, the excess of purchase consideration over the fair value of net tangible and identifiable intangible assets acquired was recorded as goodwill, primarily attributed to the assembled workforce and expanded market opportunities.

On the other hand, the Salesforce.org acquisition had a more straightforward fair value allocation, with the excess of purchase consideration over the fair value of net tangible and identifiable intangible assets acquired also being recorded as goodwill. However, unlike the ClickSoftware acquisition, the goodwill in this case was primarily attributed to the assembled workforce and expanded market opportunities, for which there is no basis for U.S. income tax purposes.

### Toyota's Executive Remuneration Evaluation: A Reflective Framework
**[1]** Toyota sets the total amount of remuneration received by each director in a year based on consolidated operating income, the volatility of the share price of Toyota, and individual performance evaluation. The balance after deducting monthly remuneration, which is fixed remuneration, from Annual Total Remuneration constitutes performance-linked remuneration.

![The table contains three rows with two columns each. In the first row, the left column contains "Consolidated operating income," and the right column mentions "Indicator for evaluating Toyota’s efforts based on business performance."](image1)

**[2]** Remuneration for Outside Members of the Board of Directors and Audit & Supervisory Board Members consists only of fixed payments. As a result, this remuneration is not readily impacted by business performance, helping to ensure independence from management.

**[3]** Toyota sets an appropriate executive compensation level for the Annual Total Remuneration based on position and duties by referencing a benchmark group of companies located in Japan.

**[4]** Toyota's executive compensation system is an important means to promote various initiatives and is determined based on the following policy.

**[5]** Toyota deems the benefit of its shareholders an important element of its management policy and continues to work to improve its corporate structure and enhance its corporate value in order to realize sustainable growth.

**[6]** Using cost reduction and the thorough application of the Toyota Production System (TPS), we are reinforcing the profit structure and securing funds to invest in advanced and cutting-edge technologies.

**[7]** Toyota's executive compensation system reflects their business performance through the evaluation of consolidated operating income and volatility of the share price of Toyota.

![The table shows an evaluation framework for Toyota, divided into two main criteria: Consolidated Operating Income and Volatility of Toyota’s Share Price.](image3)

The financial metrics presented in **[5]**, specifically dividend payments, shareholder returns, and payout ratios, demonstrate Toyota's focus on enhancing shareholder value and dividends.

**[8]** Toyota engages in constructive dialogue with the issuers of shares it holds to encourage them to improve corporate value and achieve sustainable growth.

![The table presents financial data for five fiscal years, specifically ending in March of each year from 2017 to 2021, indicating dividend payments, total payments, payout ratio, and share repurchases.](image5)

### Conclusion
Toyota's executive remuneration evaluation effectively reflects their business performance and shareholder value indicators by considering key metrics such as consolidated operating income, volatility of the share price, and dividend payments. This approach enables the company to balance individual performance evaluation with corporate performance assessment, ultimately promoting sustainable growth and shareholder value enhancement.

Comprehensive income of Danaher Corporation increased by approximately $\$3.6$ billion in 2020 as compared to 2018, primarily due to net earnings of $\$3.6$ billion in 2020, a gain on sale of product lines of $\$455$ million, and a foreign currency translation gain of $\$2.9$ billion. The increase in comprehensive income is also attributed to the effect of gain on sale of product lines, net earnings from Cytiva, and the provision for uncertain tax positions recorded in the first quarter of 2019.

[1] Comprehensive income increased by approximately $\$3.6$ billion in 2020 as compared to 2018, primarily due to net earnings of $\$3.6$ billion in 2020, a gain on sale of product lines of $\$455$ million, and a foreign currency translation gain of $\$2.9$ billion.
[2] Comprehensive income can be broken down into the following categories, which contributed to the change in comprehensive income from 2018 to 2020.
[3]   *   Net earnings: The company’s net earnings increased by $\$540$ million in 2020 as compared to 2018, driven by increased sales in existing businesses, net earnings from Cytiva, and a gain on sale of product lines.
[4]   *   Other comprehensive income: The foreign currency translation gain of $\$2.9$ billion in 2020 contributed to the increase in comprehensive income, while the foreign currency translation loss of $\$75$ million in 2019 resulted in a decrease in comprehensive income.
[5]   *   Other comprehensive income includes items that are not part of net income. These items are typically adjustments for changes in the value of certain assets and liabilities. In this case, the foreign currency translation gain increased comprehensive income, while the foreign currency translation loss decreased comprehensive income.
[6] The increase in comprehensive income from 2018 to 2020 can be attributed to the following factors:
[7]   *   Increased sales in existing businesses: The company's sales increased by 24.5% in 2020 compared to 2019, driven by the acquisition of Cytiva.
[8]   *   Net earnings from Cytiva: The Cytiva Acquisition contributed significantly to the increase in comprehensive income, with Cytiva's core sales growing more than 30% in 2020 compared to the comparable 2019 period.
[9]   *   Gain on sale of product lines: The company recognized a pretax gain on sale of $\$455$ million in 2020, which contributed to the increase in comprehensive income.
[10]   *   Gain on sale of product lines: The gain on sale of product lines increased comprehensive income, as the sale resulted in a pretax gain of $\$455$ million.

[7]  2020 operating cash flows benefited from higher net earnings in 2020 as compared to 2019.
[8]  However, the impact of this increase was partially offset by the fact that 2019 net earnings from continuing operations included $\$215$ million of net discrete noncash tax charges compared to a net discrete noncash tax benefit of $\$85$ million in 2020.
[9]  In addition, net earnings from continuing operations in 2020 included $\$22$ million of noncash impairment charges and $\$6$ million of fair value adjustment gains related to certain long-lived assets and investments.
[10] These noncash charges and gains impacted earnings without a corresponding impact to operating cash flows.
[11] Net earnings for 2020 reflected an increase of approximately $\$1.1$ billion of depreciation, amortization (intangible assets and inventory step-up) and stock compensation expense as compared to 2019.
[12] The increase in depreciation and amortization in 2020 compared to 2019 is primarily due to the Cytiva Acquisition in 2020.

Sensitivity determinations applied the same methodology as applied for the determination of the post-employment benefit obligation. Sensitivities reflect changes in the defined benefit obligation solely for the assumption changed.
Siemens ­ Healthineers measures entitlements from defined benefit plans by applying the projected unit credit method.  Thereby, the obligation from defined benefit plans reflects an actuarially calculated present value of the future benefit entitlement for services already rendered (defined benefit obligation, DBO). Actuarial valuations rely on key assumptions including discount rates, expected compensation increases and pension progression and mortality rates. Discount rates are determined by reference to yields on high-quality corporate bonds of appropriate duration and currency at the end of the reporting period. High-quality corporate bonds have an issuing volume of more than 100 million units (in the respective currency) and an AA rating (or equivalent) by at least one of the three rating agencies Moody’s Investors Service, S & P Global Ratings or Fitch Ratings. In such case that yields are not available, discount rates are based on government bond yields. For significant plans, individual spot rates from a full yield curve approach are applied in general. Due to changing market, economic and social conditions, the underlying actuarial assumptions may differ from actual developments.
The Conditional Capital 2018 and the authorization to issue convertible bonds or warrants under warrant bonds as of February 19, 2018 were canceled by resolution at the Shareholders’ Meeting on February 12, 2021. Simultaneously, the share capital was conditionally increased by up to €107.5 million (107,500,000 shares, Conditional Capital 2021) and the authorization of the Managing Board to issue convertible bonds and/or or warrant bonds was renewed. The Conditional Capital 2021 serves to grant shares to holders or creditors of bonds issued by Siemens–Healthineers AG or one of its affiliated companies until February 11, 2026. Furthermore, the Managing Board was authorized to exclude the subscription rights of the shareholders with the approval of the Supervisory Board.
Siemens–Healthineers provides post-employment benefits for the majority of its employees, partly resulting in provisions for pensions. An increase of provisions for pensions due to an adverse development of plan assets or the defined benefit obligation is considered a significant risk. The funded status can be affected by changes in actuarial assumptions, primarily the discount rate, as well as by movements in financial markets.  In order to comply with local pension regulations in selected foreign countries, we may face increasing cash outflows to reduce an underfunding of our pension plans in these countries.  Regular asset liability studies are performed for major pension plans to implement an investment strategy to mitigate liability risks and reduce funded status volatility.

**Definition of Accumulated Depreciation**
Accumulated depreciation is the total depreciation expense recorded over the life of an asset, reflecting the decrease in value over time. It is a contra-asset account that offsets the cost of property, plant, and equipment (PP&E).

**Accumulated Depreciation and Net Value of Solar Energy Systems**
From 2019 to 2020, the net value of solar energy systems decreased from $6,138 million to $5,979 million. This decline is primarily due to an increase in accumulated depreciation.

### Net Income and Comprehensive Income Impact

For a comprehensive understanding of how Accenture's net income and comprehensive income influenced total shareholders' equity over the years 2018 to 2020, let's delve into the provided data.

### Image 1 Overview

The cash flow statement (image 1) is a critical component of the financial data, detailing the company's activities in terms of cash inflows and outflows. While it does not directly impact equity, it's integral in understanding the broader financial health and liquidity position of the company. The statement is categorized into three main sections: cash flows from operating activities, investing activities, and financing activities.

### Image 2 Detailed Equity Components

Image 2 (image 2) presents a detailed breakdown of Accenture's equity components, including net income, other comprehensive income (loss), and their respective attributions to the company and noncontrolling interests. 

- **Net Income** represents the profit or loss of the company for the period. It is crucial for understanding the core financial performance of the business.
- **Other Comprehensive Income (Loss)** encompasses items that are not included in net income, such as foreign currency translation adjustments, defined benefit plan adjustments, cash flow hedges, and investments. These components can significantly impact the equity balance and should be carefully managed to maintain the company's financial stability.

### Image 3 Equity Changes

The table in image 3 (image 3) shows the detailed changes in shareholders' equity over a fiscal year. It includes various sections for different types of shares, treasury shares, equity adjustments, Accenture plc, and noncontrolling interests. The key components such as net income, comprehensive income, share purchases, treasury shares, share-based compensation, dividends, and other adjustments are noted, providing a comprehensive view of the financial activities that affect the company's equity.

### Image 4 and 5 - Equity Components

Images 4 (image 4) and 5 (image 5) offer additional details on equity changes, focusing on specific components like ordinary shares, class A ordinary shares, additional paid-in capital, treasury shares, retained earnings, accumulated other comprehensive loss, and noncontrolling interests. These tables highlight the intricate relationships between these equity components and the broader financial picture of the company.

### Impact on Total Shareholders' Equity

The impact of Accenture's net income and comprehensive income over the years 2018 to 2020 is evident in the changes to the company's equity. Net income, which is a direct result of the company's operations, plays a significant role in determining the increase or decrease in retained earnings and subsequently the total shareholders' equity.

- **Fiscal Year 2018**: The total shareholders' equity at the end of the year was $3,730,974, with a comprehensive income figure of $3,730,974. This comprehensive income figure is entirely attributed to the company itself, indicating no impact from noncontrolling interests.
- **Fiscal Year 2019**: The equity increased to $4,846,241, driven by a net income figure of $4,846,241 and comprehensive income of $575,086, with $264,406 attributed to the company and $310,380 attributed to noncontrolling interests.
- **Fiscal Year 2020**: The equity reached $5,185,313, driven by a net income figure of $5,185,313 and comprehensive income of $5,472,296, with $5,386,579 attributed to the company and $85,717 attributed to noncontrolling interests.

In conclusion, Accenture's net income and comprehensive income had a significant impact on the total shareholders' equity over the years 2018 to 2020. The comprehensive income figures, in particular, demonstrate the company's financial performance beyond just net income, highlighting its ability to manage various financial risks and opportunities.

Lovisa has leveraged its existing international territories to expand its store footprint, with a focus on securing quality retail store sites in locations with high pedestrian traffic. The group has refined its global store model based on what it understands to be the optimal store size, location, and format. This has enabled the roll-out of stores quickly, at low cost, with an average time of 14 days to fit out a new Lovisa store. [9]

Lovisa's growth strategy is based on its ability to increase earnings contributions from existing stores and continue to open and operate new stores on a timely and profitable basis. The group has successfully established a portfolio of company-owned stores in Australia, New Zealand, Singapore, Malaysia, South Africa, the United Kingdom, France, and the United States of America, and supporting franchised stores in Kuwait, the United Arab Emirates, Oman, Bahrain, Saudi Arabia, Qatar, and Vietnam. [4]

Through its international store expansion strategy, Lovisa aims to capitalize on the opportunities presented and obtain scale in these markets. The group continues to explore other markets through pilot programs and will advise shareholders upon successful completion of those pilot programs. [4]

However, Lovisa faces challenges in expanding into new markets, including competition, retail environment and economic conditions, failure to implement strategies, and lack of suitable locations. To mitigate this risk, the group employs a product team of more than 20 people to meet market demands. [8]

To analyze the effect of the changes in noncurrent assets and long-term debt on IBM's overall financial standing, let's examine the data on noncurrent assets and long-term debt between 2019 and 2020, as well as the changes in cash flows and equity.

According to the provided data, the increase in noncurrent assets of $\S3,039$ million ( $\scriptstyle{\mathfrak{S}}829$ million adjusted for currency) in 2020 was primarily driven by [4]. The same data also shows that the long-term debt decreased by $\S3,560$ million from December 31, 2019 ( $\$3,905$ million adjusting for currency) in 2020, primarily due to lower funding requirements as a result of the decline in financing assets, consistent with the company’s portfolio management strategy, as mentioned in [5].

Now, let's look at the cash flow information presented in image3. The decrease in net cash used for acquisitions of $\S32,294$ million due to the Red Hat acquisition in the prior year, as mentioned in [8], partially offset by a decrease of $\S6,245$ million in cash provided by net non-operating finance receivables primarily driven by the wind down of the OEM IT commercial financing operations.

We can also observe that the net change in cash, cash equivalents, and restricted cash for 2020 was $\$5,361$ million, while for 2019 it was $(\$3,290)$ million, as presented in image3.

Additionally, the total debt of $\$61,538$ million decreased $\pmb{\updownarrow}\texttt{11,501}$ million since the end of the second quarter 2019 (immediately preceding the Red Hat acquisition), as shown in [9]. The debt used to fund Global Financing assets is composed of intercompany loans and external debt. Total debt changes generally correspond with the level of client and commercial financing receivables, the level of cash and cash equivalents, the change in intercompany and external payables and the change in intercompany investment from IBM, as mentioned in [5].

Considering these changes in cash flows and equity, IBM's overall financial standing appears to have improved in 2020 due to the decrease in long-term debt and the increase in noncurrent assets. However, the change in cash flows also shows a decrease in net cash used for acquisitions and an increase in net cash provided by non-operating finance receivables, which could be a positive factor for the company's financial standing.

The final answer is: The changes in noncurrent assets and long-term debt between 2019 and 2020, along with the changes in cash flows and equity, suggest that IBM's overall financial standing improved in 2020 due to the decrease in long-term debt and the increase in noncurrent assets.

The total future minimum lease payments are a significant component of the company's financial obligations. According to the table presented in image4, the total future minimum lease payments amount to $5,046 million. This figure represents the sum of future lease payments made over the next few years, including $865 million in 2021, $775 million in 2022, and $646 million in 2023.

![Total future minimum lease payments](image4)

To calculate the total future minimum lease payments, the company follows a specific process. First, it identifies all non-cancelable operating leases and estimates the future lease payments. The company then calculates the present value of these future lease payments using the appropriate discount rate. Finally, it adds up the present values of all future lease payments to arrive at the total future minimum lease payments.

![Calculation of total future minimum lease payments](image4)

The table in image4 provides a detailed breakdown of future minimum lease payments by year, including:

*   2021: $865 million
*   2022: $775 million
*   2023: $646 million
*   2024: $538 million
*   2025: $441 million
*   Thereafter: $1,781 million

After subtracting imputed interest of $599 million, the total future minimum lease payments amount to $4,447 million. This represents the total amount the company expects to pay over the next few years to satisfy its lease obligations.

We have an active program for managing capital through a comprehensive process for assessing the Company’s overall capital adequacy. Our objective is to maintain capital at an amount commensurate with our risk profile and risk tolerance objectives, and to meet both regulatory and market expectations. We primarily fund our capital needs through the retention of earnings net of both dividends and share repurchases, as well as through the issuance of preferred stock and long- and short-term debt. Retained earnings at December 31, 2021, increased $17.6 billion from December 31,  2020, predominantly as a result of  $21.5  billion of Wells Fargo  net income, partially offset by  $3.7  billion of common and  preferred stock dividends. During 2021, we issued  $2.1  billion of  common stock, substantially all of which was issued in connection with employee compensation and benefits. In 2021, we repurchased 306 million shares of common stock at a cost of  $14.5  billion. For additional information about capital planning, see the “Capital Planning and Stress Testing” section below.

As shown in Table 5.6, the future lease payments under operating leases as well as information on the remaining average lease term and discount rate as of December 31, 2021, for additional information about capital planning, see the “Capital Management – Capital Planning and  Stress Testing” section in this Report.

On January 25, 2022, the Board approved an increase to the Company’s first quarter 2022 common stock dividend to  $0.25  per share. For additional information about capital planning, see the “Capital Management – Capital Planning and  Stress Testing” section in this Report.
