Toward achieving transformation into a mobility company, Toyota is committed to both “realizing advanced monozukuri (manufacturing) with higher quality and efficiency based on Toyota Production System (TPS)” and “taking on challenges in new areas.” To this end, Toyota encourages its employees to reexamine their workstyles and hone their individual abilities, thereby enhancing the workplace structures. [1]
With respect to its framework for executing operations, Toyota has been continuing its efforts to respond swiftly to the external environment, which is changing faster than ever. Following the introduction of “region-based management” in 2011, the “business unit system” in 2013, and the “in-house company system” in 2016, in 2017, Toyota further clarified that Members of the Board of Directors are responsible for decision making and management oversight and that operating officers are responsible for operational execution for the purposes of further accelerating implementation of decisions. [7]
The Toyota Safety Sense system packages multiple active safety functions based around three major functions considered effective in reducing serious traffic accidents causing death or injury. These are Pre-Collision Safety (PCS), which helps avoid and mitigate damage from collisions with cars ahead or pedestrians; Lane Departure Alert (LDA), which contributes to preventing accidents caused by leaving the lane of travel; and Automatic High Beam (AHB), which helps ensure clear sight in front of the vehicle at night. In 2018, we expanded the system’s driving assistance functions, such as nighttime pedestrian and daytime cyclist detection and Lane Tracing Assist (LTA). [5]
 Toyota provides optimized driver support at every stage of driving, from parking to normal operation, the moment before a collision, during a collision, and post-collision emergency response. We also aim to enhance safety by strengthening inter-system coordination, rather than considering each system separately. These are the approaches behind our Integrated Safety Management Concept. [6]

The image illustrates a fleet management system based on the Toyota Production System (TPS) for e-Palettes. It highlights a "just-in-time mobility" approach, outlining the process as follows:
1. Increase in Customer Demand: When waiting customers increase, the system responds through an operation management center called AMMS.
2. Real-Time Dispatch: Additional units are dispatched in real-time to meet demand.
3. Operation Consistency: The system works to prevent variations in operation intervals.
4. Remote Management: Features include emergency remote vehicle stop/restart, immediate deployment of replacement vehicles, and automatic redirection to a garage in case of abnormalities. 
The graphic emphasizes efficient, flexible management of vehicle fleets. [3]
When there is an increase in waiting customers, the Fleet Management System of Toyota responds by increasing customer dispatch in real-time through an operation management center called AMMS. This system is designed to provide efficient and flexible management of vehicle fleets, ensuring that there is always a suitable vehicle available to meet customer demand.

Beverage volume includes volume of concentrate sold to independent bottlers and volume of finished products bearing company-owned or licensed trademarks and allied brand products and joint venture trademarks sold by company-owned bottling operations, including by our noncontrolled affiliates. Concentrate volume sold to independent bottlers is reported in concentrate shipments and equivalents (CSE), whereas finished beverage product volume is reported in bottler case sales (BCS). Both CSE and BCS convert all beverage volume to an 8-ounce-case metric. Typically, CSE and BCS are not equal in any given period due to seasonality, timing of product launches, product mix, bottler inventory practices and other factors.  Brazil Minerals, Inc. has a strong focus on developing its hard-rock lithium projects in Brazil. Currently, our main goal is to enter commercial production of spodumene concentrate, a lithium-bearing commodity.

### On our Lithium Project in Minas Gerais


 Brazil Minerals, Inc. has consolidated our results as of December 31, 2020 in this Annual Report. The lithium projects owned by Brazil Minerals, Inc. are summarized in the table below. We currently own approximately $60\%$ of Apollo Resources Corporation.

Our Minas Gerais Lithium Project encompasses 43 mineral rights for lithium in the Brazilian Western Pegmatite Province in the municipalities of Araçuai, Coronel Murta, Itinga, Rubelita, Taiobeiras, and Virgem da Lapa. Mineralizations are described in metric to decametric pegmatite bodies, with tear geometry, with well-defined zoning, accessible both on surface and in galleries. The lithium ore occurs as crystals of centimetric to metric sizes of spodumene among masses of lepidolite and albite. We have a dedicated exploratory geology team responsible for the detailed mapping, systematic sampling and analysis of the pegmatite occurrences within our project area.

| Mineral | Project Name & Location in Brazil | Total Area (acres) | Status |
|---------|---------------------------------------|---------------------|--------|
| Lithium | Minas Gerais Lithium Project         | 57,855 acres         | Research Exploration |


Our sand deposits are located on the banks and on the Jequitinhonha River in the state of Minas Gerais. High-quality, commercial grade sand for construction use is found in our deposits. A professional mining engineer surveyor measured one of our deposits to contain 1,140,400 cubic meters of sand in the surveyed area, with an average modeled body thickness of $3.07\;\mathrm{m}$, very close to the average of $3.19\;\mathrm{m}$  found in the 13 sampled holes. Several other deposits of similar size are thought to exist in our overall project area.

Our Diamond Project is located in the State of Minas Gerais and comprises a total of 24 mineral rights, including 10 mining concessions, the highest level of mining title in Brazil. All our diamond rights are located along the banks of the Jequitinhonha River in the northern part of Minas Gerais. This river rises within the Diamantina Plateau, a region where more than alluvial diamond produced in the world for more than 200 years. The Diamantina region stands out not only for being the place where diamonds were first discovered in the country, in 1714, but also for being responsible for most of the Brazilian production to date.

### Comprehensive Income and Net Income Changes

Comparing the comprehensive income and net income figures for the years 2018 to 2020 from the provided information:

#### 2018:

- **Comprehensive Income:** $8,313 million
- **Net Income:** $8,394 million

#### 2019:

- **Comprehensive Income:** $8,083 million
- **Net Income:** $7,842 million

#### 2020:

- **Comprehensive Income:** $6,807 million
- **Net Income:** $7,264 million

The comprehensive income and net income show a decline from 2018 to 2020.

### Inference Regarding Financial Performance

The decline in both comprehensive income and net income suggests a worsening financial performance over the years 2018 to 2020. The comprehensive income, which includes all changes in equity except those resulting from investments by owners and distributions to owners, directly reflects the change in equity's net amount. Net income specifically measures the total amount of profit available to shareholders, after deducting all expenses.

These declines indicate that despite the company's revenue growth (as seen in product sales and other revenues), the overall profitability and financial health might be under pressure due to various factors such as:

- **Increasing Operating Expenses:** Despite higher revenues, the company's operating expenses grew or at least kept pace with revenue increases, suggesting inefficiencies or increased costs.
- **Provision for Income Taxes:** The increase in the provision for income taxes in 2019 indicates higher tax expenses, which can be due to various factors including tax reforms or increased activity.
- **Net Unrealized Gains/Losses on Investments:** The negative net unrealized gains in 2020 compared to 2019 might be due to market fluctuations affecting the company's investment portfolio.

However, without further context, it's challenging to pinpoint the exact reasons for the decline. The company's ability to invest in research and development, pay dividends, and undertake strategic acquisitions will also influence its financial performance.

**Definition of Evaluation Weight Distribution**
According to [image1], the evaluation weight for consolidated operating income and volatility of Toyota's share price are both 50%.

The quote from [1] clearly states, "1. Consolidated Operating Income - Evaluation Weight: 50% - Evaluation Method: Degree of attainment of consolidated operating income in the current fiscal year, using the required income set in 2011 for Toyota’s sustainable growth." Similarly, it also mentions, "2. Volatility of Toyota’s Share Price - Evaluation Weight: 50% - Evaluation Method: Comparative evaluation of the volatility of Toyota’s share price using the share price of Toyota and the Nikkei stock average at the end of the previous fiscal year."

```markdown
|  **Criteria**  |  **Evaluation Weight**  |  **Evaluation Method**  |
|  :---------:  |  :-----------------:  |  :-----------------:  |
|  Consolidated  |           50%         |  Degree of attainment of |
|    Operating  |                             |  consolidated operating  |
|   Income      |                             |   income in the current  |
|  Volatility  |           50%         |  Comparative evaluation  |
|   of Toyota's  |                             |  of the volatility of  |
|    Share Price |                             |  Toyota’s share price using |
|  (Indicator)  |                             |  the share price of      |
|               |                             |  Toyota and the Nikkei    |
|               |                             |  stock average at the end |
|               |                             |  of the previous fiscal |
|               |                             |  year                     |
```

**Conclusion**
The evaluation weight distribution is equal for both consolidated operating income and volatility of Toyota's share price, each with a weight of 50%.

### Comparison of Capital Expenditures and Shareholder Returns

McDonald's capital expenditures and shareholder returns showed a marked improvement in 2020 compared to 2018 and 2019. Capital expenditures decreased by $\$753$ million or  $31\%$  in 2020, primarily due to lower reinvestment in existing restaurants as a result of COVID-19. On the other hand, shareholder returns increased significantly, with dividends paid reaching $\$4.6$ billion in 2020, a substantial increase from the $\$3.6$ billion paid in 2019. This demonstrates the Company's ability to balance its investment in new restaurants with a focus on returning value to shareholders.

*   Cigarettes: Sales decreased by 11.8% from 72,293 million units in 2019 to 63,749 million units in 2020.
*   Heated Tobacco Units: Sales increased by 50.8% from 299 million units in 2019 to 451 million units in 2020.

**Factors Contributing to the Changes:**
---------------------------------------

In East Asia & Australia, the decrease in cigarette sales is largely attributed to the growth of the cigarette new taste dimension segment, where Philip Morris International (PMI) has a relatively low share. On the other hand, the increase in heated tobacco unit sales is driven by the popularity of PMI's heated tobacco products.

In contrast, the decline in cigarette sales in Latin America & Canada is primarily due to adult smoker down-trading to ultra-low-price brands produced by local manufacturers. However, the region saw a significant increase in heated tobacco unit sales, largely due to the growing popularity of PMI's heated tobacco products in the region.

These changes reflect the shifting consumer preferences and market trends in the tobacco industry.

This could be due to a variety of factors, including increased efficiency in capital management, changes in dividend payments, share repurchases, or other financing activities.

### Comparison of Noncurrent Assets, Long-term Debt, and Noncurrent Liabilities (Excluding Debt) Between 2019 and 2020

IBM's financial data reveals significant changes in key components of its balance sheet between 2019 and 2020, reflecting the company's financial strategy and liquidity position.

#### Noncurrent Assets
The table provided in image2 indicates that noncurrent assets increased from $113,767 million in 2019 to $116,806 million in 2020, a growth of $3,039 million ($829 million adjusted for currency). This increase signifies that IBM has made efforts to enhance its financial assets, potentially driven by strategic investments or the acquisition of new businesses.

#### Long-term Debt
In contrast, long-term debt decreased from $54,102 million in 2019 to $54,355 million in 2020, a reduction of $1,157 million ($43 million adjusted for currency). This decrease in long-term debt could be a result of debt repayment or refinancing, indicating the company's ability to manage its financial obligations.

#### Noncurrent Liabilities (Excluding Debt)
Noncurrent liabilities excluding debt decreased from $39,398 million in 2019 to $41,020 million in 2020, an increase of $1,622 million ($251 million adjusted for currency). However, this growth primarily stems from the inclusion of certain liabilities, which, when removed, reveals a net decrease in noncurrent liabilities excluding debt.

### Implications on the Company's Financial Strategy

These changes in noncurrent assets, long-term debt, and noncurrent liabilities (excluding debt) have implications for IBM's financial strategy:

1.  **Asset Management**: The increase in noncurrent assets suggests that IBM is focusing on acquiring or investing in businesses or assets that align with its strategic objectives, potentially driving growth and profitability.
2.  **Debt Management**: The decrease in long-term debt indicates that the company has made efforts to manage its financial obligations and reduce its debt burden, which can improve its financial flexibility and reduce its cost of capital.
3.  **Liquidity Position**: Despite the increase in noncurrent liabilities, IBM's strong liquidity position, as evident from its ample financial flexibility and cash flows, provides a buffer against potential short-term liquidity challenges.

In conclusion, the changes in noncurrent assets, long-term debt, and noncurrent liabilities (excluding debt) between 2019 and 2020 provide insights into IBM's financial strategy, indicating efforts to enhance its financial assets, manage its debt, and maintain a strong liquidity position.

While Bank of America has made significant efforts to address environmental issues such as air pollution and greenhouse gas emissions, there is still much work to be done to minimize their impact on the environment and society. On one hand, Bank of America has taken steps to reduce their carbon footprint and invest in renewable energy. For instance, they have committed to achieving net-zero greenhouse gas emissions before 2050 and have made significant investments in renewable energy sources.

On the other hand, Bank of America's operations still have a significant impact on the environment, particularly in terms of air pollution. According to their 2019 emissions report, they emitted nitrogen oxides (NOx), sulfur oxides (SOx), particulate matter, and other pollutants from their operations. These emissions can have serious health and environmental impacts, particularly in urban areas.

Bank of America's efforts to address these issues include their investment in clean energy and their commitment to reducing their carbon footprint. However, more work needs to be done to minimize their impact on the environment and society.

![The table presents information on Bank of America's initiatives and performance related to climate change and freshwater availability, organized under the theme "Planet*". Here's a breakdown of what's included:](image1)

**Theme: Climate Change**

1. **Metric: Greenhouse Gas (GHG) Emissions**
   - **Response**: Details of Bank of America's 2019 GHG emissions, with reductions since 2010. Emission categories include Scopes 1, 2, and 3, such as location-based, market-based, purchased goods, capital goods, employee commuting, and more.

2. **Metric: TCFD Implementation**
   - **Response**: Bank of America's commitment to the Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures (TCFD) and its efforts to reach net-zero GHG emissions by 2050. The bank has launched a TCFD report and set targets aligned with the Paris Agreement.

3. **Metric: Paris-aligned GHG Emissions Targets**
   - **Response**: Strategies and interim targets to align with the Paris Agreement goals, involving client engagement, operational emissions, and investment portfolio emissions.

4. **Metric: Impact of Greenhouse Gas Emissions**
   - **Response**: The societal impact of the Bank's emissions was estimated at $238 million in 2019 based on EPA's social cost of carbon.

Changes in sales prices and volumes had a substantial impact on the Underlying EBITDA between 2020 and 2021. Specifically, a $16,965 million increase in sales prices, primarily due to higher prices for commodities like iron ore, copper, and nickel, contributed significantly to the growth in Underlying EBITDA. 

On the other hand, a decrease of $312 million in volumes, partly due to record volumes and natural field declines, as well as impacts from acquisitions and natural events, negatively affected Underlying EBITDA. However, these offsetting effects were largely overcome by the positive impact of a $16,095 million change in sales prices, after adjusting for the effect of price-linked costs. 

Overall, the increase in sales prices, especially for key commodities, and the positive adjustment for price-linked costs, contributed to a substantial growth in Underlying EBITDA of $15,308 million, highlighting the key role of commodity pricing in driving the company's financial performance.

The percentage change in the number of offshore stores from FY18 to FY19 can be found in the provided image quotes. According to the Revenue Growth (A$M) chart, the number of offshore stores in FY18 was 326, and in FY19 it was 390. Therefore, the number of offshore stores increased by 64 stores over the year.

To calculate the percentage change, we can use the following formula:

((Increase in number of stores / Original number of stores) * 100)

Plugging in the values, we get:

((64 / 326) * 100) = 19.7%

So, the number of offshore stores increased by 19.7% from FY18 to FY19.

**Decreased Impairment Losses on Other Investments**
[6] Impairment of Non-marketable Equity Investments.  We monitor our investments for events or circumstances that could  indicate impairment, including those that result from observable price adjustments. In fiscal 2021, we recorded impairment  losses on other investments (which primarily related to our non-marketable equity investments) of   $\$33$   million, a decrease of   $\$372$   million compared to fiscal 2020. Significant evaluation and judgments were required in determining if the negative  effects of COVID-19 indicated that such investments were impaired, and if so, the extent of such impairment. This included,  among other items: (i) assessing the business impacts that COVID-19 had on our investees, including taking into  consideration the investee’s industry and geographic location and the impact to its customers, suppliers and employees, as  applicable, (ii) evaluating the investees’ ability to respond to the impacts of COVID-19, including any significant  deterioration in the investee’s financial condition and cash flows, as well as assessing liquidity and/or going concern risks and  (iii) considering any appreciation in fair value that has not been recognized in the carrying values of such investments. Based  on this evaluation, certain of our investments were impaired and written down to their estimated fair values in fiscal 2020 (a  significant portion of which related to the full impairment of our investment in OneWeb, who filed for bankruptcy in the  second quarter of fiscal 2020). For a significant portion of the impairment losses recorded in 2020, the estimated fair values  resulted in a full write-off of the carrying value. In fiscal 2021, there were no significant impairment losses or adjustments to  our previous judgments and estimates recorded.

The use of reasonable estimates and judgements is an essential part of the preparation of the consolidated financial statements [9]. In Novo Nordisk's case, the company identifies several areas with significant accounting judgments and estimates, along with the associated estimation risks.

### 1. **US net sales and rebates**
The estimate of US sales deductions and provisions for sales rebates is considered a high-risk estimate, with a noted estimation risk in Note 2.1 [5]. This policy area involves significant judgement and estimation by Management, particularly in a US healthcare environment with growing competitive pricing pressure and product discounting trends [7].

### 2. **Income taxes and deferred income taxes**
The judgment and estimate regarding deferred income tax assets and provision for uncertain tax positions are also subject to a medium estimation risk, as noted in Note 2.6 [10]. This policy area requires careful consideration of various factors, including tax laws and regulations.

### 3. **Provisions and contingent liabilities**
The estimate of ongoing legal disputes, litigation, and investigations is another area with a medium estimation risk, as noted in Note 3.6 [11]. This policy area demands a thorough assessment of potential liabilities and the likelihood of their occurrence.

**Restricted Share Units Vesting Conditions**

According to the provided quotes, the vesting conditions for Restricted Share Units (RSUs) over the first three years are as follows:

### First Full Year
The number of RSUs vesting at the end of the first year depends on meeting the Non-GAAP Operating Income (OI) criteria for the first year. If the Non-GAAP OI is more than 15% less than the set objective in the Annual Operating Plan (AOP), the RSUs do not vest. Otherwise, they vest.

### Second Full Year
Similarly, the number of RSUs vesting at the end of the second year depends on meeting the Non-GAAP OI criteria for the second year. If the Non-GAAP OI is more than 15% less than the set objective in the Annual Operating Plan (AOP), the RSUs do not vest. Otherwise, they vest.

### Third Full Year
The number of RSUs vesting at the end of the third year depends on meeting the Non-GAAP OI criteria for the third year. If the Non-GAAP OI is more than 15% less than the set objective in the Annual Operating Plan (AOP), the RSUs do not vest. Otherwise, they vest.

These conditions are outlined in the Performance-Vesting Restricted Share Unit Vesting Schedule, which is attached to the Award Terms.

![Performance-Vesting Restricted Share Unit Vesting Schedule](image3)

Here's a simple table summarizing the conditions for each year:

| Year | Non-GAAP OI Requirement | Vesting |
| --- | --- | --- |
| 1 | ≥ 85% of set objective | Vest if ≥ 85% |
| 2 | ≥ 85% of set objective | Vest if ≥ 85% |
| 3 | ≥ 85% of set objective | Vest if ≥ 85% |

The fair value of the RSUs is adjusted by the performance factor and rounded for each year.

While the table does not explicitly state what happens when the Non-GAAP OI is between 70% and 84% of the set objective, the schedule itself can guide users to infer that they do vest.

### Grants and Forfeitures
Grants and forfeitures are tracked separately, and the number of RSUs granted or forfeited can vary significantly with the performance of the specified market criteria.

![RSU Grants and Forfeitures](image5)

[2] In July 2015, the Financial Accounting Standards Board (“FASB”) issued an Accounting Standards Update (“ASU”) modifying the accounting for inventory. Under this ASU, the measurement principle for inventory changed from lower of cost or market value to lower of cost and net realizable value. The ASU defines net realizable value as the estimated selling price in the ordinary course of business, less reasonably predictable costs of completion, disposal, and transportation. The ASU is applicable to inventory that is accounted for under the first-in, first-out method. We adopted this ASU in Q1 2017 with no material impact to our consolidated financial statements. 
[3] Sales of Amazon Prime memberships are also considered arrangements with multiple deliverable s, including shipping benefits, Prime Video, Prime Music, Prime Photos, and access to the Kindle Owners’ Lending Library. The revenue related to the deliverable s is amortized over the life of the membership based on the estimated delivery of services. Amazon Prime membership fees are allocated between product sales and service sales. Costs to deliver Amazon Prime benefits are recognized as cost of sales as incurred. As we add more benefits to the Prime membership, we update the method of determining the estimated selling prices of each element as well as the allocation of Prime membership fees. 
[4] The preparation of financial statements in conformity with GAAP requires estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities, revenues and expenses, and related disclosures of contingent liabilities in the consolidated financial statements and accompanying notes. Estimates are used for, but not limited to, determining the selling price of products and services in multiple element revenue arrangements and determining the amortization period of these elements, incentive discount offers, sales returns, vendor funding, stock-based compensation forfeiture rates, income taxes, valuation and impairment of investments, inventory valuation and inventory purchase commitments, collect ability of receivable s, valuation of acquired intangibles and goodwill, de pre ci able lives of property and equipment, internal-use software and website development costs, acquisition purchase price allocations, investments in equity interests, and contingencies. Actual results could differ materially from those estimates. 
[5] Because of our model we are able to turn our inventory quickly and have a cash-generating operating cycle  3 . On average, our high inventory velocity means we generally collect from consumers before our payments to suppliers come due. We expect variability in inventory turnover over time since it is affected by numerous factors, including our product mix, the mix of sales by us and by third-party sellers, our continuing focus on in-stock inventory availability and selection of product offerings, our investment in new geographies and product lines, and the extent to which we choose to utilize third-party fulfillment providers. We also expect some variability in accounts payable days over time since they are affected by several factors, including the mix of product sales, the mix of sales by third-party sellers, the mix of suppliers, seasonality, and changes in payment terms over time, including the effect of balancing pricing and timing of payment terms with suppliers. 
[6] In May 2014, the FASB issued an ASU amending revenue recognition guidance and requiring more detailed disclosures to enable users of financial statements to understand the nature, amount, timing, and uncertainty of revenue and cash flows arising from contracts with customers. We will adopt this ASU on January 1, 2018 with a cumulative adjustment that will increase retained earnings by approximately   $\S650$   million rather than retrospectively adjusting prior periods. The cumulative adjustment will primarily relate to unredeemed gift cards. We will begin to recognize revenue from estimated unredeemed gift cards over the expected customer redemption period, which is substantially within nine months, rather than waiting until gift cards expire or when the likelihood of redemption becomes remote, generally two years from the date of issuance. Other changes relate to Amazon-branded electronic devices sold through retailers, which will be recognized upon sale to the retailer rather than to end customers. We also will change how we recognize and classify Amazon Prime memberships, which are currently considered arrangements with multiple deliverable s that are allocated among products sales and service sales. Upon adoption of the ASU, Amazon Prime memberships will be accounted for as a single performance obligation recognized ratably over the membership period and will be classified as service sales. Other changes that we have identified relate primarily to the presentation of revenue. Certain advertising services will be classified as revenue rather than a reduction in cost of sales, and sales of apps, in-app content, and certain digital media content will primarily be presented on a net basis.

According to the table of FY2017 financial summary in image4, Amazon's net sales were $118,573 million. The formula for DPO is: 
DPO = (Average accounts receivable * 365) / Average inventory. We can't calculate DPO from the information provided in the image 4. However, we can calculate the average accounts receivable and average inventory using the FY2017 financial summary in image4.
In FY2017, Amazon had total accounts receivable of $27,738 million and total inventory of $71,651 million. To calculate average accounts receivable and average inventory, we can use the following formulas:
Average accounts receivable = Total accounts receivable / 2 = $27,738 / 2 = $13,869 million
Average inventory = Total inventory / 2 = $71,651 / 2 = $35,825 million

Now we can calculate DPO:
DPO = (Average accounts receivable * 365) / Average inventory
DPO = ($13,869 * 365) / $35,825
DPO ≈ 151.31 days

```markdown
| Year | Total Net Periodic Benefit Cost (Benefit) |
| --- | --- |
| 2019 | $638 million |
| 2020 | $239 million |
| 2021 | $1,122 million |
| 2022 (Expected) | ($121) million |
```
According to **[9]**, the expected increase in the Total Net Periodic Benefit Cost (Benefit) in 2022 compared to 2021, excluding the impact of mark-to-market gains and losses, is $168 million. This increase is primarily due to changes in assumptions causing higher interest costs in 2022 due to higher discount rates at the end of 2021 and lower expected return on plan assets in 2022.

In contrast, **[4]** mentions that the primary factors that resulted in mark-to-market losses (gains) for 2021, 2020, and 2019 are described below, indicating that mark-to-market losses in 2021 were $833 million, while mark-to-market gains in 2020 were $383 million, and mark-to-market losses in 2019 were $468 million.

```markdown
| Year | Net Mark-to-Market Loss/Gain (Benefit) |
| --- | --- |
| 2019 | ($468) million (Loss) |
| 2020 | $383 million (Gain) |
| 2021 | ($833) million (Loss) |
```
The mark-to-market losses in 2021 and 2019 are primarily due to lower discount rates at the end of the respective years, as mentioned in **[6]** and **[7]**, while the mark-to-market gain in 2020 is partially offset by a higher actual return on plan assets compared to the expected return on plan assets.
```markdown
[6] z 2020 net mark-to-market loss of ($383) million – Primarily due to lower discount rates at the end of 2020 compared to the end of 2019.
[7] z 2019 net mark-to-market loss of ($468) million – Primarily due to lower discount rates at the end of 2019 compared to the end of 2018.
```
Overall, the Total Net Periodic Benefit Cost (Benefit) is expected to increase in 2022, primarily due to changes in assumptions, while mark-to-market losses in 2021 and 2019 are primarily due to lower discount rates at the end of the respective years.

According to [1] and [7], the Gross UTB Balance shows a significant increase over the three-year period. 

The Gross UTB Balance at January 1 of each year was:

Adding the amounts for tax positions related to the current year, additions for tax positions of prior years, reductions for tax positions of prior years, settlements, and reductions due to lapse of applicable statute of limitations, we get:
- 2018: $647 million

![Summary of Gross UTB Balance](image1)

The Gross UTB Balance increased from $319 million in 2017 to $647 million in 2018, a rise of $328 million. This indicates a trend of increasing Gross UTB Balance from 2016 to 2018.

### Related Effects
The increase in Gross UTB Balance can be attributed to various factors, including additions for tax positions related to the current year and prior years, as well as reductions due to lapse of applicable statute of limitations. These factors impacted the gross balance and resulted in an increase in the Gross UTB Balance.

### Conclusion
The Gross UTB Balance has shown a significant trend of increase from 2016 to 2018, reflecting the complexities of tax positions and the company's exposure to potential tax liabilities.

Investment stage distribution in European venture capital funds has undergone significant changes from the 1998 fund to the 2007 fund. The 1998 fund had a high proportion of Seed investments (78%) and Early Stage investments (18%), with only 4% in Mid-Stage investments, as shown in the 3D bar chart in image1. In contrast, the 2007 fund exhibited a notable decrease in Seed investments (10%) and an increase in Early Stage investments (74%), with only 16% in Mid-Stage investments. The new distribution highlights a shift in the market's focus, with Early Stage investments dominating the funding landscape in 2007.

This change can be seen in the 3D bar chart depicting the 1998 and 2007 funds in image3, which shows the funds' financial data in millions of euros. The chart displays a stark contrast between the two funds, with the 1998 fund containing €5.3 million and the 2007 fund containing €3.8 million.

The images further illustrate the evolution in investment stage distribution. The 3D bar chart in image2 compares the growth of three different funds over five years, with the 2007 fund noting a slower growth rate compared to the other two funds. The chart highlights a noticeable decrease in the proportion of Seed investments and an increase in Early Stage investments by 2007.

Overall, the distribution of investment stages in European venture capital funds has shifted from the 1998 fund to the 2007 fund, with Early Stage investments becoming a dominant force in the market. This change is evident in the investment stage distribution and growth rates of the funds, as illustrated in images 1, 2, 3, and 5.

**Does Latino registered voters align closely with the Democratic Party or show a moderate alignment? [4]**

According to a survey conducted in August 2022, the results of which are detailed in [4], Latino registered voters identify with or lean toward the Democratic Party over the Republican Party by a nearly two-to-one margin (64% vs. 33%). This nearly two-to-one margin indicates that Latino registered voters align closely with the Democratic Party.

**How does the alignment of Latino voters with the Democratic Party relate to their perceptions of differences between the parties? [7][8]**

Although the alignment of Latino voters with the Democratic Party suggests that they view the two parties differently, [7] survey results reveal that only a slight proportion (45%) of all Hispanics believe there is a "great deal of difference" between the two parties, while 36% believe there is a "fair amount of difference," and 16% believe there is hardly any difference at all. When broken down by political affiliation, [7] both Democrats and Republicans believe that there is a greater degree of difference between their respective parties.

Since the party affiliation among Latino voters shifted little over the past few years [8], the alignment of Latino voters with the Democratic Party suggests that their perceptions of differences between the parties are likely shaped by a combination of factors, including the varying priorities and values of the two parties.

Gender discrimination in STEM jobs is a significant issue affecting women more than men. According to a Pew Research Center survey, half of women in STEM jobs say they have experienced any form of gender-related discrimination at work, which is higher than the 41% of women in non-STEM jobs and the 19% of men in STEM occupations. [1] [3] [5]

The most common forms of gender discrimination experienced by women in STEM jobs include earning less than a man doing the same job, having someone treat them as if they are not competent because of their gender, experiencing repeated, small slights in their workplace, and receiving less support from senior leaders than a man who was doing the same job. [3] [6]

Women in STEM jobs working in majority-male workplaces are significantly more likely to experience gender-related discrimination and believe their gender has made it harder to succeed in their job compared to women in majority-female workplaces or those in workplaces with an even mix of men and women. [7] Most women in STEM jobs who work in majority-male workplaces, in computer jobs, or who have a postgraduate degree have experienced gender discrimination at work. [8]

On average, women working in STEM jobs are more likely to report experiences with and concerns about gender inequities in the workplace compared with men in these jobs. [10] Men in STEM jobs are more likely to say they have not experienced discrimination in the workplace, but they are less inclined than women to think that women are "usually treated fairly" when it comes to promotions. [9]

**Facilities of the Indian Space Programme located in Bengaluru**
====================================================================

Bengaluru serves as a major hub for the Indian Space Programme, hosting several key facilities that contribute to the country's space exploration and development efforts.

### Telemetry, Tracking and Command Network (ISTRAC)

*   The Indian Space Research Organisation's (ISRO) Telemetry, Tracking and Command Network (ISTRAC) facility is located in Bengaluru.
*   ISTRAC is responsible for providing tracking support for all satellite and launch vehicle missions of ISRO.
*   The facility's major objectives include estimating preliminary orbits of satellites, carrying out mission operations for operational remote sensing and scientific satellites, and operating the ground segment for the Indian Regional Navigation Satellite System.

[![![ISTRAC facility](image2)](image2)](image2)

### ISRO Satellite Centre (ISAC)

*   The ISRO Satellite Centre (ISAC) is the lead centre for designing, developing, fabricating, and testing all Indian-made satellites.
*   ISAC has developed cutting-edge technologies relevant to its satellite building activities and established infrastructure for design, development, fabrication, and testing of spacecraft.

[![![ISAC facility](image8)](image8)](image8)

### Liquid Propulsion Systems Centre (LPSC)

*   The Liquid Propulsion Systems Centre (LPSC) is a key facility located in Bengaluru.
*   LPSC is responsible for the design, development, and testing of liquid propulsion systems for launch vehicles and satellites.

[![![LPSC facility](image9)](image9)](image9)

### Mission Operations Complex (MOX)

*   The Mission Operations Complex (MOX) is a facility located in Bengaluru.
*   MOX is responsible for monitoring and controlling the operations of ISRO's satellites and launch vehicles.

[![![MOX facility](image10)](image10)](image10)

### Indian Institute of Space Science and Technology (IIST)

*   The Indian Institute of Space Science and Technology (IIST) is a deemed university established in Thiruvananthapuram.
*   IIST was set up to provide quality manpower to ISRO and has already placed 99 students of the 2011 batch as Scientists/Engineers at various ISRO centres.

[![![IIST facility](image11)](image11)](image11)

### ISRO Headquarters

*   The ISRO Headquarters is located in Bengaluru.
*   The headquarters coordinates various programs, including satellite communication and navigation, earth observation, launch vehicle, space science, disaster management support, and more.

[![![ISRO Headquarters facility](image7)](image7)](image7)

Hispanic Identity Fades Across Generations as Immigrant Connections Fall Away [1]

The generational breakdown of self-identified Hispanics and non-Hispanics reveals distinct differences in heritage identification. Among self-identified Hispanics, connections with ancestral national origins decline as immigrant roots become more distant. Eight-in-ten immigrants (82%) who identify as Hispanics say they feel very or somewhat connected to their country of origin. However, by the third generation, only 44% feel very or somewhat connected to their family's country of origin. This indicates that heritage identity is more pronounced among early generations of immigrants and declines as the generation progresses.

![Immigrant Generation Bar Chart](image1)

The composition of networks of friends also varies across immigrant generations. Most (77%) immigrant Latinos say all or most of their friends are Latinos. However, this share drops to 55% among second-generation self-identified Latinos and only 37% among third or higher generation self-identified Latinos. This suggests that heritage ties remain strong among younger generations, while older generations become more integrated into the broader community.

![Friendship Network Bar Chart](image2)

The preferred self-identification terms among self-identified Hispanics also provide insight into heritage identity. While 50% of self-identified Hispanics prefer their country of origin/heritage, 23% prefer the term "Hispanic/Latino," and 23% prefer "American." This indicates that heritage identity is complex and multifaceted, with individuals identifying with various labels depending on their personal connection to their heritage.

![Preferred Self-Identification Terms Bar Chart](image3)

Furthermore, the generational makeup of self-identified Hispanics and non-Hispanics reveals that heritage identity is more pronounced among early generations. Among self-identified Hispanics, 18% are foreign born, 29% are second generation, and 65% are third or higher generation. In contrast, among self-identified non-Hispanics, 96% are of the third or higher generation. This suggests that heritage identity is more pronounced among older generations and declines as the generation progresses.

![Generational Makeup Bar Graph](image4)

Finally, the chart comparing those who speak Spanish and those who have a Spanish last name provides additional insight into heritage identity. Among self-identified Hispanics, 71% do not speak Spanish, while 28% do. This indicates that heritage identity is not solely tied to language proficiency, but also to other aspects such as cultural heritage and surname.

![Spanish Language and Last Name Bar Chart](image5)

In conclusion, the generational breakdown of self-identified Hispanics and non-Hispanics reveals a complex and multifaceted picture of heritage identity. As immigrant roots become more distant, connections with ancestral national origins decline, and heritage identity becomes more pronounced among older generations. However, language proficiency and surname are not the sole determinants of heritage identity, and individuals may identify with various labels depending on their personal connection to their heritage.

In the early 1870s, Hamilton County experienced a population surge with approximately 130 citizens in 1870 and a rapid increase to 8,267 by 1880, with 14,096 residents in 1890 being the county's peak population to date. Unfortunately, Hamilton County’s population has slowly declined since that peak. The fluctuations in population have been attributed to historical factors, such as the Transcontinental Railroad Act and the Homestead Act, which dramatically transformed Nebraska's landscape and spurred westward expansion. The railroad brought much of the overland freight traffic under its control, while the Homestead Act provided pioneers with 160 acres of land if they constructed a permanent structure and resided on the land for five years. By 1900, nearly 69,000 people had acquired land in Nebraska under the Homestead Act, with a significant number of those who filed claims failing to secure title to the land. As a result, the county's population declined, and many rural school districts were consolidated, with only a handful remaining today.

While European VC-backed IPO performance matches or exceeds US performance, both pre- as well as post-IPO [1]. Active GPs Managing Funds of Vintage ≥2006, Investment Grade Funds [2]. A number of funds based in Europe have achieved US top quartile performance in post-bubble era [3]. 
![EU VC Funds in Top Quartile Comparison](image1) 
In the US, market publication requirements of endowments oblige most GPs to publish financial performance. In contrast, there are no such requirements in Europe, so many of the top-performing European funds are not publishing their financial data in the Thomson Venture database. Moreover, in Europe $85\%$ of EVCA listed funds have disappeared since the burst of the bubble, and only $10\%$ of the remaining funds are considered active, yet the bulk of European venture fund managers that are still listed are no longer active, resulting in a long non-contributing tail of European VC funds listed in the Thomson database [4]. 
The scarcity of VC money in Europe not only has led to low entry valuations but also has driven up capital efficiency (roughly 70 percent higher than in the US) and yield (hit rate) because the scarcity of money allows the very few investors to simply be more selective [5]. 
European venture capital is a cottage industry characterised by an insufficient number of private investors (e.g., lack of pension and endowment funds which account for roughly 65% of the US VC industry) with the capacity and willingness to invest in venture capital, mainly due to past disappointments and the resulting lack of confidence which still inhibits the European venture industry today [7]. 
![European VC Industry Lack of Confidence](image3) 
In addition to highly misleading published historical industry data for European VC which lead to a negative bias in official statistics, there is almost no reported performance of post-bubble vintages (which effectively started only 2004/2005) - these funds are significantly better performing and, as evidenced by recent exits across top-tier funds, are now at the inflection point [8].

When comparing opinions between 2008 and 2016 regarding political leaders working with the newly elected presidents, a notable difference emerged. In 2008, voters who supported Obama and McCain had similar views, with $52\%$ of Obama voters and $76\%$ of McCain voters favoring collaboration with Republicans, as depicted in [4]. This was reflected in a similar trend observed in 2012, with $56\%$ of Obama voters and $90\%$ of Romney backers desiring cooperation with Republicans, noted in [4]. Moreover, in 2008, as Obama was preparing to enter office, $78\%$ of his voters and $76\%$ of McCain's voters expressed the desire for Democratic leaders to work with Republicans, even if it meant disappointing their supporters, shown in [5].

However, this similarity in views between 2008 and 2016 vanished when comparing the opinions of voters who supported Trump and Clinton. A substantial partisan divide was observed, with more than eight-in-ten Trump voters $(83\%)$  saying Democratic leaders should work with  Trump to get things done even if it means  disappointing their supporters, while only $35\%$  of Clinton voters held this view, stated in [1]. Conversely, nearly two-thirds of Clinton voters $(63\%)$   believed that Democrats should stand up to Trump on issues that are important to Democrats even if  it means less gets done in Washington, as noted in [2].

Another key distinction between the two years lies in the views of those who voted for the losing candidate in each election. In 2008, $58\%$ of McCain voters expressed the desire for Republican leaders to try their best to work with Obama, whereas, in 2016, $14\%$ of Trump voters wanted their party’s leaders to cooperate with Obama, observed in [8]. This contrasted with the feelings among those who voted for the losing candidate in 2008, when $59\%$ of Republicans or those leaning Republican preferred working with Obama, while $36\%$ wanted to "stand up" to the new president, as seen in [9].

In addition, there was a significant shift in the views of Democratic voters between 2008 and 2016. In the former year, $49\%$ of all Democratic and Democratic-leaning voters believed the party’s leaders should move in a more liberal direction, whereas $47\%$ favored a more moderate approach, reported in [10].

**Comparing Opinions on National Defense Spending in the U.S. and Germany**
====================================================================================

According to the Pew Research Center and Körber-Stiftung surveys conducted in 2017, 2018, and 2019, the opinions of Americans and Germans on national defense spending exhibit some interesting trends.

### Shifts in Opinions

The chart shown in image 5 provides a visual representation of the changing opinions in both countries over the three-year period. 

In the U.S., Americans' opinions on whether European allies should increase, keep the same, or decrease spending on national defense have shifted as follows:

*   In 2017, 45% of Americans supported an increase, 37% favored keeping it the same, and 9% supported a decrease.
*   In 2018, 39% supported an increase, 46% favored keeping it the same, and 11% supported a decrease.
*   In 2019, 35% supported an increase, 50% favored keeping it the same, and 9% supported a decrease.

In contrast, Germans' opinions on whether Germany should increase, keep the same, or decrease spending on national defense have also shifted:

*   In 2017, 32% of Germans supported an increase, 51% favored keeping it the same, and 13% supported a decrease.
*   In 2018, 43% supported an increase, 40% favored keeping it the same, and 14% supported a decrease.
*   In 2019, 40% supported an increase, 41% favored keeping it the same, and 15% supported a decrease.

These shifts in opinions suggest that both Americans and Germans have become less supportive of increasing national defense spending for European allies over the three-year period.

### Conclusion

The data suggests that while opinions on national defense spending have changed in both countries, the overall trend is a decrease in support for increasing spending. This is a notable shift in view from 2017, when a larger proportion of Americans and Germans favored increased spending.

*   In the U.S., the shift from 2017 to 2019 is notable, with 9 percentage points less support for increasing spending.
*   In Germany, the shift from 2017 to 2019 is also notable, with 11 percentage points less support for increasing spending.

These findings highlight the evolving attitudes of Americans and Germans towards national defense spending, emphasizing the need for continued monitoring and analysis of public opinion on this critical issue.

While comparing public concerns about terrorism and economic issues from December 2014 to December 2015, we can see significant shifts. From [4], it is stated that the share of Americans who say the government is doing well in reducing the threat of terrorism fell by 26 percentage points – from 72% to 46% – and now stands at its lowest point in the post-9/11 era. This indicates a decrease in public trust and confidence in the government's ability to handle terrorism effectively. Furthermore, [6] indicates that comparable percentages said they were very concerned about the rise of Islamic extremism in September of last year, with these being among the highest levels of concerns measured in the questions’ trend dating to 2007.

Concerns over terrorism saw a substantial increase from December 2014 to December 2015. As mentioned in [2], currently, 29% cite terrorism, national security, or ISIS as the most important problem facing the country today, with these issues garnering a much higher percentage of mentions than in December 2014. A year ago, just 4% of the public cited any of these issues, highlighting a significant rise in public concern over terrorism. It is also worth noting that [8] mentions that the share citing terrorism is the highest it has been since February 2003, indicating a renewed focus on terrorism as a major concern.

Regarding economic issues, [4] shows that the percentage of Americans mentioning economic issues decreased from 34% to 23% over the year. This represents a decrease of 11 percentage points, indicating a decline in public concern over economic issues. However, it is essential to note that economic issues were still a prominent concern in December 2014, with 34% of the public mentioning them, highlighting a significant drop in concern over economic issues compared to other issues.

![Graph illustrating the decrease in government's ability to reduce terrorism threat](image4)

![Graph illustrating the decrease in government's ability to reduce terrorism threat](image4)

 Overall, public concerns about terrorism increased significantly from December 2014 to December 2015, while concerns over economic issues decreased. These shifts indicate that terrorism has become a more pressing concern for the American public, while economic issues have fallen down the priority list.

Blacks in STEM jobs tend to report experiences of workplace discrimination due to race more than blacks in non-STEM jobs ($\cdot62\%$ vs. $\cdot50\%$) [1]. Among blacks in STEM jobs, $72\%$ say discrimination in recruitment, hiring, and promotions is a major reason behind the underrepresentation of blacks and Hispanics in these jobs [4]. In contrast, only around a quarter of whites (27%) and Asians (28%) say this [4]. Hispanics, however, think discrimination is a major reason behind the underrepresentation at a rate of $43\%$ [4]. Blacks working in STEM jobs are also less convinced than white STEM workers that black employees where they work are treated fairly when it comes to hiring and promotions [5]. On the other hand, $43\%$ of blacks in STEM jobs believe that blacks where they work are usually treated fairly during recruitment [5], whereas $37\%$ say this is the case during promotion and advancement opportunities [5]. Most white STEM workers believe that blacks are usually treated fairly in these processes where they work (78% say this about hiring, 75% about advancement processes) [5]. Hence, perceived racial/ethnic disparities in the workplace among those in STEM professions are highlighted through various indicators including discrimination experiences, fairness perceptions, and role of racial/ethnic discrimination in underrepresentation.

In various scenarios for Caltrain service improvement, the peak hour train car requirement varies as follows:

The current peak hour requirement for Caltrain is 5 car trains, 5 trains per hour, which equals 25 train cars. If Caltrain were to use Metrolink's used cars, the peak hour requirement would increase to 30 train cars, with a peak service of 6x5. Electrification of the trains could increase the peak hour requirement to 36 train cars, with a peak service of 6x6. Furthermore, extending platforms to accommodate more cars could increase the peak hour requirement to 48 train cars, with a peak service of 6x8. Finally, increasing frequency, potentially with High-Speed Rail (HSR), could necessitate 64 train cars during peak hours, with a peak service of 8x8.

By contrast, nearly half of Republicans $(46\%)$ hold the opposing view that the statement does not describe their views well. Among Hispanic independents and those who are not partisans, ${\it29\%}$ of those who lean Democratic say Democrats work hard to win Latinos’ votes, while $41\%$ who lean Republican say the statement does not describe their view well.
 
[4] Meanwhile, more than half of Hispanic Republicans and Republican leaners $(56\%)$ say “the Democratic Party works hard to earn Latinos’ votes” describes their views at least somewhat well, while about a third of Hispanic Democrats and Democratic leaners $\left(35\%\right)$ say “the Republican Party works hard to earn Latinos’ votes” describes their views at least somewhat well.
 
[5] Certain groups of Latinos are especially likely to say the statement “Democrats work hard to earn Latinos’ votes” describes their views very or extremely well. Among Latinos, similar shares of immigrants $(44\%)$, Spanish-dominant Latinos $(48\%)$, Catholics $\left(42\%\right)$, and evangelical Protestants $(42\%)$ say this. The shares of Latinos ages 50 to $64\left(45\%\right)$ and ages 65 or older $(46\%)$ who say the same are also similar.
 
[7] Relatively few Latinos say Republicans try hard to earn their vote. About one-in-five Latinos $\left(19\%\right)$ say the statement “Republicans work hard to earn Latinos’ votes” describes their views very or extremely well. Among Latino Republicans, $40\%$ say the statement describes their views well, compared with only $13\%$ of Latino Democrats. Among independents and those who do not identify as partisans, $13\%$ who lean Democratic say the statement describes their views well. Republican-leaning independents have distinct views from Republican-leaning Democrats.
 
**Answer:** 
Latino Republicans and Democrats have a significant difference in their views on whether 'Republicans work hard to earn Latinos' votes. A substantial share of Latino Republicans (40%) say Republicans work hard to earn Latinos' votes, while a majority of Latino Democrats (51%) say the Democratic Party works hard to earn Latinos' votes.

More say press had 'too much' influence on outcome of the election  [1]. Yet, in 2000, only 53% of voters thought that news organizations had too much influence on the outcome of the election, indicating a slight decrease in this perception over time.

![The image is a vertical bar chart displaying a survey over several years (1992, 1996, 2000, 2004, 2008, 2012, and 2016). It shows three categories for each year: "Too much," "About the right amount," and "Too little."](image1)

In 2004, 43% of voters believed that news organizations had too much influence, but this perception increased to 57% in 2016, the highest it has been since 2000. The share of those saying the press had about the right amount of influence is the lowest in Pew Research Center polling going back to 1992. 

![The image is a bar chart showing people's perceptions of voting accuracy in two different contexts: their own vote and votes across the country, for the years 2004, 2008, 2012, and 2016. The chart is divided into four categories of confidence: "Very," "Somewhat," "Not too," and "Not at all."](image2)

A 2016 Pew Research Center survey found that 57% of voters said news organizations had too much influence on the outcome of the presidential election, while 13% said the press had too little influence, and 27% said the press had the right amount of influence.

![The image contains bar charts showing survey results regarding voters' confidence in the accuracy of vote counting in the U.S. elections of 2016. There are two main sections in the image, each dealing with different aspects of voting confidence.](image3)

About six-in-ten Trump voters (62%) say the press had too much influence, as do 50% of Clinton voters. A similar number of Romney (69%) and McCain (77%) voters said the press had too much influence following their election losses.

![The image is a bar chart depicting voting trends for the Republican and Democratic candidates in four U.S. presidential elections: November 2004, November 2008, November 2012, and November 2016.](image5)

In summary, the perception that news organizations had 'too much' influence on presidential elections has increased over time, with a significant spike in 2016. This trend suggests a growing sense of mistrust among voters towards the media's role in shaping the election narrative.

According to [1], among self-identified Latinos, the foreign-born and the second generation are most likely to say that all or most of their neighbors share their heritage. Some $41\%$ of both groups say this. The share that lives in largely Latino neighborhoods falls to $30\%$ among third or higher generation self-identified Latinos. This indicates that generational differences among self-identified Hispanics do indeed affect the likelihood of having Hispanic friends, with foreign-born and second-generation Hispanics being more likely to report having Hispanic neighbors.

![The percentage of self-identified second-generation Hispanics who say that all or most of their friends are Latinos, showing a 55% share.](![image2](image2))
In the image2, which charts the percentage of self-identified Hispanics who believe all or most people in America share similar views, it can be seen that self-identified second-generation Latinos have a 55% share. Similarly, when looking at the chart in image3, self-identified second-generation Hispanics have a 56% share of saying that being Hispanic has not made a difference in their lives. These suggest that second-generation Hispanics are less likely to have Hispanic friends.

As stated in [2], among self-identified non-Hispanics with Hispanic ancestry, $16\%$ say all or most of their friends are Hispanic. This indicates that even among those who identify as Hispanic but were not born in the US, they are not as likely to have Hispanic friends as foreign-born and second-generation Hispanics.

In [3], it is mentioned that connections with ancestral national origins decline as immigrant roots become more distant. Specifically, among self-identified Hispanics, connections with their country of origin decline from $82\%$ for immigrants to $44\%$ for third or higher generation self-identified Hispanics. This suggests that third or higher generation Hispanics may be less likely to have strong ties to their Hispanic heritage, which in turn may affect their likelihood of having Hispanic friends.

Overall, the data suggests that generational differences among self-identified Hispanics can indeed affect the likelihood of having Hispanic friends, with foreign-born and second-generation Hispanics being more likely to report having Hispanic neighbors and friends.

Even though most downzoned lots were located near transit stations, the overall impact of the rezonings we studied appears consistent with the City’s stated goal, because the upzonings near transit added much more capacity than the down zoning s near rail stations took away. Specifically, upzoned lots near transit gained about 181 million square feet of residential capacity and downzoned lots near transit lost only about 89 million square feet of capacity. As a result, rezoned lots near transit accounted for a vast majority of the citywide net increase in capacity. Furthermore, of the capacity added to upzoned lots further away from rail stations, a large portion was in the proposed Hudson Yards project area in Manhattan, where an extension of the 7 line subway is currently underway. If we exclude the Hudson Yards rezoning, the rezonings we studied actually resulted in a small net decrease in residential development capacity in areas further away from rail stations, consistent with the City’s goals. 

According to Table A: Residential Development Capacity and the Impact of Rezonings, by Borough (2003–2007), the Bronx accounted for 18.4% of the City's total land area that was rezoned from 2003-2007.

**Among older adults, physical health conditions play a significant role in technology use.**  
![A bar chart comparing the percentage of older adults with physical or health conditions that make tech use challenging vs. all adults](image1)  
[1] According to data from the Pew Research Center, around 23% of older adults (65+) indicate that they have a "physical or health condition that makes reading difficult or challenging," while 16% of all adults share the same issue. This difference in prevalence highlights the impact of physical health conditions on technology use among older adults.  
![A line graph illustrating the percentage of people in different age groups using some form of technology or service over time](image4)  
[2] Interestingly, the trend suggests that the 65+ age group showed the lowest usage initially but climbed consistently to 46% by 2013. This indicates that older adults are more likely to face physical challenges that hinder technology use.  
![A table showing data for a group of people aged 65 and older, segmented by demographic factors](image5)  
[3] The table data indicates that 29% of older adults with a disability, handicap, or chronic disease that prevents them from fully participating in many common daily activities also own a cell phone, which is lower than the 69% of older adults without such conditions. This suggests that physical health conditions can affect the adoption of digital devices among older adults.  
![A bar chart comparing the percentage of internet users and non-users who strongly agree with a statement](image3)  
[4] Moreover, differences in technology adoption between these "physically challenged" seniors and the rest of the older adult population are somewhat more modest when it comes to tablets and e-book readers. Some 22% of seniors with a life-impacting disability or chronic disease, or a physical condition that makes reading difficult, own either a tablet computer or an e-book reader, which is lower than the 69% of older adults without such conditions.  
[5] These findings suggest that physical health conditions can have a significant impact on technology use among older adults, with around 23% of older adults indicating that they have a "physical or health condition that makes reading difficult or challenging." This prevalence is higher than the 16% of all adults who share the same issue, highlighting the need for accommodations and support to increase technology adoption among older adults with physical health conditions.

The population of Hamilton County experienced a significant surge in the late 1800s, with the population increasing from 130 in 1870 to 8,267 in 1880, and peaking at 14,096 in 1890. Although the population began to decline after that peak, it continued to grow until the early 20th century. 
![Image description: The table shows population data for various census years.] ([3])
Since then, the population has slowly declined, with some towns experiencing recent population gains. For example, Aurora peaked in population at the most recent census in 2000 with 4,225 citizens and has steadily increased since 1940. However, as farm consolidation continues, it is likely that Hamilton County's towns, outside of Aurora, will struggle to maintain their current populations. 
![Image description: The image shows a monument with the inscription "Chaffee" on it.] ([4])
According to the U.S. Census Bureau, the population of Hamilton County continued to grow until the early 20th century, with a peak population of 14,096 in 1890. By 1900, the population had declined to 13,330, and continued to decline until 1920, when it reached 13,237. The population continued to decline until 1940, when it reached 9,982. However, in the following years, the population began to increase, with a peak of 9,403 in 2000. 
![Image description: The table shows population data for various census years.] ([5])
![Image description: The image shows a church building with a tall steeple and a cross on top.] ([6])
![Image description: The table shows population data for various census years.] ([7])
According to historical records, the introduction of center-pivot irrigation systems in the early 1970s led to a rapid conversion of rangeland to cropland in Hamilton County. By the late 1970s, approximately 89 percent of the county's area was cropland, with 81 percent of that being irrigated and 19 percent being dryfarmed. 
![Image description: The image shows a monument with the inscription "Chaffee" on it.] ([8])
This significant increase in agricultural production led to an influx of settlers and the establishment of new towns, such as Hamilton, which briefly campaigned for the county seat. However, the county seat was eventually moved to Aurora, leading to the decline of many of the smaller towns in the area.

**The stark reality of racial disparities in the STEM workforce**

There is widespread support among Americans, including those in STEM and non-STEM jobs, for the ideals of racial and ethnic diversity in the workplace. However, blacks in STEM jobs experience discrimination, with 62% reporting that they have experienced discrimination at work because of their race or ethnicity, compared to 44% of Asians, 42% of Hispanics, and just 13% of whites in STEM jobs.

[4] Concerns about the underrepresentation of blacks and other racial minorities – and particularly women of color – in the STEM workforce have been ongoing for at least four decades. [5] About six-in-ten blacks working in STEM say they have experienced workplace discrimination because of their race.

These disparities in experience are not limited to men; women in STEM jobs, particularly black women, face similar challenges. The Pew Research Center survey finds that 50% of black women in STEM say they have experienced discrimination at work, compared to 37% of black women in non-STEM jobs. Meanwhile, 31% of women in STEM jobs, and 19% of women in non-STEM jobs, say they have experienced difficulty succeeding due to their gender.

**Perception of fairness in hiring and promotion processes**

Blacks in STEM jobs are less convinced than white STEM workers that black employees where they work are treated fairly when it comes to hiring and promotions. In all, 43% of blacks in STEM jobs believe that blacks where they work are usually treated fairly during recruitment; 37% say this is the case during promotion and advancement opportunities. By contrast, most white STEM workers believe that blacks are usually treated fairly in these processes, with 78% saying this about hiring, and 75% saying this about advancement processes.

In contrast, whites in STEM jobs perceive a significant disparity in fairness, with 15% of whites in STEM jobs believing their workplace pays too little attention to increasing diversity. In contrast, 57% of blacks in STEM jobs feel their workplace pays insufficient attention to diversity issues.

**Image 4 illustrates these disparities**

[![The chart uses this information to highlight the gender disparities faced by men and women in computer-related jobs](image4)](image4)

In this regard, blacks working in STEM jobs share common ground with Asians and, to a lesser degree, Hispanics who are all much less likely than whites in such jobs to believe that members of their own racial or ethnic group are usually treated fairly, particularly when it comes to opportunities for promotion and advancement.

[8] Most blacks in STEM have experienced discrimination; fewer blacks see fair treatment in hiring, promotions.

The stark reality of racial disparities in the STEM workforce is a pressing issue that requires attention and action.

Results on SemEval 17 Table  4  compares the results of our model with the state of the art on the SemEval 17 dataset for tasks of span identiﬁcation, keyphrase extraction and relation extraction as well as the overall score. Span identiﬁcation aims at identifying spans of entities. Keyphrase classiﬁ- cation and relation extraction has the same setting with the entity and relation extraction in S CI ERC. Our model outperforms all the previous models that use hand-designed features. We observe more signiﬁcant improvement in span identiﬁcation than keyphrase classiﬁcation. This conﬁrms the bene- ﬁt of our model in enumerating spans (rather than BIO tagging in state-of-the-art systems). More- over, we have competitive results compared to the previous state of the art in relation extraction. We observe less gain compared to the S CI ERC dataset mainly because there are no coference links, and the relation types are not comprehensive. [1]
In the SemEval task, we compare our model S CI IE with the best reported system in the SemEval leaderboard ( Peters et al.,  2017 ), which extends E2E Rel with several in-domain features such as gazetteers extracted from existing knowledge bases and model ensembles. We also compare with the state of the art on keyphrase extraction ( Luan et al., 2017b ), which applies semi-supervised methods to a neural tagging model. [6]
S CI IE outperforms all the baselines. For entity recognition, our model achieves   $1.3\%$   and   $2.4\%$  relative improvement over   $\tt L S T M+C R F$   with and without ELM O, respectively. Moreover, it achieves  $1.8\%$   and  $2.7\%$   relative improvement over E2E Rel with and without ELM O, respectively. For rela- tion extraction, we observe more signiﬁcant im- provement with   $13.1\%$   relative improvement over E2E Rel and  $7.4\%$   improvement over E2E Rel with ELM O. For coreference resolution, S CI IE outper- forms E2E Coref with  $4.5\%$   relative improvement. We still observe a large gap between human-level performance and a machine learning system. We invite the community to address this challenging task. [5]

Note that our model achieves highest F1 score of 58.6 in span identification from [1] and 64.2 in test set span identification from [3].

Error Analysis of Step-Back Prompting on TimeQA
====================================================

Step-Back Prompting is a technique used to improve the performance of large language models (LLMs) on knowledge-based tasks such as TimeQA. The analysis reveals that the main error types identified in Step-Back Prompting on TimeQA are:

### Errors Introduced by Step-Back

*   **Reasoning Error**: 45% of errors are due to failure in retrieving the right information despite the abstraction provided by step-back makes it a much easier task. This suggests that the model struggles with complex reasoning tasks.
*   **Math Error**: 25% of errors are due to math-related mistakes, indicating that the model needs improvement in mathematical skills.
*   **Context Loss**: 7% of errors are due to context loss, which may be caused by the model's inability to properly understand the context of the question.
*   **Principle Error**: 9% of errors are due to principle errors, which are errors caused by the failure of the abstraction step.

### Comparison with Baseline

The analysis also shows that Step-Back Prompting significantly improves the performance of the model on TimeQA. The model is able to turn 39.9% of wrong predictions into correct predictions, while causing 5.6% errors.

![Error Analysis of Step-Back Prompting on TimeQA](image5)

Among the three correction strategies: training-time correction, generation-time correction, and post-hoc correction, **training-time correction** has the most representative papers in the survey.

This is evident from the quotes provided in the text, where training-time correction is mentioned as a crucial aspect of model refinement, with specific strategies such as Direct Optimizing Human Feedback, Reward Modeling and Reinforcement Learning from Human Feedback (RLHF), and Self-Training being discussed extensively.

Figure 4 in the text categorizes the key post-hoc correction strategies into Self-Correction, Correction with External Feedback, and Multi-Agent Debate, but there is no similar categorization for training-time correction.

Figure 2 in the text illustrates three typical strategies for training-time correction, each utilizing different forms of feedback to optimize the model during training.

Moreover, Figures 2 and 4 both depict post-hoc correction strategies, while only Figure 3 illustrates the two typical strategies of generation-time correction: Generate-then-Rank and Feedback-Guided Decoding.

Therefore, based on the quotes and the visual representations provided, training-time correction appears to have the most representative papers in the survey.
