[2] Main Results.  The main results are shown in Ta- ble  3. We can clearly ﬁnd that the proposed GCAN signiﬁcantly outperforms the best competing meth- ods over all metrics across two datasets, improving the performance by around   $17\%$   and   $15\%$   on aver- age in Twitter15 and Twitter16, respectively. Even without the proposed graph-aware representation, GCAN-G can improve the best competing method by   $14\%$   and  $3\%$   on average in Twitter15 and Twit- ter16, respectively. Such promising results prove the effectiveness of GCAN for fake news detec- tion. The results also imply three insights. First, GCAN is better than GCAN-G by   $3.5\%$   and   $13\%$  improvement in Twitter15 and Twitter16, respec- tively. This exhibits the usefulness of graph-aware representation. Second, the dual co-attention mech- anism in GCAN is quite powerful, as it clearly out- performs the best non-co-attention state-of-the-art model CSI. Third, while both GCAN-G and dE- FEND are co-attention-based, additional sequential features learned from the retweet user sequence in GCAN-G can signiﬁcantly boost the performance. [3]
[4] Data.  Two well-known datasets compiled by  Ma et al.  ( 2017 ), Twitter15 and Twitter16, are uti- lized. Each dataset contains a collection of source tweets, along with their corresponding sequences of retweet users. We choose only “true” and “fake” labels as the ground truth. Since the original data does not contain user proﬁles, we use user IDs to crawl user information via Twitter API. [5]
[6] Explainability on Retweet Propagation.  We aim to exploit the retweet order in propagations to unfold the behavior difference between fake and real news. We randomly pick three fake (F1-F3) and three true (T1-T3) source stories, and plot their weights from source-propagation co-attention (Sec- tion  4.5 ), as exhibited in Figure  6, in which the horizontal direction from left to right denotes the order of retweet. The results show that to determine whether a story is fake, one should ﬁrst examine the characteristics of users who  early  retweet the source story. The evidences of fake news in terms of user characteristics may be evenly distributed in the propagation. [7]
[7] This paper deals with fake news detection un- der a more realistic scenario on social media. We predict whether a source tweet story is fake, given only its  short text  content and its  retweet sequence of users, along with  user proﬁles. That said, we detect fake news under three settings: (a) short-text source tweet, (b) no text of user comments, and (c) no network structures of social network and diffu- sion network. Moreover, we require the fake news detection model to be capable of  explainability, i.e., highlighting the evidence when determining a story is fake. The model is expected to point out the suspicious retweeters who support the spreading of fake news, and highlight the words they especially pay attention to from the source tweet. [8] Competing Methods.  We compare our GCAN with the state-of-the-art methods and some base- lines, as listed below. (1)  DTC  ( Castillo et al., 2011 ): a decision tree-based model combining user proﬁles and the source tweet. (2)  SVM-TS  ( Ma et al.,  2015 ): a linear support vector machine classi- ﬁer that utilizes the source tweet and the sequence of retweet users’ proﬁles. (3)  mGRU  ( Ma et al., 2016 ): a modiﬁed gated recurrent unit model for rumor detection, which learns temporal patterns from retweet user proﬁle, along with the source’s features. (4)  RFC  ( Kwon et al.,  2017 ): an ex- tended random forest model combining features from retweet user proﬁles and the source tweet. (5) CSI  ( Ruchansky et al.,  2017 ): a state-of-the-art fake news detection model incorporating articles, and the group behavior of users who propagate fake news by using LSTM and calculating the user scores. (6)  tCNN  ( Yang et al.,  2018 ): a modi- ﬁed convolution neural network that learns the lo- cal variations of user proﬁle sequence, combining with the source tweet features. (7)  CRNN  ( Liu and Wu,  2018 ): a state-of-the-art joint CNN and RNN model that learns local and global varia- tions of retweet user proﬁles, together with the resource tweet. (8)  dEFEND  ( Shu et al.,  2019a ): a state-of-the-art co-attention-based fake news detec- tion model that learns the correlation between the source article’s sentences and user proﬁles. [9] This paper solves the fake news detection prob- lem under a more realistic scenario on so- cial media. Given the source short-text tweet and the corresponding sequence of retweet users without text comments, we aim at pre- dicting whether the source tweet is fake or not, and generating explanation by highlight- ing the evidences on suspicious retweeters and the words they concern. We develop a novel neural network-based model, Graph-aware Co- Attention Networks (GCAN), to achieve the goal. Extensive experiments conducted on real tweet datasets exhibit that GCAN can signiﬁ- cantly outperform state-of-the-art methods by  $16\%$   in accuracy on average. In addition, the case studies also show that GCAN can produce reasonable explanations. [10] Early Detection.  We further report the perfor- mance (in only Accuracy due to page limit) by varying the number of observed retweet users per source story (from  10  to  50 ), as exhibited in Fig- ure  2  and Figure  3. It can be apparently found that our GCAN consistently and signiﬁcantly outper- forms the competitors. Even with only ten retweet- ers, GCAN can still achieve   $90\%$   accuracy. Such results tell GCAN is able to generate accurate early detection of the spreading fake news, which is cru- [5]

The filtering process for collecting images in the entity dataset involves several steps. First, a comprehensive list of entities encompassing 22 primary categories is compiled, totaling 14,910 diverse entities. The entity list is then filtered by cross-referencing each entry with its corresponding Wikipedia page. Entities lacking valid Wikipedia pages are subsequently removed from the list [1].

Next, images are sourced from Creative Commons (CC). Further filtering is conducted by removing entities that don’t have a sufficient number of images obtained via Google Image Search engine [1]. The collected metadata is stored in a CSV file containing essential information such as image URLs, source page URLs, renamed image names, and the corresponding Wikipedia page URLs.

After filtering, the final number of entities in the SnapNTell dataset is 7,568 [1].

Figure 3 is described as follows:
The image illustrates three types of retrieval augmentation processes for a Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) system:
1. **Iterative Retrieval (Left):**
   - Alternates between retrieval and generation.
   - Aims to provide richer and more targeted context from the knowledge base at each step.
   - Iterates a specified number of times or until a threshold is met.
   - Process: Query → Retrieve → Generate → Judge → (Repeat or Response).
2. **Recursive Retrieval (Middle):**
   - Gradually refines the user query and divides problems into sub-problems.
   - Continuously solves complex problems through retrieval and generation.
   - Utilizes query transformation/decomposition.
   - Process: Query → Retrieve → Generate → Judge → Query Transformation → (Repeat or Response).
3. **Adaptive Retrieval (Right):**
   - Enables the RAG system to decide when external knowledge retrieval is needed.
   - Can autonomously determine when to stop retrieval and generation, using special tokens.
   - Process: Query → Judge → Retrieve (on demand) → Generate → Query Transformation → Judge → (Repeat or Response).

These images focuses on enhancing the retrieval and generation tasks differently to improve the system’s performance and flexibility.

The distribution of informal and formal entries across different domains in Yahoo Answers is an essential aspect of understanding the GYAFC dataset. The dataset consists of a total of 40 million entries, with 24 million being informal and 16 million being formal. The domains of Entertainment & Music (E&M) and Family & Relationships (F&R) contain the most informal sentences.

**Distribution of Informal and Formal Entries Across Domains:**

| Domain    | Total     | Informal | Formal    |
|-----------|-----------|----------|-----------|
| All Yahoo Answers | 40M      | 24M      | 16M       |
| E&M        | 3.8M      | 2.7M     | 0.7M      |
| F&R        | 7.8M      | 5.6M     | 1.8M      |

As illustrated in Table 4, the F&R domain contains the most informal sentences, with 5.6 million entries. In contrast, the E&M domain has 2.7 million informal entries. The formal entries are relatively balanced across both domains, with the E&M domain having 0.7 million formal entries and the F&R domain having 1.8 million formal entries.

Furthermore, the distribution of informal and formal entries in E&M and F&R domains is as follows:

- In the E&M domain, 52,595 instances are available for training, 2,877 for tuning, and 1,416 for testing in the Informal to Formal transformation task. 
- In the F&R domain, 51,967 instances are available for training, 2,788 for tuning, and 1,332 for testing in the Informal to Formal transformation task.

These statistics demonstrate the uneven distribution of informal and formal entries across different domains in Yahoo Answers, which can impact the performance of formality style transfer models.

**Distribution of Gendered Instances Across Winogender, WinoBias, and WinoMT**
===========================================================

The distribution of gendered instances across the Winogender, WinoBias, and WinoMT datasets reveals an imbalance in the representation of male, female, and neutral instances.

According to the data presented in Figure 1, the Winogender dataset consists of 240 instances each for male, female, and neutral genders, with a total of 720 instances.

In contrast, the WinoBias dataset has a significantly higher number of instances, with 1582 male, 1586 female, and 0 neutral instances, totaling 3168 instances.

The WinoMT dataset, which combines the Winogender and WinoBias datasets, has a more balanced representation of male, female, and neutral instances, with 1826 male, 1822 female, and 240 neutral instances, totaling 3888 instances.

```markdown
| Dataset          | Male | Female | Neutral | Total |
|------------------|------|--------|---------|-------|
| Winogender       | 240  | 240    | 240     | 720   |
| WinoBias         | 1582 | 1586   | 0       | 3168  |
| WinoMT           | 1826 | 1822   | 240     | 3888  |
```

These observations suggest that the WinoBias dataset has a notable imbalance in its representation of gendered instances, with a significant majority of instances belonging to female gender.

The WinoMT dataset, which combines the Winogender and WinoBias datasets, exhibits a more balanced representation of male, female, and neutral instances, which is a desirable characteristic for evaluating gender bias in machine translation.

The faithfulness aspect in RAG models is evaluated using various metrics, including:

The table appears to categorize different evaluation metrics or criteria (listed in the first column) based on which aspects they assess (represented by the column headers from the second to the last column). Each checkmark (✓) indicates that the corresponding metric evaluates or is relevant to the corresponding aspect.

* Faithfulness is assessed by Accuracy, EM, BLEU, and ROUGE/ROUGE-L.

For a better understanding, let's look at each of these metrics individually.

*   **Accuracy**: Measures the proportion of correct predictions made by the model.
*   **EM (Exact Match)**: Evaluates the exact match between the generated answer and the target answer.
*   **BLEU (Bilingual Evaluation Understudy)**: Assess the similarity between the generated answer and the target answer in terms of n-gram precision.
*   **ROUGE (Recall-Oriented Understudy for Gisting Evaluation)**: Measures the similarity between the generated answer and the target answer in terms of n-gram recall.

These metrics collectively provide a comprehensive evaluation of the faithfulness aspect in RAG models.

To address specific data scenarios, recursive retrieval and multi-hop retrieval techniques are utilized together. Recursive retrieval involves a structured index to process and retrieve data in a hierarchical manner, which may include summarizing sections of a document or lengthy PDF before performing a retrieval based on this summary. Subsequently, a secondary retrieval within the document refines the search, embodying the recursive nature of the process. In contrast, multi-hop retrieval is designed to delve deeper into graph-structured data sources, extracting interconnected information [106].

To address the question of how the collapsed tree and tree traversal querying methods compare in terms of F1 score across different context lengths, let's break down the findings from the provided text and image quotes.

### The Text

[6] We tested both approaches on 20 stories from the QASPER dataset. Figure 3 shows the performance of tree traversal with different top-sizes and collapsed tree with different maximum token numbers. The collapsed tree approach consistently performs better. We believe collapsed tree retrieval is better due to offering greater flexibility than tree traversal; i.e., by searching through all the nodes simultaneously, it retrieves information that is at the correct level of granularity for a given question.

[3] One drawback, however, of the collapsed tree approach is that it requires cosine similarity search to be performed on all nodes in the tree. However, this can be made more efficient with fast $k$-nearest neighbor libraries such as FAISS (Johnson et al., 2019).

[9] The tree traversal method first selects the top-k most relevant root nodes based on their cosine similarity to the query embedding. The children of these selected nodes are considered at the next layer and the top $\cdot\mathrm{k}$ nodes are selected from this pool again based on their cosine similarity to the query vector. This process is repeated until we reach the leaf nodes.

These sections highlight the performance differences between the collapsed tree and tree traversal methods, indicating that the collapsed tree approach generally outperforms tree traversal in terms of F1 score across different context lengths.

### The Image

image3 is described as: The image is a graph comparing different querying methods based on the F1 score. The x-axis represents the Context Length, ranging from 0 to 2500. The y-axis shows the F1 score, ranging from 40 to 65.

There are two lines representing different methods:
- **Collapsed tree** (green line): Shows results over various context lengths. It peaks at 2000 tokens with the best F1 score, slightly decreasing as the context length increases to 2500.
- **Tree Traversal** (blue line): Shows a steady increase in F1 score with context length, but overall performs lower than the collapsed tree method.

### The Answer

Based on the information provided, the collapsed tree querying method generally outperforms the tree traversal method in terms of F1 score across different context lengths. The collapsed tree approach is able to achieve higher F1 scores, particularly at longer context lengths, due to its ability to retrieve information from all nodes simultaneously, offering greater flexibility than the tree traversal method.

Effectiveness of OCR and Captioning Enhancements : The application of OCR and captioning technologies does not yield a significant improvement in the performance of text-only LMMs. This finding suggests that the  MMMU  benchmark requires models that can effectively interpret and integrate both textual and visual information, under- scoring the complexity of the multimodal tasks it presents. [1]

To further distinguish the difference between  MMMU  and other existing ones, we elaborate the benchmark details in Figure 4. From the  breadth  perspective, the prior bench- marks are heavily focused on daily knowledge and com- mon sense. The covered image format is also limited. Our benchmark aims to cover college-level knowledge with 30 image formats including diagrams, tables, charts, chemi- cal structures, photos, paintings, geometric shapes, music sheets, medical images, etc. In the  depth  aspect, the previ- ous benchmarks normally require commonsense knowledge or simple physical or temporal reasoning. In contrast, our benchmark requires deliberate reasoning with college-level subject knowledge. [2]

In this context, we evaluate various models including LLMs and LMMs. In each type, we consider both closed- and open-source models. Our evaluation is conducted under a  zero-shot  set- ting to assess the capability of models to generate accurate answers without fine-tuning or few-shot demonstrations on our benchmark. For all models, we use the default prompt provided by each model for multi-choice or open QA, if available. If models do not provide prompts for task types in  MMMU, we conduct prompt engineering on the validation set and use the most effective prompt for the zero-shot setup in the main experiments. We also report the few-shot results of some selected models in the Appendix. All experiments are conducted with NVIDIA A100 GPUs. [7]

To this end, we introduce  MMMU : a comprehensive benchmark designed for college-level multi-discipline mul- timodal understanding and reasoning. It features problems sourced from college exams, quizzes, and textbooks span- ning six common disciplines: Art & Design, Business, Sci- ence, Health & Medicine, Humanities & Social Science, and Tech & Engineering.  MMMU  consists of  11. 5 K carefully selected multimodal questions, which cover  30  diverse sub- jects and  183  subfields, thus meeting the  breadth  goal. Moreover, many problems within  MMMU  require expert-level reasoning, such as applying “Fourier Transform” or “Equi- librium Theory” to derive the solution, thus meeting the depth  goal.  MMMU  also presents two unique challenges ab- sent in current benchmarks ( Figure 1 ). Firstly, it covers di- verse image formats, from visual scenes like photographs and paintings to diagrams and tables, testing the perceptual capabilities of LMMs. Secondly,  MMMU  features interleaved text-image inputs. A model needs to jointly understand the images and text, which often requires recalling deep subject knowledge, and conducting complex reasoning based on the understanding and knowledge to reach a solution. [10]

**The Historic Treasures of Bergen: UNESCO World Heritage Museums**
================================================================

**[UNESCO World Heritage Sites in Bergen](https://paste.fynz.io/memz8uomam)**
--------------------------------------------------------------------

Bergen, Norway, is home to several museums that have been recognized by UNESCO as World Heritage Sites. These institutions are a testament to the city's rich cultural and historical heritage.

**Bryggen and its UNESCO World Heritage Site**
------------------------------------------

*   **Bryggen Museum**: This museum showcases the history of the Hanseatic League, a powerful trading federation that dominated the North Sea region during the Middle Ages. Visitors can explore the reconstructed 19th- and 20th-century Bergen, featuring a unique collection of around 50 original wooden buildings.
*   **The Hanseatic Museum & Schützengilde St. Jacobi**: This museum delves into the history of the Hanseatic League, with a focus on the city's role in the league's growth and development. The museum also features a beautiful English-style park and a seawater pool.

[![Bryggen and its UNESCO World Heritage Site](https://paste.fynz.io/dpyx2ihsun "Bryggen and its UNESCO World Heritage Site")]([1](https://paste.fynz.io/memz8uomam))

**KODE Art Museums of Bergen**
------------------------------

KODE, located in four buildings in the heart of the city, is Norway's second-largest art collection. The museums feature works from the 15th century up to the present, including pieces by famous artists such as Munch, Dahl, Klee, and Picasso. Visitors can explore the extensive collection, with a dedicated KunstLab section for children and a separate program of changing exhibitions.

[![KODE Art Museums of Bergen](https://paste.fynz.io/xgnf7myiez "KODE Art Museums of Bergen")]([2](https://paste.fynz.io/memz8uomam))

In conclusion, Bergen's UNESCO World Heritage museums offer a unique glimpse into the city's rich history and cultural heritage. Whether you're interested in the Hanseatic League, art, or architecture, there's something for everyone to enjoy.

To understand the coursework requirements for the ISEP program, let's break down the necessary components:

### Coursework Requirements

The program requires students to complete coursework conducted by NUS faculty and/or RIs. The requirements for this include:

*   **Minimum 30 modular credits (MCs):** This is the overall requirement for coursework.
*   **Compulsory courses:** These include GS6001, GS5002, and GS6883A. Students must complete these courses.
*   **Other courses:** These must be approved by the supervisor and ISEP.
*   **Important notes:**
    *   The level of the courses should be at or above level 5000 or 6000, which aligns with the requirements mentioned in [Text Quote 3].
    *   "S/U" grading is allowed, but its impact on CAP and modular credits needs to be considered carefully.
    *   The program's grading system for coursework is outlined in [Text Quote 4].

### Lab Rotations

Lab rotations are also a crucial part of the program. The requirements for lab rotations are as follows:

*   **Two laboratory rotations:** These must be completed within the first 4 months of the program, each lasting 1.5-2.5 months.
*   **Approved supervisors:** Students must work with approved supervisors for these rotations.

### Additional Requirements

In addition to coursework and lab rotations, the program also requires students to participate in a workshop in September/October facilitated by the module coordinators. [Text Quote 5]

### Conclusion

The ISEP program requires students to complete coursework and lab rotations. The coursework must include a minimum of 30 MCs, with compulsory courses such as GS6001, GS5002, and GS6883A. Students can also complete other courses approved by the supervisor and ISEP. The program also requires two lab rotations with approved supervisors within the first 4 months. Additionally, students must participate in a workshop facilitated by the module coordinators.

Visit the Living Museum, which features a unique collection of around 50 original wooden buildings, an English-style park, and a seawater pool. This is a great way to experience nostalgia and explore the city's history [3].

**Showcasing Norway's maritime heritage**
The Shipping Museum features the development of shipping and its importance to Bergen and Norway, from the Iron Age and Viking Age to the present [4]. The museum building is an architectural gem, situated in beautiful surroundings, and guided tours are available from June to August.

**Reach the top of Bergen for breathtaking views**
Take the cable car to the top of Bergen and experience the fantastic landscape, views, and unique culinary experiences at Sky sk rape ren Restaurant [5]. The Ulriken Express Bus service runs from the city centre to the cable car every half hour from 1 May to 30 September.

**Experience Norwegian aquaculture**
The Storeblå Aquaculture Visitor Centre provides a unique insight into Norwegian aquaculture, with a modern exhibition and the opportunity to see salmon up close on a bracing RIB boat trip to a fish farm outside Bergen [6].

**A variety of museums and attractions**
Bergen has many museums, including the Bergen Aquarium, where you can see sea lions, penguins, and other animals, as well as the VilVite Science Centre, which is great for families [7]. [5] Immerse yourself in fascinating history in authentic 18th-century wharfside warehouses. Learn about the sea, our common marine resources and fishermen’s lives through the ages. This museum appears to cater to a wide audience, including children, with its family-friendly activities and outdoor and indoor facilities.

[2] Visit a unique cultural monument with many stories to tell. When its last residents died in 1946, the hospital had been in use for more than 500 years. Learn about leprosy, how widespread it was and the efforts made to eradicate the disease, which culminated in Gerhard Armauer Hansen’s discovery of the leprae bacillus in 1873.
The Leprosy Museum at St. George’s Hospital focuses specifically on educating about the history of leprosy, providing insights into the disease’s prevalence and the groundbreaking discoveries made to combat it.

[3] Osterøy Museum is in a beautiful setting in the cultural landscape of Osterøy. Old buildings show how people in the countryside outside Bergen lived, and through story-telling and experiences, the museum links objects and the living cultural heritage of textiles and costumes, weaving and local building customs.
Although not specifically listed as a museum focused on children’s activities, the Osterøy Museum offers experiential learning through storytelling and connecting visitors with the local cultural heritage, potentially benefiting children.

[8] Local history museum for Ytre Arna, where the industrialisation of Western Norway began in 1846. Arne Fabrikker was the biggest textile factory in Norway in the 1950s. Learn about industrial history and the development of the local community, combined with a visit to the Oleana textile factory, which is housed in the same building.
While primarily focused on industrial history, the museum may offer activities and insights that could be engaging for children, especially regarding the local community and textile manufacturing.

In summary, museums that specifically cater to children’s activities are:
- The 18th-century wharfside warehouses

- Osterøy Museum (for experiential cultural heritage learning)

The Leprosy Museum stands out for its focus on educating about the history of leprosy, making it a valuable resource for those interested in this specific subject.

![Leprosy Museum at St. George’s Hospital](image2)

![Osterøy Museum](image3)

### Old Bergen Museum [1] and Its Unique Collection
Old Bergen Museum is a reconstructed 19th and 20th-century living museum in Bergen, featuring a unique collection of around 50 original wooden buildings that once stood in the centre of Bergen. This historical collection showcases the city's cultural heritage, transporting visitors back in time.

### Bryggen [3]
Bryggen is a UNESCO World Heritage site where Bergen's history began, offering a walk through the wooden buildings and ruins of the city's first town hall, which are well hidden below street level. The walk concludes at the Schwitch Stuene assembly rooms, providing a comprehensive historical experience.

### Osterøy Museum [4]
Osterøy Museum is set in a beautiful cultural landscape, presenting old buildings that demonstrate life in the countryside outside Bergen. Through storytelling and experience, the museum connects objects with living cultural heritage, including textiles, costumes, weaving, and local building customs.

### Salhus Trikke Fabrik [5]
Salhus Trikke Fabrik is a listed textile factory from 1859 that demonstrates how wool is turned into clothes. This unique museum offers insight into the textile industry in Western Norway.

### Haakon's Hall [6]
Haakon's Hall is a 13th-century royal banqueting hall built in stone, the largest and most imposing of its kind in Bergen. It now serves as a living national cultural heritage site, giving visitors an idea of what it was like to be a king in the Middle Ages.

### KODE Art Museums of Bergen [7]
KODE features Norway's second-largest art collection in four museums in the heart of the city. It showcases art and design from the 15th century up to the present, including works by Munch, Dahl, Klee, and Picasso. The KunstLab section includes a workshop and exhibition area for children, with a separate program of changing exhibitions.

### Bergen Latin School [8]
The Bergen Latin School, dating back to 1706, is Norway's oldest school building. Exhibitions on the Norwegian school system and society from the Middle Ages to the present are available, along with a thematic exhibition of old natural science posters.

### Herdla Museum [9]
Herdla Museum, situated on a small island west of Bergen, has exhibitions about its dramatic role in World War II and its rich fauna and birdlife. The main attraction is a German fighter aircraft from WWII, making it a great destination for history buffs and nature enthusiasts.

These museums in Bergen offer a diverse range of historical and cultural experiences, highlighting the city's rich heritage through unique and engaging exhibits.

To answer your question, the coffee machine comes with different types of drip trays and grids, which cater to various user preferences and machine configurations. Here are some key differences:

- **Drip tray with SteamJet function:** This type of drip tray is designed to work in conjunction with the SteamJet feature, which allows for precise control over steam flow and temperature. This specific drip tray has a unique design that allows for easy cleaning and maintenance. [image1]
- **Drip tray without SteamJet function:** This type of drip tray is designed for machines without the SteamJet feature. It still serves the primary purpose of collecting used coffee grounds and beverage waste but is a more standard design. [image1]
- **Drip grid:** A drip grid is a type of tray that is specifically designed to separate coffee grounds from the liquid during brewing. It works on the principle of allowing coffee grounds to pass through a mesh or perforated surface while keeping the liquid on top. This design is particularly useful for users who want to minimize mess and cleanup. [image1]

The differences between these drip trays and grids lie in their design, functionality, and compatibility with specific machine features. While the drip tray with SteamJet function is tailored to work with machines that have this feature, the standard drip tray is more versatile and can be used with a variety of machines. The drip grid, on the other hand, is a separate accessory that can be used with any machine that uses a drip tray. [image1]

![Table with drip tray options](image1)

The minimum and maximum values for the oscillator frequency are:

level-2 in the five-level reliability architecture of OBS (Object Based Storage) has passed TRUCS in page 8 concerns with FRUs (Field Replaceable Units) and ensures reliability through erasure code solution: Erasure code
![Erasure code](image3)
 
In level-2 of the five-level reliability architecture, erasure code is used to address the concern of FRUs (Field Replaceable Units). Erasure code is a technique that can correct errors that occur due to faulty FRUs. This ensures that the data remains intact and reliable, even if one or more FRUs fail. By implementing erasure code, OBS (Object Based Storage) can maintain the overall reliability of the system and ensure that data is available even in the event of hardware failures.

To ensure optimal washing quality, the dishwasher should be loaded according to the manufacturer's guidelines, taking into account the specific recommendations for both the upper and lower baskets. [2] [4] [5] [6] [8] [9]

As illustrated in image1, the dishwasher should have the lower basket loaded first, followed by the upper basket, and then items such as cups, glasses, pots/pans, etc., placed faced downwards. [5]

For the lower basket, common items like pots, pans, serving dishes, and bowls should be placed, with serving dishes and lids positioned on the side of the racks to avoid blocking the rotation of the top spray arm. [6] 

In addition, image2 provides a list of numbered items commonly used for dining, which can serve as a reference for loading utensils. 

It's also essential to consider the type of items being washed, such as curved items or ones with recesses, which should be loaded at an angle to allow water to run off. [9]

As highlighted in image3, failure to comply with the recommended loading procedure can result in poor washing quality. 

Furthermore, image4 illustrates a dishwasher rack with a numbered guide indicating different dishware items, emphasizing the importance of proper loading for optimal washing quality.

To ensure secure loading, utensils should be stacked securely and cannot tip over, and long bladed knives should be positioned horizontally in the upper basket. [9]

Lastly, as shown in image5, a cutlery rack diagram provides a visual representation of how utensils can be organized, but without a legend, the exact meanings of the numbers are unclear.

By following these guidelines and taking into account the specific recommendations for both the upper and lower baskets, you can ensure optimal washing quality and proper energy consumption for your dishwasher.

To customize the Control Panel on a smartphone, a user can follow these steps:

1.  **Swiping down** from the upper right edge of the screen to display the Control Panel.
2.  **Accessing the shortcut switches panel**: The user can expand the shortcut switches panel by touching the "Edit switches" option. The exact steps might vary depending on the device model.
3.  **Draging and dropping the shortcut switch**: To customize the Control Panel, the user needs to touch and hold a shortcut switch to drag it to their preferred position.

Some features to be considered while customizing the Control Panel include:
1.  **Updating the shortcut switch list**: Users should make sure that all the necessary apps are updated to the latest version before customizing the Control Panel.
2.  **App support**: Not all apps support the Control Panel feature, so users should check the compatibility of their apps before attempting to customize the Control Panel.
![Control Panel Apps](image3)
To access more shortcut switches, the user can swipe down from the upper right edge of the screen and touch the "Sort shortcut switches" option. Alternatively, they can touch the "Edit switches" option to access the full list of shortcut switches.

To access and manage Bluetooth and Wi-Fi features on a smartphone using the Control Panel, swipe down from the upper right edge of your phone to display the Control Panel, then touch the Wi-Fi and Bluetooth icons at the top of the Control Panel. You can enable or disable these features and access their settings by holding these icons.

![Bluetooth and Wi-Fi Status Icons Indicate Feature Enablement](image2)
[1]  Swipe down from the upper right edge of your phone to display Control Panel and touch to expand the shortcut switches panel (depending on your device model).
Some status icons in the Control Panel include:
- Circular Wi-Fi signal icon: Wi-Fi connected
- Two devices connected by Wi-Fi icon: Hotspot connected
- Wi-Fi signal icon with an 'X': Hotspot disconnected
- Wi-Fi 6 label next to the Wi-Fi icon: Wi-Fi 6 connected
- Wi-Fi 6 icon with exclamation mark: Wi-Fi 6 network is faulty, unable to connect to the Internet
- Wi-Fi 6+ label next to the Wi-Fi icon: Wi-Fi 6+ connected
- Wi-Fi 6+ icon with exclamation mark: Wi-Fi 6+ network is faulty, unable to connect to the Internet
- Airplane icon: Airplane mode is ON
- Empty battery icon: Battery empty
- Low battery icon: Low battery power
- Charging lightning bolt icon: Charging
- Super charging double lightning bolt icon: Super charging
- Quick charging zigzag lightning icon: Quick charging
- Wireless super charging zigzag lightning icon with additional curves: Wireless super charging

# On-Campus Supermarkets and Markets Opening Hours
The on-campus supermarkets and markets have the following opening hours:

### On-Campus Supermarkets
One of the on-campus supermarkets is Tmall campus - Zijing store located in the basement of the Zijing Student Service Center (C Building). Its opening hours are:
Monday to Sunday, 8:30am - 11:30pm

Another on-campus supermarket is Tmall campus - Qingfen store located in the basement of the New Student Apartment, Building 7, south area, with the same opening hours: Monday to Sunday, 8:30am - 11:30pm.

Lastly, there's Tmall campus - Guanchou store located in the basement of Guanchou Yuan canteen, with the opening hours: Monday to Sunday, 9:00am - 9:00pm

### On-Campus Markets
Three on-campus markets are also available, with the following opening hours:

1.  Zhaolanyuan Market (照澜院农贸市)
    -   Location: In the Zhaolanyuan area
    -   Opening Hours: Monday to Sunday, 8:30am – 7:00pm
2.  West Market (西市场)
    -   Location: East of Yuyuan Canteen
    -   Opening Hours: Monday to Sunday, 8:00am – 7:00pm
3.  North Area Fruit and Vegetable Market (北区便民果蔬超市)
    -   Location: Outside the north gate
    -   Opening Hours: Monday to Sunday, 8:00am – 10:00pm

# Off-Campus Supermarkets
Off-campus supermarkets have varying opening hours:
-   Lotus Supermarket (易初莲花) has opening hours: Monday to Sunday, 9:00am – 9:00pm
-   BHG Supermarket (华联) has the same opening hours: Monday to Sunday, 9:00am – 9:00pm
-   Carrefour (家乐福) has the opening hours: Monday to Sunday, 8:30am – 10:00pm

## Comparison
In comparison, the on-campus supermarkets generally have longer opening hours than their off-campus counterparts.

The aerobic zone is represented by a colored segment on the watch screen. To determine the exact color associated with the aerobic zone, let's examine the evidence provided by quote [5]. According to this quote, the heart rate zone for different types of workout activities is calculated based on the selected calculation method.

● If you select **Maximum heart rate percentage** as the calculation method, the heart rate zone for different types of workout activities is calculated based on your maximum heart rate ("220 – your age" by default). 

● If you select **HRR percentage** as the calculation method, the heart rate interval for different types of workout activities is calculated based on your heart rate reserve (HRmax - HRrest).

The evidence does not explicitly state the color for the aerobic zone when using the maximum heart rate percentage method. However, quote [5] does not directly reference color for the aerobic zone but does describe the zones for different types of workout activities.

To seek medical assistance and support services at NTU, students can utilize various resources available on campus and in the surrounding area. 

According to [9] image4, the Medical Service on campus is operated by Fullerton Healthcare Group, providing services such as general outpatient medical and dental treatment, laboratory and X-ray investigation, as well as minor surgery. They also offer immunization and travel medical advice.

Students can visit the University Health Service facility, which is located at #02-01, 36 Nanyang Avenue, and is equipped with a Medical & Dental Clinic and the Student Wellbeing Centre. The centre provides resources and support services for students, including counselling, workshops, and talks on topics such as stress and relaxation techniques. 

Near the campus, students can access a range of healthcare services, including the Singapore General Hospital, National University Hospital, and Changi General Hospital, which are listed in image1. Private clinics such as Khoo Teck Puat Hospital, KK Women’s and Children’s Hospital, and Alexandra Hospital are also readily available. 

For those requiring specialized support, students can reach out to the Accessible Education Unit at aeu@ntu.edu.sg for special needs and support services. Moreover, the Student Wellbeing Centre administers a peer support network called the ‘Peer Helping Programme’ to provide emotional and psychological support to students. 

Please see image2 for the contact information of SAO-Student Support, which can be located on level 4 of the Student Services Centre or reached at (65) 6790 6823 (during office hours) and (65) 6790 5200 (24-hour Campus Security Hotline). 

For more information, students can visit the websites of the various healthcare services or organisations listed in image1.

To connect to another Mac using the Migration Assistant, follow these steps:

First, on the Mac you want to transfer information from, open Migration Assistant (located in /Applications/Utilities/) and click Continue. Then, insert the Mac OS X Install Disc 1 that came with your MacBook Air to install the DVD or CD Sharing Setup, which includes software for DVD or CD Sharing, Migration Assistant, and Remote Install Mac OS X: [2]

If you don't use Setup Assistant to transfer information when you first start up your MacBook Air, you can do it later using Migration Assistant. Go to the Applications folder, open Utilities, and double-click Migration Assistant. [3]

When you are prompted for a migration method, select “To another Mac” and click Continue. [7]

On the other Mac, follow the Setup Assistant onscreen instructions until you get to the “Do You Already Own a Mac?” screen. Select “from another Mac” as the source of the information you want to transfer. On the next screen, choose your wireless network, and then click Continue. [10]

The image shows the screen prompt for connecting to another Mac, where you'll be prompted to enter a passcode from the other Mac, as well as instructions for setting up a connection using a Mac OS X Install Disc, joining the same AirPort network, and opening the Migration Assistant. The passcode is displayed as "640256."![Connecting to Another Mac](image2)

To ensure a smooth connection, make sure both Macs are connected to the same AirPort network. The image illustrates a graphical representation of a Wi-Fi router or modem with signal waves emanating from it, indicating wireless connectivity.![Wireless Connectivity](image5)

Once connected, you'll be prompted to enter the passcode from the other Mac. Enter the passcode on both Macs to continue the process.![Enter Passcode](image4)

After entering the passcode, the Migration Assistant will guide you through the transfer process. You can then choose to set up another Mac that has an optical disc drive to partner with, or follow the remaining prompts to select your wireless network, set up an account, and exit Setup Assistant. [9]

Finally, you can select “Do not transfer my information now” and click Continue to perform a basic setup, or choose to set up a setup with migration. [9]

### Button Functions During a Workout

During a workout, several distinct button functions are available on the smartwatch. These functions are crucial for navigating through different workout modes, adjusting settings, and pausing the workout.

According to the provided information, there are at least four distinct button functions during a workout:

- **Press the Up button**: This function can be used to pause or end the running course, lock the screen, or adjust the volume for prompts during the workout. It can also be used to adjust settings such as turning off the screen after a few minutes of inactivity.

- **Press the Down button**: This function allows you to switch between screens and view different workout data. For example, in Outdoor Run mode, you can view a range of data displayed next to Heart rate, Pace, Distance, Time, Steps, Cadence, Total calories, and Total climbing.

- **Press and hold the Up button**: This function can be used to finish a workout session.

- **Press and hold the Down button**: This function can be used to wake up the voice assistant, which is only available on certain smartwatch models, such as the HONOR Watch GS Pro.

While additional button functions are described in the table, these four are the most directly relevant to a workout experience.

The unit provides comprehensive training to Afghan scientists and technicians on laboratory operations, diagnostic procedures, and ethics in research and management, particularly in relation to U.S. select agents [1, 6]. This training is essential for building the capacity of Afghan laboratories to conduct medical research and respond to emerging health threats.

**NSMRL's Contributions to Medical and Scientific Research**
NSMRL is a leading operational medicine laboratory focused on the submarine force and human factors within [4]. The laboratory conducts medical, psychological, and human performance research, providing independent reviews of human systems and technology proposed for the submarine force [4]. NSMRL also investigates diving medicine and has developed innovative concepts for the submarine force, such as the Genesis hyperbaric chamber, which can simulate high-altitude pressures and study mission profiles without requiring configuration changes [4].

The Naval Medical Research Center (NMRC) contributes significantly to both international medical initiatives and local medical advancements through various programs and collaborations. [1] The NMRC's international efforts include partnering with the Defense Threat Reduction Agency's Cooperative Biological Engagement Program in Afghanistan to enhance biodefense and disease surveillance efforts, as well as conducting humanitarian missions such as the USNS Mercy Pacific Partnership missions in Southeast Asia. [4] [8]

For instance, as part of the USNS Mercy Pacific Partnership mission, NAMRU-3 provided medical care to over 49,000 patients in four host nations, including Indonesia, the Philippines, Vietnam, and Cambodia, with a range of services including general adult and pediatric medical care, dental, and vision screenings. [2] Additionally, the NMRC's Bone Marrow Research Directorate provides military contingency support for casualties with marrow toxic injury due to radiation or chemical warfare agents, and has established partnerships with ministries of health in several countries to build medical capacity. [3] [4]

Locally, the NMRC contributes to medical advancements through the establishment of hospital laboratories, virology, bacteriology, and serology laboratories within the Consumer Product Health Laboratory (CPHL), as well as training programs for diagnostic laboratories and implementation of acute febrile illness/diarrhea studies. [9] Moreover, the NMRC has conducted train-the-trainer programs, workshops, and other activities to enhance laboratory operations, diagnostic procedures, and ethics in research and management. [6] [7]

Notably, the NMRC also engages in donor drives, such as the C.W. Bill Young DoD Marrow Donor Program, which allows for the collection of bone marrow samples from U.S. donors for potential use in treating patients. [5] Overall, the NMRC's efforts demonstrate a commitment to improving international medical initiatives and local medical advancements through a range of programs and collaborations.

**The PCOF tool plays a crucial role in military operations by providing a repeatable, organized, and robust method for estimating patient conditions, enhancing medical mission planning, and informing decision-makers on the types of patient conditions to expect in various scenarios.**

![The image shows a man, Lt. j.g. Michael Rucker, treating the feet of a 7-year-old girl from Djibouti at the Caritas Djibouti complex. The setting appears to be a medical or humanitarian aid context, with medical supplies visible on the table.](image1)

As part of their mission to assess the risk of rickettsia l diseases to military and civilian personnel worldwide, the Rickettsia l Diseases Research Program trains individuals involved in regions that are endemic to rickettsia l diseases. [1] [8]

The PCOF tool examined through this formal VV&A effort provides an effective, accurate and repeatable method of generating PCOF estimates using standardized and documented means of adjusting baseline distributions. [9]

Using an accredited PCOF tool, planners can employ baselined, mission-centric PCOF data and tailor it to more precisely fit the anticipated mission. This will help inform decision makers on the types of patient conditions to expect in various scenarios, such as humanitarian assistance, disaster relief, defense support of civil authorities, and combat operations. [6]

The PCOF tool generates tables that show the occurrence probabilities of disease and injury types typically sustained in a contingency by a population at risk. PCOF tables exist within casualty categories of wounded in action, nonbattle injuries, disease, and outpatient visits for a given combat or noncombat scenario throughout the range of military operations (ROMO). [10]

The PCOF tool will enable planners to move beyond anecdotal, rule-of-thumb planning estimates into a repeatable, organized and robust estimating method with the potential to dramatically enhance medical mission planning. [2]

The tool was developed by the Expeditionary Medicine Modeling, Simulation, and Analysis group at the Naval Health Research Center (NHRC) and has been presented to the Force Health Protection and Readiness, Strategic Analysis Working Group Office of the Assistant Secretary of Defense, Health Affairs as part of the verification, validation, and accreditation (VV&A) plan for service acceptance. [3]

With the anticipated drawdown in troops, the research window of opportunity is rapidly closing, and the research team has prioritized enrollment and conduct of currently approved protocols as well as the judicious and expedient processing of new protocols. [7]

In summary, the PCOF tool is a critical tool for military operations, providing a repeatable and robust method for estimating patient conditions, enhancing medical mission planning, and informing decision-makers on the types of patient conditions to expect in various scenarios.

**[1] The NMRC Bone Marrow Research Directorate provides military contingency support for casualties with marrow toxic injury due to radiation or chemical warfare agents. Exposure to radiation or chemical agents can cause irreversible damage to bone marrow, breaking down the immune system in the process. The directorate performs laboratory research that supports technology innovations to make highly reliable and cost-effective DNA-based typing for marrow transplants.**

The main objectives of the USNS Mercy Pacific Partnership 2012 were to provide humanitarian assistance to the people of Liberia and to support the Armed Forces of Liberia in their efforts to combat infectious diseases such as malaria. **[5] During a meeting with Graham, he expressed particular interest in the project combining insecticide spraying for all base housing with surveillance and geospatial mapping to determine the distribution of malaria-transmitting mosquitoes. No malaria infections have been diagnosed in U.S. troops since the onset of the spraying, which is carried out by NAMRU-3 in collaboration with the Navy Entomology Center of Excellence (NECE). This illustrates the risk reduction made possible with a force health protection policy employing both environmental vector controls and anti-malarial prophylaxis.**

The DoD Bone Marrow Program, on the other hand, aims to collect and match bone marrow donors to patients in need of transplants. **[3] Following DoD donor drives like the one at Marine Corps Base Hawaii, Kaneohe Bay, donor consent forms and oral swabs with cell samples are sent to the C.W. Bill Young DoD Marrow Donor Program Donor Center and Laboratory, which is part of the Naval Medical Research Center’s (NMRC) Bone Marrow Research Directorate.**

While both programs have humanitarian objectives, the USNS Mercy Pacific Partnership 2012 had a broader scope, providing comprehensive medical and humanitarian assistance to the people of Liberia, including medical care, surgeries, and disaster response. **[6] Upon invitation, missions were conducted in four host nations: Indonesia, the Philippines, Vietnam and Cambodia. Over the 56 days dedicated to mission activities, more than 49,000 patients were seen and treated ashore, including general adult and pediatric medical care as well as dental and vision screenings at Medical and Dental Civic Action Programs (MEDCAPs).**

In contrast, the DoD Bone Marrow Program is focused specifically on collecting and matching bone marrow donors, with a primary objective of supporting military personnel and veterans in need of transplants. **[9] In 2012 over 42,000 service members, family members, and DoD employees registered with the C.W. Bill Young DoD Marrow Donor Program, joining more than 730,000 DoD volunteers who are potential marrow donors. Of these, over 5,200 have donated marrow for patients needing transplants to treat one of over 80 potentially fatal diseases.**

NSMRL's role is a multifaceted one. NSMRL is an operational medicine laboratory focused on the submarine force and human factors within. It serves as CSF's primary human technology laboratory, encompassing physical and mental aspects of submariner health and performance. The lab conducts medical, psychological, and human performance research, provides independent reviews of human systems projects and technology, and develops new concepts for CSF use. They also investigate diving medicine, as seen with the addition of an external hatch on the Genesis hyperbaric chamber, allowing for "flown" tests at high altitudes and unique mission profile studies. Furthermore, NSMRL has recently acquired NAVSEA's DP1/2 diving system, enhancing underwater investigation capabilities with real-time communications.![NSMRL's role in submarine medicine](image3)

NAMRU-3 conducted various training activities in Afghanistan, including [1] a bacteriology training workshop for nine Afghan trainees from the Central Public Health Laboratory in Kabul, and [2] a comprehensive training plan for 160 Afghan scientists and technicians on laboratory operations, diagnostic procedures, and ethics in research and management with respect to activity involving U.S. select agents. The training plan was developed in 2012 based on needs and gaps identified by NAMRU-3 laboratory assessments.

![A training session for Afghan laboratory staff](image4)

The training plan included nine modules on parasitology, bacteriology, bioscience facility management, clinical epidemiology, miomedical equipment repair, laboratory quality management system, serology, molecular biology, and virology. [7]

In addition to these formal training programs, NAMRU-3 also conducted [9] workshops to train laboratory and administrative staff on proper laboratory procedures, establish inventory for supplies, institute quality control procedures and standard operating procedures, purchase reliable supplies, and develop national laboratory biosafety and laboratory quality control plans.

![A team of U.S. Navy personnel and Afghan partners smiling and posing for a photo](image2)

These training activities were part of NAMRU-3's efforts to build medical capacity with Ministry of Health laboratories in Afghanistan, in partnership with the Defense Threat Reduction Agency's Cooperative Biological Engagement Program (CBEP). [4]

![An image of U.S. Naval Medical Research Unit-2 (NAMRU-2), Pacific emblem](image3)

Overall, NAMRU-3's training activities in Afghanistan were designed to enhance the efficiency and synergy in the U.S. government's biodefense and disease surveillance efforts, and to improve the public health capacity of Afghan laboratories.

The immune system targets malaria parasites through a complex process involving the engagement of CD8+ T cells with infected liver cells. This interaction is illustrated in image1, which highlights the immune response aimed at eliminating the parasite. Key elements include:

CD8+ T cell: Engages with the liver cell
Liver Cell: Contains the Pf schizont (a stage of the malaria parasite)
Pf peptide: Presented on the liver cell surface
Class I: Refers to MHC Class I molecules presenting antigens
Immune Response: Includes the release of perforin and granzymes by the CD8+ T cell, leading to apoptosis and death of the parasite
IFN-γ and Fas/FasR interactions: Indicate mechanisms of cell signaling and apoptosis induction

![CD8+ T cell engages with infected liver cell, releasing perforin and granzymes to induce apoptosis and eliminate malaria parasite](image1)

The CD8+ T cell plays a crucial role in targeting malaria parasites by recognizing and destroying infected liver cells. This process is critical in preventing the parasite from spreading and causing further damage to the host. By understanding the immune response against malaria parasites, researchers can identify novel antigens for vaccine development, as shown in image1.

Healthcare IT systems continue to evolve and improve. In 2006, the adoption rate of IT systems in the healthcare sector demonstrated gradual progress across several categories. A 2006 Health IT Staffing Needs report [2] observed:
*   Electronic Medical Records increased by 1 percentage point (from 61% to 62%)
*   Bar Coded Medication Management decreased by 3 percentage points (from 58% to 55%)
*   Computerized Practitioner Order Entry (CPOE) decreased by 2 percentage points (from 52% to 50%)
*   Enterprise-Wide Clinical Information Sharing decreased by 5 percentage points (from 49% to 44%)
*   Clinical Data Repository decreased by 3 percentage points (from 45% to 42%)
*   Point-of-Care Decision Support decreased by 4 percentage points (from 41% to 37%)
*   Digital Picture Archiving (PACS) increased by 16 percentage points (from 26% to 42%)
*   Ambulatory Systems decreased by 5 percentage points (from 22% to 17%)

Despite these advancements, the survey results [3] revealed significant challenges facing the healthcare IT sector. In 2006, the top challenges included:
*   Lack of financial support (20%)
*   Lack of staffing resources (13%)
*   Vendor's inability to effectively deliver product (18%)
*   Proving IT quantifiable benefits/ROI (10%)
*   Difficulty achieving end-user acceptance (8%)
*   Lack of clinical leadership (10%)
*   Lack of top management support (7%)
*   Lack of a strategic IT plan (4%)
*   Laws prohibiting technology sharing (4%)
*   Lack of common data standards (3%)

In contrast to 2005, there was a notable increase in the following challenges:
*   Lack of financial support (20% increase)
*   Lack of staffing resources (5% increase)
*   Vendor's inability to effectively deliver product (6% increase)
*   Lack of clinical leadership (2% increase)
*   Lack of top management support (no change)
*   Lack of a strategic IT plan (2% increase)
*   Laws prohibiting technology sharing (4% increase)
*   Lack of common data standards (1% increase)

In terms of applications, the healthcare IT sector continues to prioritize patient satisfaction, reducing medical errors, and improving quality of care. The 2006 survey results [5] revealed:
*   Patient satisfaction increased by 7 percentage points (from 44% to 51%)
*   Reducing medical errors increased by 13 percentage points (from 31% to 44%)
*   Improving quality of care increased by 6 percentage points (from 36% to 42%)
*   Integration and interoperability remained at 37%
*   Adoption of new technology decreased by 2 percentage points (from 31% to 29%)
*   Improving operational efficiency remained at 40%

Overall, the healthcare IT sector continues to face challenges related to financial support, staffing resources, and vendor capabilities. However, advancements in IT adoption and application priorities reflect a gradual shift towards improved patient satisfaction, reduced medical errors, and enhanced quality of care.

Together, participation statistics and weekend activity data can be perceived as part of a group, with both being integrated into a visual whole [1]. The use of graphical representations, such as the pie charts in image 3, facilitates this perception by allowing for the identification of patterns and trends [3]. For instance, the comparison between weekend activities in 2005 and 2010 can be easily visualized through the pie charts, which help to eliminate complexity and unfamiliarity, thereby creating meaning [8]. This meaning created by perception implies a global regularity, such as the shift in people's weekend activities over time, which is often mentally prioritized over spatial relations [9].

![image4](image4.png)
![image5](image5.png)
image4 is an infographic that displays participation statistics from a CTBT training program, including the number of minutes watched online, clicks on lecture videos, registered participants, and institutional affiliation data. The infographic is designed to create a visual whole, with clear and concise data presented in an orderly and simple manner. This visual representation helps to eliminate complexity and unfamiliarity, making it easier to understand and perceive the data.

In contrast, image 5 presents a visual structure, consisting of rows and columns of dots, which seems to be a visual representation rather than conveying specific numerical data or tabular information. This type of representation can be seen as a simple and orderly pattern, which is consistent with the Gestalt principle of Proximidade (Proximity) [4]. However, the lack of clear data and the focus on visual structure rather than numerical information make it less suitable for comparing participation statistics to weekend activity data.

The comparison between the participation statistics and weekend activity data can be seen as an example of the Gestalt principle of Semelhança (Similarity) [5], where similar patterns and trends are identified and grouped together. In this case, the graphical representations used in the pie charts and the visual structure of image 5 can be seen as facilitating this process.

**"Analytics is about impact...In our company [Zynga], if you have brilliant insight and you did great research and noone changes,you get zero credit."** [1]
The Analytics Value Chain is a critical process that transforms data into actionable insights and value. It consists of several stages, including data collection, analysis, and decision-making. To comprehend how the Analytics Value Chain and Levels of Analytics complement each other, let's first explore what each term means.

**Analytics Value Chain** is a framework that outlines the steps involved in transforming data into value. It includes the following stages:
- **Reporting**: The initial stage where data is used to raise questions and provide information. Reporting is about eliciting what happened, how many, how often, and where.
- **Ad-Hoc Reports**: The stage where data is used to address specific queries, such as "How many, how often, where?"
- **Query Drilldown (OLAP)**: This stage involves answering the question "Where exactly is the problem?"
- **Alerts**: Alerts determine what actions are needed based on the data.
- **Statistical Analysis**: This stage explores why things are happening and seeks to understand the underlying causes.
- **Forecasting**: Forecasting considers what will happen if current trends continue.
- **Predictive Modelling**: Predictive modeling predicts what will happen next.
- **Optimisation**: Optimisation evaluates what's the best that can happen.
The Analytics Value Chain diagram [image2] shows the progression from Business Intelligence to Business Analytics, increasing both business value and degree of intelligence as one moves up the hierarchy.

**Levels of Analytics**, on the other hand, refers to the different stages of maturity in the Analytics Value Chain. These levels represent a progression from basic reporting to advanced predictive analytics. The levels are often categorized into four main stages:
- **Standard Reports**: The initial stage where data is used to raise questions and provide information.
- **Ad-Hoc Reports**: The stage where data is used to address specific queries.
- **Query Drilldown (OLAP)**: This stage involves answering the question "Where exactly is the problem?"
- **Alerts**: Alerts determine what actions are needed based on the data.
- **Statistical Analysis**: This stage explores why things are happening and seeks to understand the underlying causes.
- **Forecasting**: Forecasting considers what will happen if current trends continue.
- **Predictive Modelling**: Predictive modeling predicts what will happen next.
- **Optimisation**: Optimisation evaluates what's the best that can happen.

The progression from Business Intelligence to Business Analytics, as depicted in the Analytics Value Chain diagram [image2], aligns with the Levels of Analytics. Business Intelligence includes stages 1 to 4, while Business Analytics includes stages 5 to 8.

The image [image4] illustrates a data-driven process that transforms data into value, from data storage to reporting, analysis, action, and finally to value. This process embodies the Analytics Value Chain and Levels of Analytics, where each stage builds upon the previous one to create actionable insights and value.

To complement each other, the Analytics Value Chain and Levels of Analytics require a strong data leadership that understands and supports the needs of the business. This leadership enables the analytics organization to perform at its best, to be happy and productive, and to maximize its impact. A collaborative, inclusive, open, and inquisitive Chief Data Officer/Chief Analytics Officer is essential to drive the organization towards a data-driven culture.

In conclusion, the Analytics Value Chain and Levels of Analytics work together to transform data into actionable insights and value. By understanding the progression from Business Intelligence to Business Analytics and the different stages of maturity, organizations can unlock the full potential of data-driven decision-making and create a culture that values data-driven insights.

Metaphase I of meiosis is a critical stage where homologous chromosomes separate, and the chromosome number is reduced by half. This process is depicted in image2 [2], which illustrates the stages of meiosis, including Metaphase I. In Metaphase I, homologous chromosomes line up at the metaphase plate, aligning their centromeres. The centromeres then separate, and the homologous chromosomes move to opposite poles of the cell, reducing the chromosome number by half.

Key features of Metaphase I include:

* Homologous chromosomes align at the metaphase plate.
* Centromeres separate, and homologous chromosomes move to opposite poles.
* The chromosome number is reduced by half.

These processes are crucial for the reduction of the chromosome number during meiosis, resulting in the production of haploid daughter cells. 

![Metaphase I: Homologous chromosomes align at the metaphase plate and centromeres separate](image2)

**Reflection and Refraction: Exploring Examples**
====================================================

When it comes to reflecting surfaces, there are several examples that can be observed in our daily lives. Two notable examples of reflecting surfaces are:

**Microscopic Pits on CDs and DVDs**
-----------------------------------

[1] Allwave can be reflected and refracted

One example of a reflecting surface is the microscopic pits on CDs and DVDs. These tiny depressions act like the absence of light in morse code, with the laser reflecting when it hits a shiny surface and not reflecting when it hits a pit. This phenomenon allows the laser to send a message to computer chips, which then send a visual or audio track to the player.

![Image from image2](![P1c: Reflection, Refraction, Diffraction](image2))

**Building and Atmospheric Reflection**
--------------------------------------

[4] -wireless signals can be reflected or refracted off buildings or by the atmosphere

Another example of a reflecting surface is the reflection of wireless signals off buildings or by the atmosphere. When a signal is transmitted, it can bounce off surfaces or be diffracted around obstacles, affecting its quality. This can result in dropped-in-quality signals or even signal blocking due to hills or buildings.

When asked how they assess the impact of their marketing activity, **80%say financial impact-such as revenue or ROI.** [1] 
Unfortunately, very few marketers use customer engagement as a primary factor in their communications, which indicates that there is a significant gap in this aspect of marketing strategy. [3] 
 Yet, despite the lack of focus on customer engagement, 54% of marketers select the frequency of interactions with their brand, [6] and 47% select the level and depth of brand interaction, [6]  which are more specific measures of engagement. [7] However, it's evident that customer engagement is not a top priority for most marketers, with only 27% saying that their marketing is integrated across brand, direct, and digital communications. [7] 
 This lack of focus on customer engagement is likely due to the challenges in measuring and managing engagement, as highlighted in the chart showing the common barriers to effective coordination and execution in business operations. [image1] 
The same chart also reveals that 52% of marketers identify "There is no single ownership of the experience resulting in siloed approaches and misaligned goals" as a challenge, which is closely related to the lack of focus on customer engagement. [image1] 
In terms of specific measures of engagement, 71% of marketers consider brand awareness and loyalty as important metrics, but it's unclear how this relates to customer engagement. [image3] 
Furthermore, the majority of marketers (64%) allocate budget across marketing disciplines based on historical spending, rather than planned activity or media mix modeling, which could lead to a lack of focus on customer engagement. [8] 
Overall, while some marketers are more focused on customer engagement than others, it is clear that there is a need for a new approach to understanding customers and prospects, one that incorporates quantitative metrics, qualitative metrics, and the fuzzy areas in between, such as social media. [9] 
However, despite the recognition of the importance of customer engagement, the majority of agencies and marketers are still applying only 10% of their campaign performance to the last click (ie. paid search). [10] 
In conclusion, while some marketers are paying attention to customer engagement, it is still a relatively rare practice, with only a small percentage of marketers using it as a primary factor in their communications.

### Needs Exploration Phase in Solution Exploration

According to Disciplined Agile Delivery (DAD) and its various diagrams, the 'Needs Exploration' phase in the process of producing a potentially consumable solution is a crucial component. It involves a range of activities and strategies to uncover and articulate the needs of stakeholders, thereby informing the development of a solution. 

Here is a breakdown of some key strategies and activities involved in the 'Needs Exploration' phase, as depicted in image 4:

*   **Needs Exploration**: 
    *   **Active stakeholder participation** - Engaging stakeholders throughout the process to gather requirements.
    *   **High-level requirements specification** - Developing a broad, high-level understanding of the requirements.
    *   **Split (A/B) testing** - Using A/B testing to validate assumptions about the requirements.
    *   **Detailed requirements specification** - Elaborating on the requirements to create a comprehensive specification.
    *   **Acceptance test-driven development (ATDD)** - Developing acceptance tests to validate the requirements.
    *   **Just-in-time (JIT) model storming** - Conducting a series of workshops to explore requirements in a fast-paced environment.
    *   **Look-ahead modeling** - Creating a detailed model of the requirements, considering the future needs of the stakeholders.

These strategies are essential for ensuring that the solution meets the actual needs of the stakeholders, thereby enhancing the overall quality and value of the solution.

During telophase and cytokinesis stages of cell division, here's what happens to the cellular structures:

Cytokinesis often overlaps telophase [1]. During telophase, the nuclear membrane re-forms around the separated sets of chromosomes, which have moved to opposite ends of the cell, as depicted in image2. The image shows chromosomes, likely stained in blue, moving to opposite ends of the cell, indicating telophase. Chromosomes then separate further, and the cell elongates, eventually leading to cytokinesis, the process where the cytoplasm divides, resulting in two daughter cells [2].

![The nuclear membrane re-forms around the separated sets of chromosomes, and the cytoplasm divides into two daughter cells.](image2)

Cytokinesis is the process where the cytoplasm divides, resulting in two daughter cells, as shown in image2. This process is crucial in dividing the cytoplasm and ultimately resulting in two daughter cells.

The cytoplasm, which was present in the original cell, undergoes cytokinesis and divides into two identical cells. This results in the production of two daughter cells, each with the same number of chromosomes as the parent cell. The image2 depicts the process of cytokinesis and the formation of two daughter cells.

Here's a simple diagram illustrating the cytokinesis process:
 
1. The cell membrane starts to pinch inward, forming a cleavage furrow.
2. The cleavage furrow deepens and widens, eventually splitting the cell into two daughter cells.
3. The two daughter cells are now separate and distinct from the original cell.

Cytokinesis often overlaps telophase, and the two processes work together to ultimately result in the production of two daughter cells.

**US Healthcare System Faces Numerous Challenges**
![US has worst outcomes of industrialized nations. (infant mortality, lifespan, etc.)](image8)

**Current State of Computerized Medical Information**
![Current system fragments patient information and creates redundant,inefficient efforts](image4)

The healthcare industry continues to grapple with various challenges, including inadequate security measures and inefficient systems. A study from 2005 and 2006 revealed that security concerns were among the top concerns, with internal breach of security and inadequate business continuity/disaster recovery being the most pressing issues. However, despite these concerns, the industry has made progress in implementing computerized medical information systems.

**Progress in Implementing Computerized Medical Information Systems**
![Electronic Medical Record: 
61% in 2005, 62% in 2006](image5)

Between 2005 and 2006, there was a notable increase in the implementation of computerized medical information systems. The adoption of electronic medical records (EMRs) increased from 61% to 62%, while bar coded medication management improved from 58% to 55%. However, the implementation of other systems, such as point-of-care decision support and clinical data repositories, showed a decline.

**Projected Implementations for the Next Two Years**
![Implementation of Security Measures: 
Firewalls: 98% today, 53% in two years](image3)

Looking ahead to the next two years, the implementation of security measures is expected to be a major focus area. Firewalls are already at a high implementation rate of 98%, but are expected to decrease to 53% in two years. In contrast, user access controls are expected to increase from 88% to 53% in two years. This suggests that while progress has been made, there is still a need for improvement in the security measures of computerized medical information systems.

**Barriers to Adoption and Implementation**
![Lack of Common Data Standards: 2% in 2005, 3% in 2006](image10)

Despite the progress made in implementing computerized medical information systems, there are still significant barriers to adoption and implementation. The lack of common data standards remains a major issue, with only 2% of systems in 2005 and 3% in 2006 using such standards. This highlights the need for standardization and interoperability in the healthcare industry.

**Benefits and Trends**
![Integration and Interoperability: 37% in 2006](image2)

The implementation of computerized medical information systems is expected to continue, with a focus on integration and interoperability. The healthcare industry is moving towards a more standardized and connected system, which will improve the quality and efficiency of care. The benefits of this trend include improved patient satisfaction, reduced medical errors, and enhanced clinical decision-making.

**Conclusion**
![Patient registration/ demographics Insurance validation Billing systems Appointment systems Computerized Physician Order Entry (CPOE) EMR/EHR/CPR Pharmacy systems](image10)

In conclusion, the healthcare industry continues to face significant challenges in terms of security, efficiency, and standardization. However, progress has been made in implementing computerized medical information systems, and there are trends towards integration and interoperability. To improve the quality and efficiency of care, it is essential to address the barriers to adoption and implementation and to continue investing in the development of secure and standardized systems.
